That the South Australian and Australian National Railways systems were intended to provide essential transport services to country, semi-isolated and isolated regions;
Australian National Railways' large increases in freight and parcel rates are forcing people to use Australia Post and road transport services;

Reduce freight and parcel rates to reasonable levels and
Encourage greater public utilisation of the Commission's services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MASON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 146 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and takes all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 38 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That all members of the Women's Services 1939-45 War qualify as 'Australian Soldier' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian Forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies making themselves available for combat duty in War Zones, and according to Acts and Regulations of the period the Military women had enlisted for service anywhere, some Naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force of 1939-45 War who were not sent to War Zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, contingent upon the Patents Amendment Bill 1981 being read a second time and pursuant to Standing Order 196A, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Patents Amendment Bill 1981 be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment for inquiry and report back to this chamber by the first sitting week in September 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Senate is alarmed by the reduction in the real value of payments to the States, and notes:

(a) The Government's failure to honour at any time the unequivocal guarantee given by Senator Carrick on behalf of the Prime Minister on 27 April 1976 that the real value of payments to the States would be increased by more than 57 per cent;
(b) The final repudiation of any intention to honour that guarantee, implicit in the Prime Minister's assertion that the Whitlam formula was too generous to the States; and
(c) the belated realisation by the Premiers, especially Sir Charles Court, that the 1975 Whitlam formula was the most generous ever offered to the States by any Federal Government.
(2) The Senate deplores the wholly avoidable increase in inflation which will inevitably follow when State governments attempt to recover lost revenue with higher State taxes and charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that foreign investment in rural land has risen from $32m in 1978 to $69m last year? Has the number of rural properties involved, particularly in the States of Queensland and Western Australia, risen over the same period from 60 to more than 700? Is it correct, as reported, that wheat growers are concerned that foreign investors are paying well above market value for farms? Has the Government made any assessment of how this increase in foreign investment will affect the economics of the wheat growing industry, which is based upon relatively low cost land for its profitability?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not able to assert the accuracy of the figures given by Senator Button, although I am aware of the movement in foreign investment to which he has referred. I will have those figures verified and seek a response on the questions he has raised with regard to the implications of an increase in foreign investment in this area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services to a report that the $11.5m development of Brisbane's Anzac Square, commonly known as the hole in the ground, is being jeopardised due to the State branch of the Department of Administrative Services refusing to allow minor modifications to the Commonwealth building bordering the square. I understand that the redevelopment calls for supporting attachments to the walkways and that negotiations have been proceeding with the Commonwealth for a number of months without success.

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the time factor involved, which now dictates that this difference must be resolved to allow completion of this project prior to the 1982 Commonwealth Games, I ask the Minister to direct his Department to act immediately and give permission to use the Commonwealth building in the manner required by the State authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bonner, as a senator for Queensland, would be concerned about this project and about the delay in its implementation. I am aware of the area involved. It is not far from the Commonwealth offices. I had a chance to be shown the area on my last visit to Brisbane. I can well understand the honourable senator's concern. I can also understand the urgency which he attaches to the project in relation to the Commonwealth Games which are to occur in Brisbane. I will pass all his concerns on to the Minister for a detailed response to each of the points.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. How widely have the new invalid pension guidelines announced by him some weeks ago been distributed? Why have they not been made available to all offices of the Department of Social Security? Is the Minister aware that people are still being rejected under the old rules because officials say: 'What new rules? I have not seen any'?

—The guidelines are, of course, guidelines which are applied principally by the Department of Health. My advice is that they have been distributed to all Commonwealth medical officers who are concerned with the assessment of applicants for invalid pension. That is a matter which I will have further checked in light of the honourable senator's question, but my advice as of the last couple of days was that that distribution had been completed.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, but it also relates to the Minister for Social Security and the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. I note that Senator Young and I visited the Pitjantjatjara communities last week, from which visit strong urgings towards this question came to us. When will the review of the Community Development Employment Program, CDEP, be completed? When will modifications to improve the program be implemented? Given the general success of the CDEP scheme in Aboriginal communities such as Ernabella and Fregon, is the Minister now able to confirm the extension of CDEP to all of the Pitjantjatjara communities, such as Mimili and Amata, and so overcome the anomalies arising from some communities having the scheme whilst neighbouring communities, to the disadvantage of the whole, have remained without it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that the Community Development Employment Program is a scheme whereby money is made available in bulk to Aboriginal communities as a form of income maintenance, and it is made in lieu of other kinds of welfare payments, for example, unemployment benefit. It can be made only with the agreement of communities involved and it requires them to forgo individual claims for unemployment benefit or other kinds of welfare payments. The scheme is a pilot scheme, as Senator Teague indicated in his question, and it is for this reason that some communities have access to CDEP money and some communities do not. We are not in a position to be able to fund all remote area communities on this basis, and it is, of course, remote area communities for whom it has been basically designed.

ANSWER.PARA: Because the scheme was a pilot scheme, a review was commenced in 1980. That review has concluded. It revealed some unsatisfactory features of the scheme in terms of its operation. I hope to be able to announce soon measures to overcome many of the problems of income maintenance in remote Aboriginal communities. An expansion of the scheme has been suspended pending the outcome of the review. I understand the urgency which the honourable senator as a senator from South Australia attaches to this. I understand the problems of which he has reminded us in the north western areas of his State. These are problems which are common to, say, the central reserves and to remote communities. I must say that CDEPs have been very well received in some parts of Australia, for example in the Torres Strait. I hope to complete this re-examination as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whether he is aware of reports that the Queensland Government intends in August of this year to abolish the Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, to incorporate reserve lands in local government areas and to rescind the notorious Queensland Aborigines Act and Torres Strait Islanders Act? Does the Minister acknowledge that these steps would leave Queensland Aboriginals without any rights to the land that they have been occupying for generations? What steps has the Federal Government taken to ensure the bringing down of legislation that will provide for secure, permanent tenure to Queensland's reserves by Aboriginals who are currently living on them? Will the Government take steps to ensure that such legislation is prepared concurrently with the expected action of the Queensland Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that Senator Ryan does Aboriginals in Queensland a service by assuming that certain events will occur. I have been following, as has she and other honourable senators, the Press comment on what might be happening in relation to Queensland's Aboriginal reserves. She will be aware, as I was, of the statement made by the Premier of Queensland during the last election campaign. She will also be aware of his promise to consult widely. Unlike Senator Ryan, I have been able to make contact with the new Minister for Water Resources and Aboriginal and Island Affairs in Queensland, Mr Tomkins. I have been able, in fact, to visit some communities with him and to discuss some of these problems. I was very heartened by a Press release, dated 15 May, by Mr Tomkins, who after all is the responsible Minister in the Queensland Government, in which he gave assurances that no one would be evicted from his home or from a reserve as a result of any move to repeal the Aborigines Act and Torres Strait Islanders Act. The Press release also stated that no matter what happened to the relevant Acts, the reserves would retain their status under the Queensland Lands Act. I would hope that Senator Ryan would welcome that statement as much as would anybody else. She may indicate by interjection that she welcomes it.

ANSWER.PARA: I note that there is no interjection, Mr President. It is under the latter Act that the land is set aside as Aboriginal reserve--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an extraordinary thing for the Minister to invite an interjection and he should have been brought to order immediately.
—Order! I call Senator Peter Baume.

—Mr Tomkins has said that no matter what happens to the relevant Acts the reserves would retain their status under the Queensland Lands Act, because it is under that Act that the land is set aside as Aboriginal reserve land. I am sure that we are all delighted by that particular assurance. Mr Tomkins also stated in his Press release that moves to repeal the Acts were being carried out in a spirit of full co-operation with the elected representatives of the Aboriginal people. I am sure that all honourable senators would want to know that the Queensland Government is acting in co-operation with the Aboriginal people and is taking into account their views. Mr Tomkins said that Aboriginal views would be taken into full account when decisions were made about the relevant legislation. I have with me a copy of the Press statement and it might suit the convenience of the Senate if I now table it.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister failed to answer the thrust of my question, which was not about the expressed intentions of any member of the Queensland Government. Indeed I did fail noticeably to express my delight or excitement about those assurances. My question is: What assurances do we have from the Federal Government that steps will be taken to ensure that Aboriginals living on reserves will have secure title to that land?

—The Federal Government would want all Aboriginals in Queensland to enjoy secure tenure of the land on which they live. We would be concerned that they should not lose that secure tenure. Apart from that, the question is hypothetical and I do not propose to deal with it further.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications: Will the Government give serious consideration, in drafting the next Budget, to the elimination of the present discriminatory charges that are levied on rural telephone subscribers in the form of installation fees based on distance, and costing $160 per half kilometre; also, the removal of the special rental charge of $380, which is made upon families living outside the free entitlement area, as those charges place an unfair financial burden on people who are already disadvantaged in so many ways by distance but who should be entitled to the services that are enjoyed by those who live in more closely settled areas.

—I will certainly make known to my colleague the Minister for Communications the question raised by Senator Bjelke-Petersen in relation to charges for the installation and rental of telephones for people living in remote areas. This question relates not only to Queensland; it relates to every State. I have received a number of representations from people living in remote communities in my State who are concerned about the costs of such installations. There is a general question of equity to be resolved in terms of cost recovery. I believe the question is complex and that Mr Sinclair will wish to give an answer direct.

—Can the Minister representing the Treasurer inform the Parliament whether the Government has changed direction, in opposition to promises previously made to central Queensland miners, regarding the levying of income tax in respect of homes occupied by miners and others in Queensland? Can the Minister advise whether a special directive has been issued to draftsmen and others to have an amending Bill available for both Houses of Parliament before the end of this session? Is it the intention of the Government to introduce the legislation and to have it applied for the current financial year, or is it intended that it will be introduced for the 1981-82 financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will seek a response from the Treasurer on these matters and see whether I can get an answer with regard to the legislation as early as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TEXTILE, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR INDUSTRY: QUOTAS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs had any reports from Australian textile or clothing manufacturers on any changes, confirmed or apparent, in the level of orders being received from major retailers as a result of the changes in the new broadbanded quotas? Does he have a close monitoring scheme to assess any apparent move? If not, will he establish such a system so that the Government may become aware of any changes that arise, if they arise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some particular information which may be of interest to Senator Archer. On 15 August 1980 the Government introduced a new program of assistance for the textile, clothing and footwear industry to operate from 1 January. The new program is not an extension of current interim arrangements determined by the Government in mid-1977. It incorporates many changes to that. The administrative package to give effect to these changes was expected to be finalised before the end of the autumn session. In fact the legislation was passed in this place last week. The Government has established an advisory committee covering this industry to assess the prospective market growth for quota adjustment purposes, to consider the administrative changes which may be necessary to achieve the Government's objective and to monitor and report on the industry situation during the program.

ANSWER.PARA: The committee recently concluded hearings in Sydney and Melbourne and all interested parties were afforded the opportunity to discuss current developments in the industry sectors. The committee has not yet settled the report which is to be sent to Ministers. I understand that some industry interests expressed concerned about the broadbanding effects that Senator Archer referred to in his question. I also understand that some representations were made to various Ministers concerning this problem. However, I can assure the honourable senator that the Government has it in mind to monitor the new arrangements as closely as possible. The establishment of and the recent round of hearings by the advisory committee are evidence of that determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to either the Leader of the Government in the Senate or the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, refers to the transfer to the State of some 1,200 experienced railway workers in South Australia, a proposal which is contained in the Review of Commonwealth Functions report. I have posed the question to the Leader of the Government because I first ask: How is it that such a proposal is determined by the Government without consultations with either all the railway authorities or the trade unions in that State? Is the Minister aware that the largest railway organisation is of the opinion that such a proposal would reduce the number of experienced railway workers available to the national railways organisation and would lead to a failure to provide proper employment and promotion opportunities for those staff who are skilled in the safe working of railways? Can the Minister assure the railway staff organisations that any such determination will be the subject of discussions with not only the management but also the railway organisations?

—The actual issue is not known in detail to me. I think it is a significant issue. It involves perhaps a number of departments. I will draw the attention of the relevant Ministers to the substance of the question and seek an early answer.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, relates to the Government's decision, announced by the Prime Minister in his statement to the Parliament on the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that the Broadcasting Information Office will not be established. Given the commitment made in September 1978 by the then Minister for Post and Telecommunications, the honourable Tony Staley, that 'A Broadcasting Information Office will be established and will have an important role in the public accountability context', I ask the Minister: Is the Government concerned at the effect which the decision of the committee will or might have on public involvement in broadcasting? Does the Minister agree that there is a need to balance the requirements and interests of broadcasters with those of the community they are licensed to serve? If so, what action will be taken by the Government to ensure that public interest groups are not handicapped by their lack of information and resources in controlling powerful media groups at radio and television hearings before the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal?

—The Government had decided to establish the Broadcasting Information Office, as the honourable senator has said. It was in the context of the Review of Commonwealth Functions that the decision was taken that that establishment should not be proceeded with. Clearly, the points raised by Senator Missen are relevant considerations. Consideration will clearly need to be given to the appropriate place in which the function which was planned for the Broadcasting Information Office should be situated. That is really a question for the Minister whom I represent to decide. I will pass Senator Missen's question to him. I am sure that once that decision is made he will make it known as soon as he can.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is it a fact that 63 Aborigines at Bamyili employed under the Community Development Employment Project have been stood down because of lack of funds? Is it also a fact that they are unable to secure unemployment benefit or any other form of assistance? If these are facts, will the Minister arrange for bridging finance to keep these people employed until funds become available in the next financial year? I feel sure it is not necessary for me to dwell on the effect of unemployment, without unemployment benefit or other assistance, on a significant section of the work force of what is essentially a cash economy community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today in Question Time Senator Teague asked me a question concerning the Community Employment Development Project. The Bamyili problem relates to a Community Development Employment Project. I think the Senate would want to know the facts. They are that the Bamyili council has expended in 11 months the funds which were made available to it for 12 months. The funds were given to it to cover the period to 30 June. This means, as Senator Robertson has said, that until the beginning of July no income is left for the 63 people who were previously entitled to receive income under the scheme. The funds were made available to the appropriate council for management and disbursement. It was due to a failure of proper disbursement that this occurred.

ANSWER.PARA: The Bamyili council has repeatedly been advised that its allocation of funds under the scheme would run out in late May if it continued to spend the funds in excess of the amount provided for each fortnight's salaries. The council was told that it was pursuing a road that would lead to that result. The Council ignored this advice. It continued to make fortnightly payments well in excess of the agreed entitlements under the scheme. The simple facts of the matter are that the yearly allocations have been expended in 11 months. Equally clearly, this concerns the Government. Officers from the Department of Social Security and from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs are examining the problem to see what can be done. We are hoping that something can be done, but the responsibility for the present crisis clearly rests with the council, which chose not to accept the warning about overexpenditure which my officers have been giving it for a considerable period.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I do not think the people of Bamyili are very interested in the pious hopes of the Minister or his Government. What I want to know is whether these people are to starve until 1 July. That is the simple question. Sixty-three people with families will need something. They will want more than hopes that something will be done in the time that is available to us.
—I think I indicated in my answer that I share that concern and that officers of the two departments are now working to see what can be done.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to the rail standardisation program being carried out in South Australia at present involving the extension of the standardised link from Adelaide to Crystal Brook and other works associated with it in the metropolitan area. Does the Minister recall that when this project was approved the Minister for Transport indicated that it would include the extension of the standardised link to Outer Harbor in order to provide an alternative port to the eastern States? Can the Minister say what progress is being made with that standardisation program and whether it is the Government's intention to carry the standardised link right through to Outer Harbor?

—Yes, I recall the Minister's statement at the time of the approval of the Adelaide to Crystal Brook railway that included in that project would be an extension of the link to the Outer Harbor centre and, I believe, also down the Le Fevre Peninsula to Port Adelaide. I have not any particular information on the point at the moment but I will inquire of my colleague Mr Hunt and bring down an early reply on the matter for Senator Jessop.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Has the Commonwealth Government requested Australian Associated Press to provide information in that Association's possession for use by its intelligence agencies, particularly the Office of National Assessments? Does this not put the lives of AAP journalists in danger where those correspondents work in countries in civil turmoil? Having regard to the premeditated killing of five journalists in East Timor by the Indonesian forces, does this not show the Government's callous disregard for journalists' lives and the incompetence of the Australian Security Intelligence Service and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation in intelligence gathering? Further, is the Minister aware that the New South Wales branch of the Australian Journalists Association has unanimously condemned this perversion of such news services, which should be absolutely free of Government interference or influence?

—I am not aware of the matter. I will refer it to the Prime Minister. It may well be that as with all matters affecting intelligence and security it is not capable of public answer. I reject out of hand any suggestion that there is any callous disregard for the lives of journalists or any other Australian. The very regrettable deaths of the journalists in East Timor cannot in any way be sheeted home to such disregard. I know very well the area where their bodies were allegedly found. It is an area that has been war torn for years. I regret very much the loss of their lives but I cannot see how that can be related to any action or callous disregard of the Government. The general question raises the practices of intelligence agencies, including ASIO. I will therefore bring it to the attention of the Minister concerned.

—Is the Attorney-General aware that the State Department for Community Welfare of Western Australia has funded the departure of family law litigants beyond the boundaries of Western Australia and therefore, presumably, beyond the authority of the Western Australian Family Court? Will the Attorney-General seek from his Western Australian counterpart details of these extraordinary circumstances? Will the Attorney-General inquire of the Western Australian Minister for Community Welfare why his Department should interfere in Family Court matters? Finally, I ask the Attorney-General whether he is able to give us a brief explanation of where Federal and State responsibilities intersect in family law in Western Australia.

—I am not aware of the Western Australian Government's community funding in the matters that Senator Martyr raised. I have some general understanding of the matter but not of the specific problem that Senator Martyr is concerned about. Perhaps he would give me more detail about it to enable me to answer his question more fully. Certainly I will inquire from the Western Australian Ministers who may be concerned in this matter. As to the question of the Western Australian Government Ministers having any authority in regard to the administration of family law in that State, I reiterate the fact that the Family Court in Western Australia is a State court set up by the State Parliament. Although funded by the Federal Government, it is a State court and the appointments to it and the administration of it come under the jurisdiction of State Ministers, so they naturally have some rights in regard to the matter. As to the relationship between the Family Law Act and the Western Australian State Family Court, I would have thought that Senator Martyr, who has been a member of a distinguished joint committee of the Parliament that sat for a long time on these matters, would have some knowledge of that situation. Maybe I will be able to assist him in that regard on a private basis on some other occasion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, concerns the Census and Statistics Act. Is it a fact that there has been a considerable volume of protest in South Africa about a survey being conducted by that nation's Department of Statistics into the sex lives of South African women, the survey asking such questions as the virginity or otherwise of the women, their frequency of sex experience, at what age this began and whether they use contraceptives? Is it a fact that when a Natal medical practitioner said 'the Authorities have undoubtedly gone mad . . . The punitive aspect is . . . a disgrace', he was referring to a maximum fine of 200 rand-about $A210-provided in South Africa for not complying with census requirements?

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that any decision to carry out a similar survey in Australia under a law passed in this place two weeks ago could subject Australian women to a fine of $1,000 or six months in gaol, or both, for knowingly giving incorrect answers? Is it a fact that an amendment to remove that penal sanction was refused by the Government at the time the Bill was passed? In view of this, can the Minister give an absolute and unequivocal guarantee that no future such survey into the lives of Australian women will be conducted while the present six months' gaol penalty remains in the law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not have any direct information on the survey in South Africa that has been referred to by Senator Mason. However, assuming that what he has said is correct and that such a survey was undertaken or is being undertaken, I can give an unequivocal guarantee that this Government would not contemplate a survey of this nature in Australia. Perhaps in this context I ought to remind the Senate that under the Census and Statistics Act the Australian Statistician is required to table in both Houses each new proposal for the collection of information for statistical purposes by the Australian Bureau of Statistics before its implementation, unless the proposal for the collection of information is on a voluntary basis.

ANSWER.PARA: Perhaps this may be an appropriate opportunity, in view of the other comments of Senator Mason, to clarify some aspects of the recent amendments to the Census and Statistics Act. The major purposes of the recent amendments were to tighten up the secrecy provisions of the Census and Statistics Act and to upgrade the penalties under that Act. The particular provision to which Senator Mason alludes relates to the offence of knowingly providing false information to the ABS. A reading of the Act will show that the penalty will apply only where there is a deliberate attempt to mislead by providing false information. The provision relates to all statistical collections conducted by the ABS. This means that the penalty is designed to cover not only returns by individuals by also those by businesses and organisations in this country. It should be clearly understood that the new penalty is a maximum one, and in the event of a successful prosecution a magistrate would decide on the appropriate penalty having regard to the circumstances of the case. Again I state quite firmly and give an unequivical guarantee that no survey of the type mentioned by Senator Mason is being contemplated in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. The media-I refer in particular to last night's Nationwide program on the Australian Broadcasting Commission and articles in the Sydney Sun and Sydney Morning Herald-have been asserting that a large segment of the pensioner population will face greatly increased costs as a result of the new health insurance arrangements. As a result of this publicity, there is no doubt that there are many worried pensioners in Australia. Will the Minister give the facts on this situation particularly those relating to pensioners and also to other low income people who do not have the pensioner health benefit card?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I saw a little of the television coverage which was given to an interview with elderly people who expressed concern about the changes. I have little doubt that some of the reports of changes will cause concern to people who are nervous of change and concerned about their position. All pensioner health benefit card holders will remain in exactly the same position as they were. Their position will not be altered, so they have nothing to be concerned about. The only concern that pensioners need have is that there is a change to the hospitals system and that change involves fees being charged to those people who do not qualify under an income test or who are not holders of a pensioner health benefit card. There will be several hundred thousand pensioners who fit into that category. In other words, those pensioners who do not have a pensioner health benefit card will be outside the income limits for being treated as disadvantaged under the new health scheme and will have the responsibility for their own hospital and medical costs.

ANSWER.PARA: Among those pensioners, of which there are several hundred thousand, there is of course a fair range of incomes. All of the people about whom we are talking have incomes well in excess of the pension. A single pensioner would need an income of $40 above the pension and a married pensioner would need an income of $68 above the pension before being in this situation. So it is only people in that group who will have to look to insurance if they wish to get coverage for their hospital costs. A very significant proportion of those pensioners are already carrying health insurance and a good number are people who qualify for a pension only because there is no income test for people over the age of 70 and who are in receipt of substantial incomes. So all of those pensioners who have chosen to insure to date under the existing arrangements are people who now will be financially better off under the health arrangements because they are also taxpayers. Therefore they will be entitled, wholly or in part, to a tax rebate on the insurance payments that they are already making. Recently the Opposition spokesman on social security matters mentioned in a statement that a very large group of pensioners still carry health insurance. That significant group of pensioners will, in the main, be financially better off under these new arrangements.

It is very easy to forget that until a few weeks ago there were frequent complaints about the existing disadvantaged status medical scheme. I received representations which suggested that a situation in which it was left to the judgment of doctors as to whether a person was to be regarded as disadvantaged was one which left disadvantaged people in a position in which the judgments would vary from doctor to doctor, there could be no certainty and indeed there would be cases of injustice. The Government has therefore moved away from that situation of uncertainty. It has provided not only for the pensioners but also for other people in the community on low incomes and it has provided a system by which people will be able to establish with certainty their entitlement to free hospital and medical care.

I have a table prepared by my Department which may be of assistance. Subject to the practicality of its incorporation, I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard. It sets out the various levels of pensioners and others who are entitled to medical treatment under the new system. I seek leave to incorporate the table in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its indulgence. A number of honourable senators have raised matters with me, including when advice will be available, and so on. I can advise the Senate that shortly there will be advertising which will give people the basic outline of the scheme and material will be available shortly at offices of the Department of Social Security for those who wish to inquire about their eligibility.

—My question to the Attorney-General concerns recent changes to the copyright law which are causing a great deal of confusion in educational and other circles at the moment. In view of the fact that when the current amending legislation, the Copyright Amendment Act 1980, takes effect, apparently in July, there will be as many as five alternative statutory procedures applicable to photocopying in schools and libraries, does the Attorney propose to issue an explanatory brochure to enable teachers and librarians to understand and comply with this legislation? Is it true that the only attempt so far to inform those affected has been the printing-at a cost the Attorney might care to tell us about at some stage-of 15,000 extra copies of the Copyright Amendment Act itself, which is a 37-page document comprehensible only to someone with considerable experience in reading statutes and, as such, of course quite incomprehensible to the vast majority of teachers and librarians? On the same subject, I further ask the Attorney: Is it the case that the existing Copyright Act, quite independently of the new amendments to it, does prohibit the videotaping of television programs, whether educational or otherwise, unless the permission of the copyright owner has been obtained? If so, and since the practice of taping educational television programs is now so widespread and has prompted schools and libraries all over the country to purchase videotape equipment at large cost, why was the opportunity provided by the Copyright Amendment Act not used to remove this anomaly in the law? Are there any plans to legislate for its removal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans has asked two quite distinct questions. The first one concerns the amendments to the Copyright Act which were passed by this Parliament in September last year and are to come into force on 1 July this year. Certainly the provisions are rather detailed with a lot of technical aspects to them. They deal with photocopying in educational institutions. The Senate no doubt will be familiar with the long consideration that was given to this question both outside the Parliament and in the long process of the legislation through Parliament. It started with the report of the Franki committee which made the recommendations some years ago. The general principles here were very well known to the educational institutions concerned. Indeed, I am sure all honourable senators will have had voluminous correspondence from both sides-the copyright owners on the one hand and the educational institutions on the other hand-about this compromise. In 1979 I introduced a package which one might say was a rather fragile consensus between these two opposing interests. It lay on the table of the Parliament for nearly 12 months, I think. As I said, it was finally passed in September last year.

ANSWER.PARA: Because of the technical nature of the legislation we decided not to bring it into operation until 1 July this year, another period of nine months. I do not say that every librarian and every school teacher would understand it-I would not expect them to-but I would have thought that the educational institutions which are getting a real benefit out of this would have made some effort to explain it to their librarians and to their teachers.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know perfectly well that it is incomprehensible legislation.

—It is not incomprehensible to the people who can get advice about it, who undoubtedly have got advice about it and who have written voluminous correspondence to members of parliament, including senators, about it. They make it quite clear in that correspondence that they understand a great deal about it. That is the background to the present situation. I have no doubt that when it comes into operation people will have difficulties in learning to operate the system, but I do not think those difficulties will be insuperable. These people will be able, surely, to get some help from the educational institutions which, as I said, must understand it. If they do not understand it, they could get legal advice about it. I am sure that they would have done so. I certainly am concerned about a situation in which numbers of people are required to give effect to laws which are technical and complicated and which they themselves cannot be expected to understand. They may need help and direction, but I question why the Government should be expected to go to a great deal of expense to provide that sort of detail when the educational institutions for which these people work could well take on that responsibility.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second part of the question which Senator Evans raised, it is a very difficult and very sensitive issue indeed, that is, the question of copyright in audio and visual material. It is not confined to this one educational area that Senator Evans mentioned. It is a very wide and difficult subject. It involves the question of whether people should be able to copy and what is to be done. It constitutes a breach of copyright in most cases when people tape music on the radio or from tapes, and so on. It is a very sensitive and difficult subject which Senator Evans raised. It cannot be dealt with just in the one simple way in which he suggested. That is the reason nothing was done about it in the legislation which already has had a very long period of gestation in the Parliament.

I understand that educational institutions are compiling reports on these problems and that they will be submitted to the Government in due course. In addition, a non-government specialist review committee was established in 1978 to consider this question. That report was submitted only in February of this year. So there is already one report by a non-government committee in relation to this issue. The educational institutions are themselves still in the process of reporting on the matter. Certainly, the officers of my Department have been studying the problem for some time. I hope that some way of resolving this issue will be found. Probably amendments to the Copyright Act will be brought down, but I can assure all honourable senators who have any enthusiasm about the matter that it presents the same conflict as does photocopying. There are two diametrically opposed views and some method of reconciling them in a way which reflects a wide consensus must be found. It is of no use sloughing this off as a joke; it is a very difficult and serious subject. I hope that honourable senators opposite will take a more serious attitude to it than they have evinced in the last few minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Having in mind the Government's expressed concern over the continuing low levels of Aboriginal health in Australia, despite heavy funding over the years and the improvement in infant mortality rates such as that being experienced in the Northern Territory, is it the intention of the Government to liaise with State and Territory governments at the grass-roots level in order to emphasise training of Aboriginal health workers by increasing staff levels and funding, to fund only those health organisations that have proven their worth and transfer funding from those with poor track records, increase the availability of specialists to provide continuous field service in such areas as ophthalmology, pediatrics and other specialised fields, and ensure recognition of the principle that improved environmental conditions, such as increased housing and sanitation provision, are essential to improved Aboriginal health?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Government has made clear, it is concerned about the continuing low levels of Aboriginal health in Australia. It is true that over the years Aboriginal health has been the subject of considerable funding. I have been interested by certain recent statistics. Senator Kilgariff has referred to infant mortality rates in the Northern Territory which show some improvement. Some Aboriginal health outcome figures, drawn from the Perth metropolitan area, also have shown considerable improvement. If honourable senators wish to examine the matter further I refer them to the Medical Journal of Australia of the last couple of weeks, in which Dr Michael Gracey has written on the subject.
—It contains a very good supplement.

—As my leader has noted, it has a very good supplement. The writer has produced some figures from Western Australia which bear out the fact that some of the improvements made are real and valuable. It is true that the Government's response yesterday indicated that it would commence at an early date discussions with State and Territory governments to implement its new approach to Aboriginal health. I remind honourable senators of the elements of that new approach. Firstly, the Government is to devote $50m to environmental health projects. I will be announcing today the details of the first $10m of expenditure on environmental health projects, which will be designed to provide major water supplies and sewerage works for Aboriginal communities. I hope that all honourable senators will welcome those projects as a practical earnest of the Government's endeavours in this field.
—No, we don't.

—Senator Ryan says no. The Government will continue to support Aboriginal medical services. It will insist on the collection and production of statistics on Aboriginal health. It will insist upon the provision of goals, objectives and evaluation as a condition for continued funding by the Commonwealth of services for Aboriginal health. We will follow up the trachoma program effectively. We will develop programs in respect of other endemic diseases among Aboriginals. Most importantly-and this relates to the honourable senator's question-we will require significant Aboriginal involvement in the planning, design, control, management and evaluation of health programs for Aboriginals at all levels. If we do not receive those assurances or that co-operation the basis of funding will have to be re-examined.

ANSWER.PARA: The details of Senator Kilgariff's question raise some issues which are not covered by that response of the Government. It would not be our intention to go outside that response. To the extent that some of his propositions would be contrary to what the Government has announced, it would not be our intention to move in that direction. I reiterate our concern to improve Aboriginal health by the measures announced yesterday. I simply reiterate that we have taken the first step today with the announcement of some very valuable projects.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY MOTOR TRAFFIC ORDINANCE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I preface it by suggesting that it can be answered either yes or no. Following the report of the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee on the Australian Capital Territory Motor Traffic Ordinance 1981, the criticisms of that ordinance by the Committee and the announced intention of the Minister for the Capital Territory to replace the ordinance with an ordinance that does not transgress civil liberties, is the Attorney-General prepared to drop the charges under that ordinance against 60 citizens or to recommend that the prosecutions do not proceed?
—I have not given the matter consideration. I will no doubt be doing so in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory. It relates to the announcement about two months ago of the design or exploration study by National Semiconductor for the setting up of a production facility in Canberra. Is the Minister aware that all Press reports about that relate to a silicon wafer production capacity only? Is the Minister aware that National Semiconductor already produces wafers in 15 different countries around the world? If it is only a wafer production facility, what technology transfer would accrue to Australia?
—That question obviously requires to be answered with some details which I do not have in my brief. I will refer it to the Minister for his detailed reply.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs aware that in 1978-79 nearly 14,000 refugees were admitted to Australia, of which only 43 came from Lebanon? Is the Minister aware that in 1979-80 some 20,000 refugees were admitted to Australia, of which only 13 were from Lebanon? Whilst we on this side of the Senate admit that Australia has a humanitarian obligation to accept South East Asian and East European refugees, how can the Minister and his Government justify the fact that presently only 0.06 per cent of Australia's intake of refugees are accepted from war-torn Lebanon? Are there any provisions to broaden the refugee intake from Lebanon, considering that many relatives of the more than 200,000 Lebanese now living in Australia have been suffering considerable hardship and deprivation? Finally, will the Minister give the most urgent consideration to this issue for the benefit of all Australians from a Lebanese background now living in Australia?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and get an early reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Will the Government give consideration to releasing the Commonwealth Development Bank from having to gain approval from the Australian Loan Council before it can tap the general public for funds? What limitations apply to preventing the Commonwealth Development Bank from being placed in the same position as the Primary Industry Bank of Australia which does not require the approval of the Australian Loan Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The jurisdiction of the Australian Loan Council extends to borrowings by the Commonwealth and State governments and, through the gentleman's agreement, by their authorities, including local government authorities. The Primary Industry Bank of Australia has a shareholding divided equally among the six major trading banks, a consortium of four State banks and the Commonwealth of Australia. As an incorporated enterprise with majority private sector ownership, it is not subject to the Loan Council. Under the present Loan Council arrangements where borrowings by fully government-owned banks, such as the Commonwealth Development Bank, are for terms of four years or more to maturity, the amount, terms and conditions of such borrowings are subject to Loan Council approval. The Commonwealth Development Bank undertakes such borrowings.

ANSWER.PARA: The scope of the gentleman's agreement is for the Loan Council to decide those matters. The Government is not able unilaterally to release its authorities, including the Commonwealth Development Bank, from the need to obtain Loan Council approval for borrowings coming under the gentleman's agreement. Perhaps I should mention that the Campbell Committee may well express views that could be relevant to this matter and that Committee's final report is expected to be available in August or September of this year. Any recommendations from that Committee would be considered in the context of this matter raised by Senator Watson. If there is any further information on this subject which would be of interest to him, I will see that he is advised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I have no doubt that he has an answer to my question as he did to Senator Jessop's. I remind the Minister that I asked him a question in February of this year about the expenditure of money on a consultancy firm to change the name of Australian National Railways. He informed me that there would be an expected expenditure of some $409,000 to change the name from Australian National Railways to Australian National. Why is it that in the Adelaide Advertiser of 23 May there is an advertisement under the heading 'Australian National' seeking money for investment in public loan No. 2 at an interest rate of 13.6 per annum and on the same day in the Melbourne Age there is an advertisement under the heading 'Australian National Railways Commission'?
—Could you repeat that? What is that last title?

—It is the Australian National Railways Commission calling for tenders for the design and manufacture of 12 brake van bogies. How can the Minister explain an expenditure of $409,000 to drop the word 'Railways' from the title Australian National Railways and, at the same time, still using that title for the calling of tenders to construct brake van bogies? Is it that the Minister is now agreeing with what I said-that people do not know what Australian National is-and that it was necessary to revert to 'Australian National Railways' because the tenderers would not know what they were tendering for?

—Unfortunately I was out of Australia on 23 May this year and, accordingly, I have not caught up with the copy of the Advertiser in Adelaide or of the Age in Melbourne. I am therefore unable to prove the accuracy of Senator McLaren's remarks. However, I have no reason to doubt that they are substantially correct. It seems to me that there would be some difference in the terms of this form of advertising in that we have a legal body-the Australian National Railways Commission-which is, in fact, calling tenders as distinct from advertising a service of Australian National which, of course, is the railways carrier. It seems to me that there is a distinction between the two forms of advertising. Nevertheless, I will refer the matter to my colleague and get an accurate reply for Senator McLaren.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister that what I said to him by way of a question is the absolute truth. I have the two advertisements here. Can the Minister get that information for me before we get on to discussing the appropriations for the Department of Transport later this day when I will be pursuing the matter?
—I will do what I can to get an early reply.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEREGULATION OF SHOPPING HOURS: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance in her capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and as a member of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee. When the Minister participated in the decision in respect of deregulation of shop trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory, was she aware of the fact that extended trading patterns have resulted in the casualisation of work in the retail trade to the detriment of full time job opportunities for those youths in Australia seeking full time work and being paid unemployment benefit? Furthermore, is she, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, aware of conclusions by the 'Committee of Experts on the Relationship between Hours of Work and Shop and Bank Opening Hours' which held its meeting at the request of the governing body of the International Labour Organisation in Geneva between 4 May and 8 May 1981? The conclusion of that body was that it was in the best interests of all concerned that these matters be determined by legislation, regulation or collective bargaining where the participants had that power. Is the Minister also aware of the conclusions from that ILO conference which stated that any departure from proposals relating to shop trading or banking hours should be taken only after the fullest possible consultations with the persons and organisations, including unions, concerned? Since the union was not--
—Order! Please put the question.
—Since the union was not consulted, can the Minister advise why the Government took this step in contradistinction to the specific decisions and conclusions of the ILO?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The committee for the Review of Commonwealth Functions looked at a number of matters. Information was given to us on this aspect. I do not recall that statistical evidence concerning the degree of casualisation of work that was mentioned by Senator Harradine was put before us, nor do I recall that we considered that what was mentioned by Senator Harradine would be the outcome of the deregulation of shop trading hours. A number of other factors were considered. One further point made in the question by Senator Harradine concerned the International Labour Organisation's conclusions on some of these matters. As far as I am concerned this matter was not brought before the committee that was looking at this question, and I do not recall any great discussion on the ILO. I can fairly say that the matter of some contravention of an ILO decision or position on this matter was not taken into account or discussed by the committee.

ANSWER.PARA: Some matters raised in the question by Senator Harradine require information. I undertake to provide to him whatever information on the subject I am able to provide. A number of factors were taken into account by the committee when it looked at the question of deregulation of shopping hours. It appeared to be a decision that would be in line with the deregulation that we were trying to invoke in many areas of government activity. However, I have noted the matters raised in the question and I will see what further comments can be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Since employment was not taken into account, what factors were taken into account?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine states in his supplementary question that employment was not taken into account. I do not wish it to be inferred that that was what I said. The original question related to the extent of the casualisation of work and other specifics with regard to International Labour Organisation decisions and conclusions. The factors that were taken into account were, in general, the freeing of shop trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory and a number of decisions that had as the basis of their conclusion the deregulation by government of commercial activity. The employment patterns in the Capital Territory and throughout Australia are always taken into account when we make decisions that would affect them. Perhaps it ought to be said that in this most recent month we were very pleased to see an increase in full time employment from the figures that related to March this year. There was a further improvement in April. There is an increase in full time employment.
—Not in the retail trade, particularly in Canberra.

— I do not have that analysis. I think I can check and provide information if the Senate finds it of interest. None of the decisions taken disregarded employment factors. However, I wanted to respond to the particular aspect of the degree to which permanent work would be affected by the decision and the degree to which casual work would be introduced. I will need to have information provided on those matters.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chipp proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The incentive given by the Government to private hospital investment, the excessive entry of overseas corporations into the private hospital field, and the need for a Senate inquiry into foreign and Australian ownership of private hospitals.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank members of the Australia Labor Party for supporting the Australian Democrats in submitting this matter of public importance to the Senate today. Philosophically, it stems from a stance recently underlined by the Liberal and National Country parties that they would transfer activities in this country to private enterprise at any cost. I wish to query today whether it is wise to transfer health care to private enterprise to the extent the present Government is allowing. At what cost will that transfer be done? The Democrats are most concerned about the whole question of the financial involvement of practising doctors in private hospitals. It raises the obvious question of a conflict of interest. Is it ethical for doctors to own private hospitals? One could equally well ask: Is it ethical for doctors to own shares in undertaking businesses or mortuaries, is it ethical for doctors to own a pharmacy, is it ethical for an eye doctor to have shares in spectacle manufacturing companies? In all these areas a conflict of interest is obvious, yet we as a society allow doctors to have an increasing interest in private hospitals. We would have thought doctors should always declare their pecuniary interest before arranging to admit any patient to a private hospital.

SPEECH.PARA: We are extremely concerned about the increasing level of American and multinational ownership of Australian private hospitals. I find it rather sickening-I do not mean to make a pun-that we have multinationals making money out of the sick, dying and frail members of our community. It is an insidious and sinister development which, I must say, I was disappointed to see was not even mentioned in the recent Jamison Report. The fact is that a great number of these hospitals are in Australia now. The four largest investor-owned hospital companies listed on the United States stock exchanges are now established in Australia. They are: Hospital Affiliates International Incorporated, Hospital Corporation of America Incorporated-HCA-Humana Incorporated and American Medical International Incorporated.

I shall deal with each of the four companies very briefly. Humana has been registered in New South Wales since April 1976 but as yet does not appear to have bought or built hospitals here. At a health conference in Dallas, Texas, in 1975 a group of Australian doctors and investors approached representatives of the giant Hospital Corporation of America Incorporated about coming to Australia. In September 1977 a company with the innocuous title Comserv (No. 409) Pty Ltd was incorporated in New South Wales. Six months later it changed its name to Hospital Corporation of Australia Pty Ltd and by August 1978 it was registered in all Australian States. By June 1978 only one of the company's directors was an Australian, the other four being executive officers and or directors of the parent American company, the giant Hospital Corporation of America Incorporated.

One asks: Why would such a giant multinational come to Australia and have itself registered with the innocuous title of Comserv? I questioned senior officials of HCA as to why they entered Australia under the name of Comserv (No. 409). The feeble answers that I got were 'solicitors advice' or 'to establish a presence in the country'. Of course the true answer is that they wanted to enter Australia by stealth so that their presence would not be noticed and they could disguise the true nature of its interests. If Hospital Corporation of America had nothing to hide why did it not come to Australia with a clean deck and say: 'We are Hospital Corporation Australia. We will register as Hospital Corporation Australia Pty Ltd.' But it did not do this; it registered as Comserv. I will give other examples in a moment.

In July 1978 HCA took over the Baulkham Hills Private Hospital Ltd of Sydney for $5m. This purchase had the ever willing consent of the Foreign Investment Review Board, a group whose activities I daily question more and more. The company now owns at least five hospitals in New South Wales, two in South Australia, two in Victoria and one in Queensland. Another multinational business which owns several Australian hospitals is Hospital Affiliates International Inc.-HAI-which is a subsidiary of the giant insurance company of North America INA Corporation. Hospital Affiliates of Australia Pty Ltd was incorporated in New South Wales in February 1979. In March 1979 HAA, again with ready FIRB approval, acquired a 97 per cent controlling interest in the Christo Road Private Hospital Pty Ltd of Newcastle. HAA has four hospitals, all in New South Wales.

The American Medical International Inc. is another company which entered Australia under a different name. In June 1978 Maxmint Pty Ltd was incorporated in Victoria. One could not be blamed for assuming that Maxmint was a company engaged in manufacturing lollypops or some such thing. Later the same month, after its incorporation as Maxmint Pty Ltd, its name was changed to American Medical International (Australia) Pty Ltd-AMI. The company successfully acquired two Victorian hospitals. I am not talking about penny anti-groups; I am talking about giant multinationals which have millions or billions of dollars at their disposal and which use the device of registering in Australia under nom de plumes. Why have these companies decided to come to Australia? Health care in America, as in Australia, is an enormously costly business. America's medical care costs account for nearly 10 per cent of its gross national product, and hospitals are responsible for 45 per cent of that expenditure. In Australia health care accounts for eight per cent of our national income, and nearly 60 per cent of that health expenditure is on hospitals. Recently the United States Government introduced regulations which have the effect of restricting unnecessary spending, particularly in the private hospital area. Therefore, private hospitals in America have been driven to seek greener pastures.

Dr Thomas F. Frist Junior, President and Chief Operating Officer of Hospitals Corporation of America, has stated that these government regulations are his company's greatest concern. HCA's expansion into Australia is part of a plan to develop foreign markets in case domestic controls severely limit the home hospital operations. He said:

It's important for us, as a basic strategy, to start building beach-heads in the international market with company-owned facilities. If . . . a moratorium were put on building hospitals in this country, we could shift the commitment of our money, cash flow and re-investment from the United States to other areas.

That quote is from Modern Health Care of August 1978. Royce M. Diener, a previous President of AMI has stated in Modern Health Care of February 1979 that international operations are far more profitable than domestic operations. What is wrong with us in this country? What sort of people do we have on the Foreign Investment Review Board? What is wrong with members of this Parliament who allow billion dollar multinationals in the health sphere blatently to make that kind of remark. They say: 'Profits are running down in the United States. Let us go to Australia and skim the cream off there'. They are not talking about manufacturing motor cars or selling tractors. They are talking about looking after the sick, terminally ill and frail aged at taxpayers' expense. One wonders why we stand by and take it. These companies cause grave concern for a number of reasons. Dr J. Barrie Morely, a member of the Australian Medical Association who wrote 'Foreign Interests in Australian Health Services', states:
The high degree of profit demanded by and of these companies could have seriously aggravating effects on the major financial problems already in our Australian hospital and health care systems.

In order to continue to attract investor support, these companies must keep showing 15-16 per cent capital return after tax, depreciation etc. Stock exchange listings are watched by the professional analysts, and should they report adversely against a company a critical consequence is that the company immediately suffers a weakening of its line of credit.

In other words, these corporations, like any other private enterprise companies, are profit motivated. The medical services which they provide tend to be rendered for the ultimate purpose of raising revenue rather than out of a central concern for the patient's needs. It is a long cry from the old fashioned view that a hospital existed to care for the needy, the sick and the frail. It is now big business and multinationals are moving into Australia. We are doing nothing to stop them. Some American private hospitals actually advertise for patients. They have demeaned the profession of nursing and hospital administration to that extent. For example, a Nevada hospital offers its customers-I use its term not mine-the chance to win a free $4,000 cruise if they come to the hospital to have an ingrown toenail looked at. This reduces hospital care to the level of a cheap raffle. The United States News and World Report of 5 March 1979 refers to an HCA officer as follows:
Refiguring the cost report of a hospital . . . in order to bring in an additional $100,000 through sophisiticated cost-accounting techniques.

Companies such as HCA often have interests in a number of different areas of medicine-for example, health insurance, medical management and rehabilitation. This vertical integration of health services obviously carries with it the inherent danger of self-referral, that is, the referral of a patient by one section of a medical conglomerate to another. The danger of over-prescription of treatment goes hand in hand with this as well.

American hospital companies are also often accused of cream skimming, concentrating on well insured patients who have relatively simple complaints to the exclusion of poorer people who have complicated conditions. I stress an important point. Because these multinational companies attract government subsidies for health services and health fund payments, their investors will ultimately take profits directly from Australia's taxpayers' funds. It seems to be an incongruity that as I stand in the Senate today, proving that multinationals are making massive profits-16 to 17 per cent after tax-on Australia's sick, at taxpayers' expense, the public hospital system in the six States and two Territories is crying out to this Government for more funds to carry on and offer some form of hospitalisation to the poor and needy.

The indifference of the Foreign Investment Review Board to the influx of HCA and others, to the extent that 7.7 per cent of acute care beds in Australian private hospitals are now controlled by American corporations, is apparent. I propose to quote again from the 1980 FIRB report which makes this statement almost gleefully. Some of my remarks, which were quoted this week, apparently hurt some feelings when I called this group of people who run the FIRB as bordering on un-Australian in their attitude. I do not resile from that description. They are bordering on being un-Australian in their attitude when they allow foreigners to come into this country and to own our motor vehicle industry, our oil refineries, 36 per cent of our manufacturing industry, 56 per cent of all mining, 51 per cent of advertising. The sickening list goes on. The 1980 report of the FIRB states:
In total, 19 applications by United States firms to invest in private hospitals in Australia have been approved in terms of the foreign investment policy.
It is thought that none, or at most one, of the applications was refused. The report continues:

Foreign investment approvals in this industry were expected to lead to investment of $45m . . . The companies concerned are . . . required to admit a minimum of 35 per cent local equity into their Australian operations within three years.

Here is a group of Australians who comprise the FIRB, charged by the Government to protect Australian industry, to prevent takeovers by foreign based companies, gleefully gloating that in one year 19 applications worth $45m-American money-have been approved to take over our private hospitals. For goodness sake, is not this the one thing that we have the wit and the ability to do on our own? Where is the expertise? Where is the new know-how? Where is the technology that these American multinationals are bringing into this country that we did not know about? What is the motive behind their coming into this country? The answer is to maximise their profits because their profitability is running down in the United States. Not only are we not stopping them from coming into Australia but also we have a Government agency like the FIRB gloating that it has been able to allow these corporations into Australia.

In 1978 a deed of equitable mortgage for $18m was concluded between the Hospital Corporation of Australia and the Australian European Finance Corporation. I say this merely for the purpose of putting it in the record. I believe it ought to be put on the record. I state categorically that in so doing I make absolutely no reflection on the Chairman of the FIRB, Sir Bede Callaghan. I have checked what I am about to say to be a fact and I believe it ought to be placed on the record. I invite honourable senators to note carefully the dates. In August 1978 a deed of equitable mortgage for $18m was concluded between the Hospital Corporation of Australia-that is multi- national foreign owned-and the Australian European Finance Corporation. This loan was of great importance in helping HCA to become established in this country. The AEFC is 77 per cent owned by foreign multinational banks. I simply note for the record that between 1970 and 1976 the Chairman of AEFC was Sir Bede Callaghan, the current Chairman of the FIRB. I repeat so that I am not misunderstood that I make no reflection on Sir Bede Callaghan. I do believe, because of the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not? You are challenging his judgment, are you not?

—I am putting it on the record so that the people who might be concerned about the massive inrush of foreign corporations being allowed to come into this country to take over hospitals will know the background to the circumstances of that. It was a condition of the FIRB that HC Australia would divest 35 per cent of its equity shareholdings to Australian shareholders by September 1981. However, it now seems that HCA is seeking a two year postponement from the FIRB owing to the present loss situation of HCA, which I am told is over $7m all told and which HCA fears would make the corporation unattractive to Australian shareholders. How firmly is the FIRB prepared to stick to its original guidelines, or will it cave in again to this massive multinational? It will be interesting to see if it does cave in.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that on the boards of HCA and other corporations associated with these multinationals there are some very distinguished Australians. I will not name them. I make no reflection on them whatsoever. But what I do say is that it is a credit and a compliment to the way in which the multinationals which are invading Australia and taking over our enterprises work. They go out of their way to select distinguished Australians with impeccable records and ask them to sit on their boards. The answer to this lies with the Federal Government. When is it going to tighten up the FIRB guidelines? When is it going to stop favouring the expansion of private hospital development at the expense of public hospitals? When is it going to give some encouragement to those magnificent people who work in charitable organisations, those in the philanthropic field-the Salvation Army, the Catholic church, the Protestant church and the freemasons who do magnificent work in the hospital field? Why not give them some encouragement in their efforts to care for the aged, the feeble and the sick? I give notice that the Australian Democrats are far from happy about the activities of the FIRB and most dissatisfied at the massive inrush of multinationals in the private hospital business in Australia. I give notice that at an appropriate time when the opportunity is available-it is fast drawing near-we will be asking the Senate to appoint a committee to inquire into this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing a matter of public importance which has been proposed by Senator Chipp. The subject really has three arguments to it. Looking at the terms of the letter which the honourable senator sent to Mr President to start this matter running, the first argument of the honourable senator is the claim that there is incentive given by the Government to private hospital investment.
