The honourable senator thinks this is a matter of public importance. Secondly, the honourable senator refers to the excessive entry of overseas corporations into the private hospital field. Thirdly, he refers to the need for a Senate inquiry into foreign and Australian ownership of private hospitals.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe this matter is worthy of consideration by the Senate and that each of the matters raised by Senator Chipp should be dealt with seriatim and should be argued because the provision of proper, decent hospital care for Australians is what we are on about. The provision of medical services which people can use is what we are concerned with. I must say that I could not quite understand the point Senator Chipp was trying to make in bringing in Sir Bede Callaghan's name in terms of his association with some commercial organisation. I will read the Hansard report of his speech. I hope in fact the honourable senator was correct when he said that he was not in any way trying to impugn a very eminent Australian in very many areas.

I will put some propositions to the Senate in relation to this matter. The first is that private hospitals, as opposed to public hospitals, are necessary for Australia today. They are necessary in the Australian health system. Secondly, private hospitals are desirable, certainly with public hospitals, so that we can get a proper mix and people will have a choice. Thirdly, private hospitals need to be supervised for the benefit of the public they serve. They need to be supervised in terms of their establishment, in terms of their operation, in terms of their numbers, in terms of their situation and in terms of their practices. The fourth proposition is that foreign investment in any area requires control, and that control should be present in this area.

I start by suggesting that private hospitals are a desirable, a necessary and a useful part of our hospitals system. Senator Chipp, in the concluding stages of his speech, made a plea on behalf of public hospital development as opposed to private hospital development. He was slightly prejorative about private hospitals as an entity. I would say he is quite incorrect in that assessment. Private hospitals complement the public hospitals system. They often provide services to developing areas of Australia. For example, in my own city of Sydney in the rapidly expanding suburbs they provide the services first; the public hospitals only come along later to provide them. Private hospitals are able to do so because they are more flexible, they can be more quickly established and they can alter their situation to meet changing needs. Indeed it is in some of the growing areas that the private hospitals have emerged. Senator Chipp referred to the Baulkham Hills Private Hospital. That is a fine example of a hospital which was situated in an area where there was no nearby public hospital operating, and where the private hospital filled a vacuum.

It is true to say that the expertise which private hospitals bring is in particularly successful management practices and often flexibility in that they can follow need rapidly and are more sensitive to change than is the public hospital system. I am not denigrating the public hospital system. For 20 years, in a professional sense, I worked within the public hospital system in New South Wales. I have only the warmest memories and associations with the public hospital system, but I would not in any way imagine that we could operate a health system in Australia today without the private hospital sector. We could not operate the health system without our private hospitals. We simply would not have the capacity. The Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals recognised the value of private hospitals. At paragraph 52 on page 12 of its report it states:
Moves to develop practical cooperative service provision ventures between particular private and public hospitals should be encouraged.
I hope that the Australian Democrats, in their pursuit of the public interest, would endorse that recommendation of the Jamison committee. The report goes on to state:

While they may not be cheaper overall, they may lead to more efficient use of resources and can do no harm, provided there is prior negotiation of terms involving all parties including the appropriate State health authorities.

Of course, that is just what occurs. Senator Chipp has asserted that the number of private hospital beds and private hospital capacity are increasing rapidly. That is an easily testable assertion of fact. Is the number of private hospital beds increasing rapidly? Indeed it is interesting if we examine the occupancy figures of private hospital beds in Australia. I make one distinction here. Although figures are boring, these figures are instructive. There are two areas of private bed provision in Australia. The first area is private beds within private hospitals, and the second is private beds within public hospitals. These facts which I will now give from the Department of Health bed days table indicate quite clearly a trend which I think Senator Chipp and all honourable senators would find quite disturbing. They show that there have been fewer bed days occupied in Australian private hospitals over the last five years. If one looks at the figures for 1976, 1979-80 and the estimated figures for this year one will find that compared with 1975-76 there are approximately-my arithmetic, I hope, is correct-240,000 fewer occupied bed days now. The number of bed days occupied in Australian private hospitals has actually been reducing over the last five years.

On the other hand, if one examines what is happening in the public hospital sector in relation to its private beds, one discovers the reverse trend. In fact 700,000 more private bed days were occupied in the public hospital sector. I ask Senator Chipp: Whose vested interest is served by that? Whose vested interest is served by the occupancy of private beds in public hospitals? A new class of elite stands to benefit from that increasing trend. If there is any increasing occupancy of private beds in Australia it is because more private beds are being provided in the public hospital system. It has nothing at all to do with the private hospitals to which Senator Chipp has addressed himself today.

It might be worth putting into some kind of perspective the situation in terms of foreign owned hospital beds, private hospital beds and the number of hospital beds generally. There are in Australia about 95,000 hospital beds. Of these about 1,500 are foreign owned. Senator Chipp was talking about massive investment and massive diversion and a great national problem. There are 1,500 beds out of 95,000; that is the number of foreign owned beds in this country. The onus is on Senator Chipp, in the terms of his own letter, to establish what is excessive. I suspect that his view and the view of the speaker who will follow me is that even one foreign owned bed is excessive. I say that is blatantly nonsensical. We require the expertise of some of these people who manage the largest hospital organisations in the world. For example, they can operate their hospital beds at a fraction of the cost that our State systems can. They operate their beds cheaper and their turnover time is quicker. I shall make some of these points later.

I said there are 1,500 foreign owned beds. In fact 20,000 beds, of the 95,000 beds in Australia are in private hospitals. Senator Chipp has not really established as his first point that foreign ownership of private hospital beds is excessive. In fact he did not produce the figures. I submit that 1,500 foreign owned beds out of 20,000 private hospital beds or 1,500 foreign owned hospital beds out of a total of 95,000 hospital beds in Australia is a very small number and certainly should have been recognised as such. In Australia we have a balance between the public and private sectors. Indeed we have to look at the development of the private hospital sector in that context. The position relating to the companies-I am not sure that Senator Chipp set this out completely-is that Hospital Corporation Australia Pty Ltd has 1,000 of those beds. It has 11 hospitals with 1,000 beds. Hospital Affiliates of Australia Pty Ltd had five hospitals with 363 beds. American Medical International (Australia) Pty Ltd has two hospitals with 194 beds. This gives a total of approximately over 1,500 beds in 18 hospitals.

No private hospital can be established or can operate in Australia unless it satisfies the existing foreign investment policy. That foreign investment policy, as Senator Chipp has acknowledged, is subject to review by the Foreign Investment Review Board, under the chairmanship of a very eminent Australian to whom he referred. Under existing foreign investment policy overseas firms are free to establish new businesses in the health care and hospital industry provided that new investment is less than $5m. If it is less than $5m they are not required to seek FIRB approval. But the fact is that, as a matter of voluntary compliance, the companies coming in to buy private hospitals, even though their investments were less than $5m, on each occasion sought FIRB approval even though they were not required so to do under the rules as they exist.

The businesses are able to expand once they are established. To date, all new investments in private hospitals in Australia have been subject to scrutiny and approval because the companies involved have co-operated. The level of foreign ownership and control of private hospitals in Australia is low. Each proposal is examined separately by the Government and proposals are approved only if it is thought they meet the general requirements of being beneficial to the Australian community. The Commonwealth has no role in determining whether those hospitals will be licensed in any State or whether approval will be obtained for that hospital to operate in a certain situation. That is a matter for each sovereign State government. These hospitals, owned by Hospital Corporation Australia Pty Ltd, AMI and Hospital Affiliates, have opened after having obtained approval from the appropriate State government. I think it should be understood that each one of these companies has the imprimatur of a State government which has determined that the hospital has an appropriate role to play in the appropriate location.

The companies have not in fact constructed hospitals; they have bought existing hospitals. They have not added to the stock. I find difficult to understand the xenophobic hatred of honourable senators opposite for these hospitals. Are they saying that it is better to have an untrained businessman representing an Australian company operating a hospital than it is to have a trained businessman who may represent an international company whose expertise is in managing hospitals? No matter who owns a hospital it will be necessary for him to obey all the rules, regulations and conditions that apply to the operation of hospitals in Australia generally and in any State in particular. There is no way that HCA could come in on a favoured basis and operate its hospitals in a less than normal way. As at 30 June last there were in Australia just under 340 private hospitals. We are talking about some 18 foreign-owned hospitals, about which so much concern has been expressed.

I draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that on 4 March of this year there appeared at page 536 of the Senate Hansard an answer to a question on notice by Senator O'Byrne on this subject. The answer sets out each of the hospitals owned in Australia by foreign companies, also certain other information concerning private hospitals.

Senator Chipp has had some rather harsh things to say about Hospital Corporation Australia Pty Ltd and about foreign companies. However, they, for their part, have tried to co-operate with the honourable senator and have been trying to communicate with him, to make known the facts about the operations and about where they stand. For example, I have before me a letter of 22 May written by Mr T. R. Russell, Chairman, Board of Advice of Hospital Corporation Australia Pty Ltd, addressed to Senator D. L. Chipp. In the letter, which is only a page and a quarter in length, Mr Russell makes several points about what HCA is doing and is not doing. The first is that foreign-owned companies do not enjoy unrestrained entry into the Australian hospital industry; that they have to secure the approval of the Foreign Investment Review Board. That fact has emerged during the debate. He also makes the point that at present foreign companies own no more than 7.7 per cent of private hospital beds in Australia, and that that represents 1.6 per cent of total hospital beds. That fact also has emerged during the debate. A further point made is that HCA and the other companies, far from coming to Australia to cream off profits or to act as profiteers, have been operating at a loss. Mr Russell states:

Far from making massive profits, HCA, and no doubt other private hospitals, have been operating at a loss in recent years. Even insured persons have been so heavily subsidised by the Australian taxpayer in public hospitals that it has paid them to choose treatment in these hospitals.

Mr Russell then gives a figure which shows the extent of that loss. Senator Chipp had this information. He knows that these companies have been operating at a loss, and he knows the extent of that loss. The writer makes it clear that the loss for 1980, as stated in an earlier letter, was $3,045,000; that the total loss since incorporation in Australia has been over $7.25m. Whatever arguments people may put up, I hope that they will not try to sell the argument that HCA is taking enormous profits out of Australia, that it is creaming off Australian profits. In fact, it is losing money. It may assist the Senate if I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard this letter, which is germane to the argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—No.
—If it is not, I seek leave to table the letter.
—I will put the question again. Is leave for incorporation granted?
—I want to know to whom the letter is addressed.
—It is addressed to Senator Chipp.
—How did you get a copy of it?
—I seek a simple yes or no answer to my request.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there any information that you wish to seek, Senator Tate, before I put the question? If not, the question is that the incorporation be allowed. There being no objection, leave is granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: The letter read as follows-
HOSPITAL CORPORATION AUSTRALIA PTY LTD
Senator the Hon. D. L. Chipp,
Leader of the Australian Democrats,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Chipp,

I am writing briefly to follow up the talks which you kindly arranged between Mr Max Edwards of your office and Sir David Hay and Mr Tom Usher of Hospital Corporation Australia on Friday last, 15 May 1981. I do so against the background of statements attributed to you in reports of your press conference at Burwood State College on 10 May. I would ask that in your proposed statement in the Senate you might keep in mind the following points:

That foreign owned companies do not enjoy unrestrained entry into the Australian hospital industry. They have to secure the approval of the FIRB which insists on Australianisation of staff and direction, and also on a suitable proportion of Australian equity, and lays down a timetable for these objectives to be achieved.

In the health field, foreign owned private hospitals, like locally owned private hospitals, can only operate under licence from the State health authorities. This affects the size, location, and type of service offered. Private hospitals would for instance, be involved in any rationalization scheme designed to reduce the total number of beds in any State.

That foreign companies at present own no more than 7.7 per cent of private hospital beds in Australia, and that this represents 1.6 per cent of total hospital beds. Leaving aside religious and charitable hospitals, the maximum percentage of the total Australian hospital industry which could be acquired by foreign companies is 9.4 per cent, if all remaining private hospitals were acquired-which in any case would be commercially impossible.

That foreign companies must operate within the health policies of the Australian governments and of the Australian medical profession. HCA, for its part, has set itself high ethical standards based upon providing the highest quality medical care at reasonable cost. Far from making massive profits, HCA, and no doubt other private hospitals, have been operating at a loss in recent years. Even insured persons have been so heavily subsidised by the Australian taxpayer in public hospitals that it has paid them to choose treatment in these hospitals.

(On page 3 of my letter of 12 May 1981 a loss figure of $3,045,000 is stated. This is in fact the loss for 1980. The total loss since incorporation in Australia is in fact over $7.25m. We understand also that the other American owned major company (Hospital Affiliates) has lost in excess of $2m and we would hope that you would, in further statements, correct the previous impressions you have given of 'massive profits').

That the bed day subsidy payable in respect of patients at a private hospital is substantially less than that payable in respect of patients at public hospitals. This means that the Australian tax payer benefits if, in the areas for which private hospitals provide health care, patients have the opportunity as well as the right to choose the private hospital and not the public hospital.

That the Jamison Report recommended that access to private hospitals be open to both pensioners and the disadvantaged. HCA would welcome this 'open door' policy on the same basis of finance as that which operates in such case when treated at public hospitals.
Yours faithfully,
T. R. RUSSELL, Chairman-Board of Advice

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In the last few minutes available to me I wish to refer to the question of incentive, a matter to which reference is made in Senator Chipp's matter of public importance. Firstly, I would indicate that private hospitals in Australia have experienced diminishing occupancy rates. In 1975-76 they had an occupancy rate of 71 per cent. By 1979-80 that had dropped to something just under 60 per cent. I repeat, such hospitals are an important part of the Australian hospitals system. Just as we could not operate our school system without the independent, non-government schools, which take 22 per cent or 23 per cent of our school children, we could not operate our public hospitals without the 22 per cent or 23 per cent of beds which are taken up by the private hospital sector. For instance, I draw attention to the fact that the Sydney Adventist Hospital in my area plays a very important role in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: The extra $16 a day which has been provided by the Government is the only additional compensation received by private hospitals during a period when public hospitals have been subsidised at taxpayers' expense. For example, although the subsidy will go up to $28 a day for a private hospital, with a rebate which will bring the total to $75, the cost of a bed in the Royal North Shore Hospital in Sydney at the moment is $182 a day. The number of days occupied, under similar conditions, is lower in private hospitals than it is in public hospitals.

The appointment of a Senate inquiry is entirely a matter for the Senate to determine. I only hope that if the Senate does decide to set up such a committee it does so on the basis of fact and that it can competently determine some useful issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Byrne Sen The Hon J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) has given the Senate no cause for complacency about the intrusion into Australia of private hospital investment. I would like to commend Senator Chipp and am very pleased to support his matter of public importance, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The incentive given by the Government to private hospital investment, the excessive entry of overseas corporations into the private hospital field, and the need for a Senate inquiry into foreign and Australian ownership of private hospitals.

The Minister, in the course of his remarks, did nothing to ease the concern felt about this matter in Australia. Does he, in his defence of this trend, believe the new Australian-based American hospital organisations are benevolent societies and that the shareholders on Wall Street will continue to struggle to obtain shares in these organisations when they are running at a loss? Of course, the Minister failed to point out that they, like most other intruders, as Senator Chipp has said, tried to enter by stealth, by assuming an alias and claiming that they were community services rather than the vanguard of American organisations.

Perhaps, to put the matter into perspective, I should say that what Senator Chipp and we on this side are trying to sound a warning to the Government about is the Government's complacency concerning what we can expect here in the future when these overseas organisations proliferate and become established on a scale similar to that seen in the United States. I wish to quote briefly from the New England Journal of Medicine a special article written by Dr Arnold Relman. Dr Relman states:
The most important health care development of the day is the recent, relatively unheralded rise of a huge new industry that supplies health care services for profit.

Proprietary hospitals and nursing homes, diagnostic laboratories, home-care and emergency-room services, hemodialysis, and a wide variety of other services produced a gross income to this industry last year of about $35 billion to $40 billion. This new 'medical-industrial complex' may be more efficient than its nonprofit competition, but it creates the problems of overuse and fragmentation of services, overemphasis on technology, and 'cream-skimming', and it may also exercise undue influence on national health policy. In this medical market, physicians must act as discerning purchasing agents for their patients and therefore should have no conflicting financial interests. Closer attention from the public and the profession, and careful study, are necessary to ensure that the 'medical-industrial complex' puts the interests of the public before those of its stockholders.

Senator Peter Baume told the Senate nothing that would allay the fears that that will happen in Australia in the future. My interest in this matter arose when I saw an article in the Age on 21 November 1978. It was the first reference I had seen to the Hospital Corporation of America, which was then applying for approval to build a new private hospital, to be called Saint Luke's, in Doncaster in Melbourne. A spokesman for the Corporation claimed that fees were to be set so as to provide a profit of 17 per cent on the investment, rising to 21 per cent as the hospital was developed. The project did not go ahead and I understand that there was a court appeal by Hospital Corporation Australia Pty Ltd against the Victorian Health Commission's refusal to allow construction of the hospital at Doncaster.

I must say that it has been in Victoria where there has been most public scrutiny and opposition by the medical profession and resistance by the State Government to the building of new foreign investor owned private hospitals. Senator Chipp mentioned Dr Barry Morley in Melbourne. His vigilance and application to this matter deserve the highest credit. I would like publicly to pay tribute to Dr Morley. The Federal Minister for Health at the time, Mr Hunt, wrote to me on 29 December 1978 in answer to a question I asked about Hospital Corporation Australia. He said:
My consideration of this matter has not yet reached the point where I am in a position to offer a firm view of this proposal.

I thought that was a rather weak reply from the Federal Minister. As I pursued the matter further, I questioned the quality of the advice that he was getting from the Health Department. The Minister seemed to think that overseas investment in Australian hospitals was simply a technical question for the Foreign Investment Review Board to sort out. There was no indication that his Department did any cost-benefit studies on the impact that such corporations would make. When a National Country Party colleague, the honourable member for Murray, questioned the Minister about the HCA and the expansion of the private hospital sector, the Minister admitted that attempts to control hospital costs through cutting back the public sector could be nullified if increases took place in the number of private hospital beds and in-bed utilisation. That was in May 1979.

This afternoon the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has applauded the entry of such hospitals. Yet the Minister's concern at the increases in the number of private hospital beds and inbed utilisation remains unanswered. Now two years later the situation is worse with the beginning of a massive retreat by the Federal Government from the health area. In August 1978 the Australian Financial Review, when reporting the HCA Press conference to announce its plans for a $45m investment in a chain of Australia's hospitals, carried the headline 'Business moves in as Government quits hospital beds'. What will the headlines be in the newspapers in two years time or when we catch up with the situation which exists in the United States at present, as cited in the article I mentioned? That article further stated:

In his farewell address as President on January 17, 1961 Eisenhower warned his countrymen of what he called 'the military-industrial complex', a huge and permanent armaments industry that, together with an immense military establishment, had acquired great political and economic power'.

The same trend has happened in medicine and hospital care. The people of Australia should be warned of it well in advance because it could have an insidious influence on the sick, the aged and those in the community who need medical and hospital care. After all, the claim is made that we are a charitable and kindly Christian society in which one of the first obligations is the care of the sick. The trend whereby the sick are becoming the objects of exploitation purely for profit-making purposes makes the argument of the Minister fall to the ground when he says that these very good Santa Clauses from the United States are running at a loss simply to provide a service for those people who need hospital care. What will the headlines be in two years time or more? Is that what the Government wants for hospitals in this country?

According to the HCA, the only condition imposed on it by the Foreign Investment Review Board was that it should give an undertaking eventually to allow 20 per cent Australian equity. A study by the Monash University Department of Social and Preventive Medicine has indicated a high density of doctors' financial interest in the Australian equity. On 4 December last year I asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health in the Senate whether investment in hospitals by members of the medical profession had ever been assessed by his Department, which after all pays a bed day subsidy to such hospitals. I raised the question of a possible conflict of interest and quoted the then Director of the Victorian Consumer Affairs Bureau, who compared doctors referring patients to hospitals in which they were shareholders with a judge having shares in a gaol and being paid accommodation charges for the inmates. The situation is as cynical and as sick as that. The Director of the Consumer Affairs Bureau recommended that doctors be required to declare their pecuniary interests in hospitals. I got the usual 'none of the Commonwealth's business' reply from the Minister. I point out that the new health proposals of the Government provide for a bed day subsidy of $28 for surgical beds in private hospitals, compared with $16 a day for non-surgical beds. What a wonderful bonanza that will be for the growing number of private hospitals with their American bases.

We know that private hospitals have traditionally concentrated on elective surgery and that Australia has a much higher rate of such operations than does the United Kingdom. The Queen's Counsel in the current inquest into the death of a child after the removal of tonsils referred to a little industry in tonsillectomies involving large sums of public money. The general practitioner and the specialist surgeon to whom he referred the child were both shareholders in the private hospital in Sydney in which the operation was performed, with the general practitioner doubling up as the anaesthetist. The Queen's Counsel cited the claim in the Jamison report that only 5 per cent of the tonsillectomies performed in Australia were necessary. The Monash study of the non-benevolent, that is, the investor owned private hospitals, found that doctors' relatives, especially wives, were also shareholders in Victorian private hospitals. Perhaps the Australian Medical Association should have a stated policy of its code of ethics.

The Minister, during his remarks, made no reference at all to the AMA and its attitude to this new dimension in hospital care and the intrusion of foreign owned and dominated hospitals in Australia. Surely the ethics of the members of the medical profession are still enough in evidence for them to state their view but they are strangely silent on this very important matter. At the moment the Victorian and Western Australian branches of the AMA have passed resolutions recommending that doctors should disclose any such financial interest to the patient. The New South Wales branch is worried by such financial interests of doctors only if the doctor overpersuades a patient to enter a hospital in which he is a shareholder.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that mean?

—'Overpersuades' is a very nebulous and ambiguous word. After all, the traditional doctor has been the be all and end all, the father confessor, the guide, the counsellor and the friend of the patient. Unfortunately, there has been a trend in the last generation for the young doctors to find out where the most cases of infected tonsils are and where the most of other easily removable parts are. As a matter of fact, once someone jokingly said that doctors could almost go into the spare parts business as they were removing parts so rapidly. Patients tend to take the advice of their doctors about referrals. I recommend to all honourable senators an article which appeared in the 23 October issue of the New England Journal of Medicine written by the doctor I referred to previously. He pointed out that in the medical market-place the classic laws of supply and demand do not keep prices down, as was implied by Senator Baume.

SPEECH.PARA: A Senate inquiry into foreign and Australian ownership of private hospitals would be very desirable and would inform this chamber of the extent to which doctors and their families are involved as well as which other business interests are involved. The Monash study was limited to Victoria. It found that nominee private companies, private trusts and benefit funds were not accessible to company searches.

The patient does not make the decisions but is dependent on the advice and judgment of the doctor. Surely the Australian Government should recognise that the people of Australia regard health care as being different from commodities bought and sold in the market-place. Health care is a basic right of all citizens and is a public rather than a private responsibility. I hope that the Senate will give its fullest support to this matter of public importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Davidson Sen G.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is considering a matter of public importance placed before us by Senator Chipp. In his letter to you, sir, he refers to what he calls the incentive given by the Government to private hospital investment and the entry of overseas corporations into the private hospital field and he calls for a Senate inquiry. Senator Chipp is reported in the Canberra Times of 11 May, when speaking at a meeting in Melbourne, as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The number of foreign-owned private hospitals was growing at an 'alarming rate'.
Apparently they are not discouraged by the Foreign Investment Review Board, which is instituted by the Government . . .

One of the factors in the economic and social development of a nation is the combination of elements necessary to provide services for the community and the public. Community services are needed and funding and finance are needed not only to establish them but also to work them. Hospital and health services are among the most necessary services in any society. They are among the earliest services provided in a developing society. In new towns, new suburbs, new country areas and in societies such as ours, hospital services are among the most important services needed as these communities are established and developed.

Hospital services are particularly important. Hospital services are also very expensive. Money must be found not only to run them but also to keep them going, improving and extending to meet whatever the need is. In a socialist economy such services are totally government funded, controlled and designed. Under the present Administration in this country many services of public importance are shared by the private sector one way or another. The involvement of private organisations in the various fields and services is of great benefit to the community. Firstly, it allows the individual a freedom of choice. The matter of freedom of choice may be a fairly familiar thing but I think it needs to be stated and restated. In so many areas of today's society a machine takes over, a network assumes control or a merging takes place and freedom of choice is taken away. It is important constantly to remind the community of the value of freedom of choice. This applies especially in this matter of hospital services.

Secondly, the matter of private organisations within this field provides also for competition. It promotes better quality services and, without doubt, leads to greater efficiency. Thirdly, private sector involvement assists the Government in areas which require large public expenditure. Government and government instrumentalities operate to ensure that many of these services about which I have been speaking are adequately provided. It is under government supervision that private organisations enter into many of these fields.

Foreign investment is a life-giving stream to any economy and any nation. If it is active it indicates that the country concerned is in a stable situation, that it is well managed and, what is more, that it is worthy of the investment. In relation to foreign investment in Australian private hospitals, private sector organisations must meet and comply with the requirements of Commonwealth departments and State health departments as well as, of course, with those of the Foreign Investment Review Board. All of the foreign-based investors referred to in the matter of public importance before the Senate this afternoon have met with FIRB approval. Such approval is given subject to those parties meeting certain requirements and demands. They had to meet the requirements of all the relevant health authorities-Federal and State. Permission is given subject to their agreeing not to expand their operations without taking such proposals for expansion to the FIRB for additional approval.

It is important to emphasise that this is a condition which does not apply normally in other foreign investment areas and under our foreign investment policy. Approval is given subject to the introduction of a 35 per cent Australian equity into their operations within three years. I make the point that the entry of these organisations is closely monitored at all levels and the applications are closely scrutinised. I think it is also clear that the entry of these organisations, particularly into the private hospital field, has been far from excessive.

Combined, the Hospital Corporation of Australia, the Hospital Affiliates of Australia and American Medical International operate some 18 hospitals within Australia, with a capacity of some 1,500 beds. This figure represents less than 8 per cent of the total number of approved private hospital beds and only 1.6 per cent of the total number of hospital beds in Australia. The services offered by these hospitals are of excellent quality and the hospital world benefits from the chains of contact and information about the new technology and access to the new technology which these world-wide organisations can provide. The Hospital Corporation of Australia has given as its reason for the expansion of services and the success of them the quality of its services. If the services had been inferior they would not have been supported by the public and would not have grown.

I turn to the Australian Medical Association Gazette of 30 August 1979. Dr Vincent Youngman argued the case for such companies on evidence he had collected after visiting Hospital Corporation of America hospitals in the United States of America and speaking to their medical personnel. In the first instance he referred to Dr Frist Senior who is the founder of the Hospital Corporation of America. Dr Youngman wrote:
Dr Frist . . . a physician in Nashville, had had a comparable problem to ours in Brisbane-
That is, difficulty in raising finance-

until he linked with a businessman ten years ago. Medicine used business finance and technique. But good medical care is the dominating theme in their organisation and the plan on which their success is based. Medicine needs the financial help of business to implement modern procedures. The type and pattern of treatment is the responsibility of the doctors who use the hospitals. I cannot see any reason why their organisation could not play a role in Australia as we believe in free enterprise.
A little later in the AMA journal the doctor went on to point out:

Private hospitals have to be efficient or they close their doors. This contrasts with government hospitals which can spend large sums of money on inefficient planning and utilisation of resources without any real accountability.

He took up the observation a little later when he referred to the major criticism relating to the profits. He said that the balance-sheet of HCA did not indicate this and that after all, even our church hospitals find that they must have profit to finance change and to proceed with development. So private hospitals have an important role to play in the provision of health and medical services in Australia. Dr Barrie Morley, who has already been quoted this afternoon, rightly recognised that when he wrote in the AMA Gazette that what he termed 'entrepeneurial private hospital services' have assisted in the heavy burden of the nation's health care. That fact was also recognised in a 1979 discussion paper on hospital facilities and charges. This was a paper by Dr Sidney Sax, the man who prepared a report on hospitals in Australia for the Commonwealth Government a few years ago.

The 18 private hospitals in Australia currently operated by these foreign based companies received from the Government a daily occupied bed subsidy of $16. This subsidy is paid to all private hospitals in Australia. This financial year it will amount to $72m. The Jamison Committee report described it as simply 1.9 per cent of the Commonwealth's health budget. Under the new health arrangements due to commence in September this year there will be a new subsidy of $28 a day for private hospital patients undergoing surgery. This will cost the Government $21m in a full year, but only $2m of it will be paid to patients in what are described as the foreign owned hospitals. These subsidies are substantially less costly for the taxpayer than the alternative, that is, payment by the Government of additional costs for insured patients who choose to be treated in public hospitals. Firstly, without that $16 a day subsidy-it has not been increased for the last six years-many private hospitals would have had to close because of financial problems and this would have forced more hospital expenses onto the Australian taxpayers. The hospitals which have been built by these companies and for which there has been a demonstrated need would have added to the Government's costs in the health care area if private enterprise had not constructed them.

The point to be made is that private hospitals, including the foreign owned private hospitals, add to the health services of Australia. They benefit the consumer directly and they ease the cost of provision of health services to the Government, thereby benefiting the consumer taxpayer quite considerably. They take their place also in the provision of employment. For example, at present the Hospital Corporation of Australia, which has been charged with employing a number of Americans, according to information that I have been able to ascertain today, employs one American and all the other employees are Australian nationals. A private hospital, foreign owned or church operated, is no different from any other business. Unless there is a satisfactory service, unless there is good management and unless there is good housekeeping, it will not succeed or grow.

To sum up, as the Minister has emphasised, these kinds of hospitals must meet not only Commonwealth requirements but also the requirements of State government, and at every point they need the approval of the State authorities. It is wrong to suggest that States are concerned only with foreign owned private hospitals. Three States have taken steps to control the growth of private hospitals in the same way as all States have expressed their control over public hospitals. The supply of hospital beds, both public and private, is under the control of the States, and the Commonwealth's decisions on health funding will encourage States to examine more closely growth in the total hospital system.

At present foreign companies own, as I have said earlier, about 8 per cent of private hospital beds. No progressive country can live entirely without technology and introductions of new technology from overseas. The private hospital system that is outlined in today's matter of public importance provides the Government, the taxpayer and the consumer with not only a choice but also a quality service. It is saving the taxpayer money and assisting the Government in the total health program, and it provides a freedom of choice in that program. Furthermore, private hospitals are recognised by the Jamison inquiry. The Commission's report stated at page 314 of volume 2:

The Commission is convinced of the important and needed role which the private hospitals play in Australian health services especially for short-term, simple medical, surgical, obstetric and psychiatric care.

The last item in Senator Chipp's matter of public importance, namely, the need for a Senate inquiry into foreign and Australian ownership of private hospitals, is a matter for decision by the Senate. Senate inquiries usually spring from a circumstance in the community which the Senate feels it is necessary to investigate. So it becomes a matter of persuading the Senate that it should undertake such an inquiry. This persuasion is usually initiated within groups or party rooms and finally determined on the floor of the Senate. The opportunity to reach such a determination in the Senate later this year is well known to all honourable senators. I have no doubt that the approach to Senate inquiries may very well have a different emphasis to that which it has had in the past. Mr President, any matters relating to public and personal health are of importance. It is well submitted, as Senator Chipp's letter has said, for discussion. However, I think the matter has taken sufficient of the Senate's time today, so I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DAY AND HOUR OF MEETINGSUSPENSION OF STANDING ORDER 68

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I amend General Business, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in the name of Senator Carrick, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Substitute 9 a.m. for 10 a.m. and 4 p.m. for 5 p.m.
Motion (by Senator Durack, for Senator Carrick), as amended, agreed to:
(1) That, unless otherwise ordered, the Senate meet on Friday, 5 June 1981, at 9 a.m. and that the sessional order relating to the adjournment of the Senate have effect at 4 p.m. on that day.
(2) That, unless otherwise ordered, Standing Order 68 be suspended for the remainder of the present period of sittings.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Speaking on my own behalf and on behalf of Senator Cavanagh, who is at a meeting, I once again lodge our objection to the fact that the right to discuss General Business is to be taken away from honourable senators on this side of the chamber. I know that we do not have the numbers to change the situation. It has been said that the situation will be different when the Senate resumes for the Budget session, that senators will be given the right to debate General Business. I place on record Senator Cavanagh's and my objections to this move.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Durack) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act for the purpose of statute law revision and other purposes.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Statute Law Revision Bill 1981 has three purposes. First, it is designed to correct some printing and drafting errors that have been found to exist in a number of Acts. Secondly, it provides for the repeal of a number of Acts and provisions of Acts the operation of which is exhausted or which are no longer required. Thirdly, it makes a number of technical or minor amendments which, whilst having some substance, are regarded as being of a non-controversial nature. The Government has decided to introduce Statute Law Revision Bills into the Parliament on a regular basis, at least once in each year and, if required, once in each sitting. This will enable the prompt correction of mistakes and errors and removal from the statute book of expired laws. In the absence of the regular passage of Bills of this kind, the correction of an error in an Act can only be achieved by having a special Bill passed for that purpose or waiting until the Act needs to be amended for some other more important purpose. An objection sometimes made to omnibus amending Bills is that they result in so-called 'hidden' amendments. However, the Government Printer now issues monthly tables of Acts passed by the Parliament and these tables indicate clearly whenever an Act is amended by an omnibus Act such as a Statute Law Revision Act.

The provisions of the present Bill that deal with the correction of errors and the repeal and amendment of expired laws do not call for particular comment. I propose to explain in some detail the nature and effect of the provisions of substance.
Acts Interpretation Act 1901

The Bill provides in Schedule 1 for the insertion in the Acts Interpretation Act of a provision that is relevant to the whole body of statute law. The provision is to the effect that, in the interpretation of a provision of an Act, a construction that would promote the purpose or object underlying the Act, whether that purpose or object is expressly stated in the Act or not, shall be preferred to a construction that would not promote that purpose or object. Mr President, under our constitutional arrangements it is the function of an independent judiciary to interpret the law and no proposals which we make can or should undermine the freedom that this function requires. Nevertheless the general approach to be adopted to statutory interpretation is something which this Parliament can-and at this stage should-address. The volume and complexity of legislation are assuming daunting proportions and the task of understanding and applying it grows in proportion. Increasingly the more significant decisions our courts are called upon to make turn on a point of statutory interpretation. Our problems are not unique. They are shared, for example, by the British Parliament, to which proposals have been made along the lines now proposed by this Bill. The British proposals, I should add, have been initiated and supported by very distinguished law Lords, including Lord Scarman and Lord Wilberforce.

The effect of the provision to be inserted in the Acts Interpretation Act will be to confirm that in interpreting provisions regard is to be had to the object or purpose underlying the Act in question. I am not among those who would say that the general approach of our courts is at present overly legalistic, but I do think that there is scope for expressly stating that the statutes we make are to be interpreted in a purposive manner. Tax decisions constitute a topical and important example that will come readily to all senators' minds, but the matter has wider implications that extend to many other statutes. I therefore commend the provision to the Senate, but before moving on I should invite the Senate's attention to some related questions. Explanatory material is often provided by the Government to assist senators and members, and subsequent users of legislation. The material is of particular value where legislation is complex or specialised in subject matter or both.

I think that we need to consider placing this practice on a more regular basis, even to the extent of having an explanatory memorandum approved by the Parliament and able to be taken into account by the courts in interpreting difficult provisions in the Act. The memorandum could not and would not be controlling. However, apart from contributing to the ease with which an Act can be understood by the public as well as by senators and members, such a practice offers the hope that the draftsman, when faced with the difficult choice of either using general language which might, however, leave the courts without sufficient guidance, or introducing lengthy detailed provisions, could feel some security in choosing the former course if he knew that a memorandum approved by the Parliament would embody its intent.

A cognate question arises where an Act is based on an expert report tabled in the Parliament for example by the Law Reform Commission. Courts can at present consider such reports, but the precise way in which they can use them has been the subject of dispute. The fear has been expressed that the use of extraneous materials such as reports and explanatory memoranda will increase the cost and length of legal proceedings. Certainly the possible disadvantages have to be considered and weighed against the benefits that would flow from the use of such materials. The time has come, however, when the matter should be fully explored and I take the opportunity of stating to the Senate that I propose to do so with a view to developing specific proposals that can be brought into the Parliament for further consideration. In the meantime, the present position on the use of extraneous materials is preserved by stating in the proposed new provision that it is not to be construed as authorising the consideration of extraneous materials for any purpose for which they could not be considered if the new provision had not been enacted.
Administrative Appeals Tribunal 1975

Part II of the Bill repeals the provisions of the Schedule to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 that confer jurisdiction on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in matters arising under various other Acts, and other parts of the Bill re-enact the provisions concerned as part of those other Acts. In the course of transferring these provisions from one Act to another, Part IV omits the requirement that the Tribunal be constituted by a presidential member sitting alone when a decision is being reviewed under section 20 of the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Act 1969. That section empowers the Commissioner of Taxation to revoke a banker's authority to issue cheque forms that are pre-stamped with the duty payable under that Act if the banker is convicted of an offence against that Act. Part XI provides for the Tribunal to have jurisdiction to review decisions of the Collector of Customs under sections 22 and 23 of the Distillation Act 1901. Those sections relate to the renewal of licences to distil spirits. In all other respects these amendments do not make any change in substance to the jurisdiction of the Tribunal.
Schools Commission Act 1973, Tertiary Education Commission Act 1977

The Bill provides for the word 'Commonwealth' to be included at the beginning of the names of the Schools Commission, the Schools Commission Advisory Boards and the Tertiary Education Commission and provides for these bodies to perform the same functions in relation to the Northern Territory as they perform in relation to a State. Clause 117 amends references in various Acts to the former names of these bodies.
Defence Act 1903, Air Force Act 1923 and Naval Defence Act 1910

The amendments made by Parts III, X and XV and clause 116 give effect to recommendations made by the Millar Committee report on the Citizen Military Forces in 1974 regarding the title and structure of the Army Reserve. The Millar Committee recommended that the Citizen Military Forces be retained as the country's immediate reserve of Army units and be renamed the Australian Army Reserve. The Committee also recommended that the members of the Regular Army Reserve, the Regular Army Emergency Reserve and the Reserve Citizen Military Forces be brought into this single Army Reserve organisation. On 4 April 1974, the report was tabled in the House of Representatives by the then Minister for Defence, who announced approval of these two recommendations. It was not appropriate to proceed with formal amendment to the titles and structures of the Reserve Forces until the Government had considered a further recommendation of the Committee that the Army Reserve be available for service in situations short of a proclaimed time of defence emergency. Honourable senators will recall that in January 1980 the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) announced that the Government had decided not to vary the availability for service of the Army Reserve.

In recommending a change to the title of the Citizen Military Forces, the Millar Committee recognised the concern within that force that the existing title misrepresented the nature of the Citizen Military Forces. It was considered that the essential nature of the force was more accurately reflected in the title 'Australian Army Reserve'. The validity of the Committee's view is shown by the general acceptance of the title 'Army Reserve', except where the use of the present formal title 'Citizen Military Forces' is dictated by legal requirements. Before legislation could be introduced to reflect the new title, it was necessary to consider whether corresponding title changes should be made to the Citizen Naval Forces and the Citizen Air Force. It was also necessary to consider the structures of the Citizen Forces of all three Services because some of the elements of those forces bore derivative titles such as Active Citizen Military Forces and Active Citizen Air Force.

The Bill amends the Defence Act to rename the Active Citizen Military Forces as the Active Australian Army Reserve and the Reserve Citizen Military Forces as the Inactive Australian Army Reserve. The Regular Army Reserve, which is a non-training element of the Permanent Military Forces, is abolished and its members are transferred to the Inactive Reserve. In the context of Reserve Forces, 'Active' denotes those elements the members of which have specific training obligations. The Bill also removes from the Defence Act reference to the unattached list and the Reserve of Officers. These relate to the internal administrative arrangements of the Active and Inactive Reserves, respectively, which are matters of administrative detail appropriate to be dealt with by the regulations or by determinations under section 33 of the Defence Act. It has been decided not to incorporate the Regular Army Emergency Reserve into the Australian Army Reserve as recommended by the Millar Committee. The Emergency Reserve comprises former members of the Regular Army who agree to become members on cessation of their Regular Army service. Members may be called out by the Governor-General when he considers it desirable to do so.

The enactment of the provisions of the Bill to which I have referred will bring to finality implementation of the recommendations of the Millar Committee, except for those few recommendations with which the Government has chosen not to proceed. Parts III and XV of the Bill amend the Air Force Act 1923 and the Naval Defence Act 1910 to make amendments in relation to the Air Force and the Navy corresponding to the amendments made in respect of the Army. The Bill renames the Citizen Air Force as the Australian Air Force Reserve. It also restructures the Reserve so that the Active Citizen Air Force becomes the Air Force Active Reserve, the Air Force Reserve become the Air Force General Reserve and an additional element, the Air Force Specialist Reserve, is introduced. The Air Force Specialist Reserve will comprise officers and airmen having specialist skills, such as doctors, dentists, lawyers and chaplains. Members of the General Reserve and the Specialist Reserve will not usually have peace time training obligations. The Bill renames the Citizen Naval Forces as the Australian Naval Reserve. It does not deal with the elements into which that body is divided because this is dealt with in regulations under the Act.

The opportunity has been taken to revise the provisions of the Defence Act, the Air Force Act and the Naval Defence Act with regard to the rendering of service-other than continuous full time service-by members of the Reserve Forces. The revised provisions are more closely tailored to the needs of the Reserves and provide more accurately for the regulations relating to obligatory and voluntary periods of non-continuous service. Clause 116 amends references in various Acts to the former titles of the Reserve Forces and to 'continuous full time service'.
Federal Court of Australia Act 1976

Schedule 1 amends the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 so as to permit an affidavit to be sworn before a district registrar and a deputy district registrar of the court. It also amends that Act so as to enable a reserved judgment to be delivered at any subsequent sitting of the Court, whether or not the Court is sitting as a full court.
Historic Shipwrecks Act 1976

Part XIII amends sub-section 3 (5) of the Historic Shipwrecks Act 1976. The Amendment relates to the description of the area adjacent to Queensland contained in the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 and is, consequential on an alteration that is proposed to be made to that description by another Bill during the present sittings.
Migration Act 1958

The purpose of the amendments made to the Migration Act 1958 by clause 59 is to overcome a problem resulting from the amendments of section 16 of the Act that were made by the Migration Amendment Act 1979. Section 16 deems to be a prohibited immigrant a person who, for the purpose of securing entry into Australia, produces or produced to an officer an official document that was not issued to him or was forged or obtained by false representation. A doubt has arisen as to whether section 16 would apply to a person who produced a visa or return authority to an officer before 1 November 1979, which was the date on which the amending Act came into force, in a case where the visa or return authority was not a separate document but was stamped in the person's passport. The amendment will make it clear that the section will apply in such a case. Clause 2 will make the amendment retrospective to 1 November 1979.
Navigation Act 1912
Schedule 1 amends the Navigation Act 1912 so as to enable judges of the Federal Court to sit on courts of marine inquiry without the need for special authorisation by the Governor-General.
Parliamentary Counsel Act 1970

Schedule 1 amends the Parliamentary Counsel Act 1970 to remove any doubts as to the validity of the long-standing practice of making dormant acting appointments to the offices of First and Second Parliamentary Counsel. These are appointments that are made in anticipation of any absences from duty of the holders of those offices and are designed to take effect automatically whenever an absence occurs during the currency of the relevant acting appointment.
Pig Industry Research Act 1971

Schedule 1 inserts the word 'Australian' at the commencement of the name of the Pig Industry Research Committee, which is constituted under the Pig Industry Research Act 1971. This will bring the name of the Committee into line with similar committees established under other Acts.
Public Service Act 1922

Clause 79 corrects an obsolete cross-reference in sub-section 82 (6B) of the Public Service Act 1922. That sub-section provided that the services of a temporary employee to whom Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979 applied could not be dispensed with except on the ground that the employee had been guilty of conduct which, if he were an officer, would constitute an offence referred to in sub-section 55 (1) of the Public Service Act. However, on 15 March 1981 the provisions of sub-section 55 (1) were replaced by the new disciplinary provisions of Division 6 of Part III of the Act. Clause 79 therefore omits the reference to the repealed sub-section 55 (1) and replaces it with a reference to specified grounds of dismissal, which are the same grounds as are set out in the new Division 6 of Part III of the Act. Clause 2 provides that clause 79 is to be deemed to have come into operation on 15 March 1981.
Social Services Act 1947

Schedule 1 amends the Social Services Act 1947 to enable claims for age, invalid or widows pension, or sheltered employment allowance, to be lodged with any registrar. That Act presently requires such claims to be lodged with the registrar whose office is nearest the place of residence of the claimant.
Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975

In 1979 the Australian Council of Salaried and Professional Associations and the Australian Council of Trade Unions were amalgamated and the former body ceased to exist. Part XXIII provides for the abolition of the offices of the persons representing the former body on the Australian Council for Union Training, and on each of the State Councils for Union Training, established under the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975, but it increases by one the number of persons representing the ACTU on each of those councils. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The speeches read as follows-
Customs Amendment Bill 1981

The principal purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Act to give effect to a number of recommendations of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs. The royal commission made a large number of recommendations. In many cases only administrative action was recommended or was found to be required on an examination of the recommendations. There has been substantial progress already towards implementation of those recommendations. Other legislative recommendations did not relate to the Customs Act. Some required action by the Governments of the States and the Northern Territory. These amendments give effect to the Government's decisions on those of the royal commission's recommendations which are considered by the Government to require action by way of amendment to the Customs Act.

The royal commission recommended that responsibility for narcotics control under the Customs Act in situations beyond the Customs barrier should be transferred from the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs to the Australian Federal Police. This recommendation has been implemented by an Administrative Direction and Administrative Arrangements Order. This Bill contains provisions to give clear legislative authority for the division of powers and functions. The division particularly affects the seizure of goods and their custody, claims for recovery of seized goods, avenues of redress and the final disposal of any seized goods which become condemned to the Commonwealth. The proposed amendments are contained in clauses 3, 26, 33, 34, 36 and 38.

Clause 25 is proposed to implement the recommendation of the royal commission that a person seeking to clear goods through Customs might be required to disclose and prove his identity or the identity of the owner of the goods. This measure is designed to facilitate the apprehension of those importers of illicit narcotic drugs who address the drugs to ficticious persons for collection by anonymous agents. The royal commission also recommended that the Customs control over ships and aircraft at sea or in air space within three nautical miles of the Australian coast should extend to the area within 12 nautical miles of the coast. This is consistent with international law and convention.

The Bill implements that recommendation in clauses 12, 24 and 29. However, the Bill provides that the limitation to the area within 12 nautical miles will apply only to foreign ships and aircraft. Customs control over Australian ships and aircraft will be exercisable to the full extent consistent with international law and convention. The Bill also proposes a number of amendments of a more general nature. These amendments flow from a continuing process of review and modernising of the Customs Act. All imported goods become subject to Customs control on importation. They remain subject to this control until they are released by Customs. The control is essential to the Customs barrier against prohibited imports such as narcotics or quarantinable goods. It is also essential to Customs' duty collection role. The control usually is exercised through a system of documentary checks. These necessarily are supplemented by physical examination of a proportion of the imports.

The Customs Act imposes responsibilities on those who are in possession of goods which are subject to Customs control. They are required to keep the goods safely and to produce them or account for them when so required by Customs. The Customs Act now recognises the passing of Customs entries as the principal authority for dealing with imported goods. When the entry is endorsed as passed the entry document remains in the possession of the Customs. It has been necessary to develop administrative procedures for a written authority to be given to the person in possession of the goods. The authority allows the person, usually a shipping company or an airline, to deliver the goods for the purposes for which they have been entered; for example for warehousing or for home consumption.

It is proposed to give legislative effect to that practice by replacing the passing of entry by the giving of an authority to deliver the goods. Clause 9 proposes that delivery authorities may be as prescribed by regulation. Almost half of the clauses of the Bill are consequential on these changes. The delivery authority will usually be given on the basis of an examination of commercial documents furnished by the owner of the goods, or his agent. However, intelligence may be received from other sources suggesting that narcotics may be concealed in the goods or that the goods are not properly described in the documents. Provision is made, therefore, to permit an authority to be suspended in order to allow a physical examination of the goods.

It is now an offence to move, alter or interfere with goods which are subject to Customs control. This offence is too limited in its present terms. The employee who improperly moves the goods will be liable. The principals, who have the responsibility to keep the goods securely, are not liable for their failure to implement and oversight effective systems for that purpose. Accordingly, Clause 5 now proposes that principals should be liable for the acts of employees involved in the unauthorised movement of goods which are subject to Customs control. A defence is provided to protect those principals who do take reasonable precautions and exercise due diligence to ensure proper compliance with the Customs Act. Clause 13 proposes an amendment to section 64 to authorise regulations to prescribe the time and manner for ships, aircraft and their cargo to be reported to Customs after arriving from overseas.

Last year the Customs Act was amended to provide a means for dealing with refugee boats or other illegally imported vessels. Clause 26 now proposes new sections to supplement those powers. New section 207 will permit the speedy disposal of a seized vessel that is too unseaworthy to be maintained by Customs. Customs will be able to dispose of the vessel even though it has not been condemned to the Commonwealth. This will reduce the costs now incurred in keeping such vessels. New section 208B provides that a person with an interest in the vessel has a right to take proceedings to recover the proceeds of any sale of the vessel or the value of any destroyed vessel.

New section 208E allows conditions to be imposed on the sale or disposal of ships or aircraft which have been condemned to the Commonwealth. By clause 30 they may again be forfeited if the conditions are not complied with.

Customs Tariff Proposals are introduced into the Parliament from time to time following Government decisions to alter the Customs duty on imported goods. These Proposals are usually incorporated in a Customs Tariff Amendment Bill or a Customs Tariff Validation Bill. Clause 28 proposes to amend section 226 to extend the validity period of Customs Tariff Proposals from 6 months to 12 months.

The proposed extension of the life of Proposals will reduce the number of Customs Tariff Bills. It will not diminish in any way the authority of the Parliament to scrutinise Customs tariff changes. Provision is made in clause 35 to allow Customs Tariff Notices to have up to 6 months retrospective effect except where the proposal alteration would increase the duty payable. Honourable senators, the Bill represents a desirable advance towards a modernised Customs Act and will assist effective Customs administration. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Excise Amendment Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to amend section 114 of the Excise Act 1901 to extend the validity period of Excise Tariff Proposals from 6 months to 12 months. This amendment is being proposed as a consequence of the Customs Amendment Bill 1981. That Bill similarly proposes an extension to the validity period of Customs Tariff Proposals. Excise Tariff Proposals are introduced into the Parliament from time to time following a Government decision to alter excise duty. It has been the practice to incorporate the Tariff Proposals into an Excise Tariff Amendment Bill. These are normally introduced late in a parliamentary sitting.

When an Excise Tariff Amendment Bill is unable to achieve passage prior to six months after a proposal is introduced, it has also been the practice to validate that proposal by an Excise Tariff Validation Bill. This proposed amendment will have the effect of reducing the number of Excise Tariff Bills. It will not however diminish in any way, the authority of the Parliament to scrutinise excise tariff changes as they occur. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
