SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night, when the Committee debated the departments in group B-namely, the Department of Education, the Department of Communications and the Department of Home Affairs and Environment-I moved a motion which referred the first annual report of the Special Broadcasting Service for the period 1 January 1978 to 30 June 1979 and the second annual report of the Special broadcasting Service for the period 1 July 1979 to 30 June 1980 to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and I spoke to that part of the motion. At that time I did not address remarks to the rest of the motion, namely, that the Committee on Finance and Government Operations examine and report instances where departments and authorities may have breached statutory reporting requirements and the matter of financial assistance for the exhibition tour of the United States of America by the speed boat Spirit of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As I discern the position no further senators want to speak on the estimates for the Department of Communications. Therefore I will comment on the section of the report which relates to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and to the third and fourth parts of my motion. The third part follows on from the first and second parts which relate to reporting by the Special Broadcasting Service. I do not intend to give details-unless honourable senators are interested in details-of the allegation that it appears that other groups have not met their responsibilities in reporting to Parliament. The Finance and Government Operations Committee will go into that matter in some detail. I will speak very briefly on the fourth matter-the matter of financial assistance for the exhibition tour of the United States of America by the speed boat Spirit of Australia. One of my principal concerns on the evidence received in relation to granting $93,000 for the purpose of this tour is that that matter arose as a result of questions I asked about the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. I am concerned whether that Advance was properly used in this instance. I make it clear that it is certainly not my intention to pass any judgment on Mr Warby, whether he should have received that grant and the value of the tour because the evidence requested by Estimates Committee B did not indicate whether that tour was successful, worth while or anything else. I cannot comment on whether it was a good thing or whether it was done properly. The matter will be looked at by the Finance and Government Operations Committee. Nevertheless, I emphasise that the whole issue arose in relation to the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

In the comments I will make today I will refer further to the subject of the Advance to the Minister for Finance, evidence that came up in Estimates Committee B and other matters which relate to the general conduct of Estimates committees and the quality of evidence received by them. I have never, in my seven years' experience on Estimates committees, had anything like the range of extraordinary experiences that I had on Estimates Committee B in relation to both issues and evidence presented to the Committee.

I will pursue for a moment the subject of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. Yesterday the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) made a statement to the Senate, in response to a report from the Finance and Government Operations Committee, on the subject of the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. I am sure that those positive recommendations which she indicated will be acted on by the Government. Indeed some recommendations already have been acted on and will be welcomed by the Senate as they assist its consideration of government policies in relation to expenditure. They may tighten up a situation which is altogether too lax at the moment.

A couple of noteworthy examples came to the attention of the Committee. I refer to page 12 of Estimates Committee B's report on the subject of a Southern Cross Replica Museum Trust. Evidence was given to the Committee that an advance of $50,000 had been made to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment for this item. I remind the Committee that the general principle is that money from the Advance to the Minister for Finance does not come in the course of normal appropriations for departments; it comes from an amount of money voted to the Government to enable it to meet urgent and unforeseen expenditure. We like to be assured that it is for that purpose. The advance for the Southern Cross Replica Museum was for $50,000. When questions were asked about why this money was either urgent or unforeseen or urgent and unforeseen, it turned out that only $15,000 of the $50,000 requested by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment from the Department of Finance was indeed urgent. Evidence indicated that $35,000 could have waited until Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1980-81 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1980-81.

We sought an explanation from the officer from the Department of Finance who attended our Committee hearing. He did not have the information available nor did he have any reason to have it with him as no indication had been given to him that he would have to answer these questions. So we did not advance any further on why $50,000 was provided when only $15,000 was requested urgently. I will quote from page 13 of the report of Estimate Committee B which cites written evidence from the Department of Finance. It states:
Contrary to the advice given by the Departmental witness to the Committee, the Department of Finance was not told that only $15,000 of the grant was required immediately.

I cannot guess why the Department of Home Affairs and Environment would have said that it needed all the $50,000 for the balance of the financial year on an urgent and unforeseen basis when, in fact, it needed only $15,000 on that basis. The other $35,000 could have come through the Appropriation Bills. I shall not speculate on the Department's motives, but I reiterate to the Department and the Committee that it is not good enough, in my opinion, in the opinion of this Committee and, I believe, in the opinion of the Senate for a department to take such a casual approach in its submissions to the Department of Finance on why it needs money from that source rather than waiting for the Appropriation Bills. I think this is a matter which bears some explanation. We have also said, as a committee, that we believe the Department of Finance should take greater care to ensure that in future similar requests meet the necessary criteria. The Department of Finance clearly, from its written evidence, is a little sore that it was not told that only $15,000 was needed urgently. It is possible that the Department of Finance, when it receives requests from other departments, could be a little more careful about the detail of how much is urgent and unforeseen. I indicate to departments which appear before hearings of Estimates committees on which I sit in the future, to the Department of Finance and witnesses from that Department that they ought to be prepared to answer in some detail questions on individual items in respect of the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

The second aspect in relation to operations of Estimates committees on which I think it is worth spending a couple of minutes is the quality of evidence received by committees. Estimates Committee B's report refers to examples of misleading or contradictory evidence which was presented to it during its hearings. A minute ago I gave one example of this which related to the Advance to the Minister for Finance and the Southern Cross Replica Museum where we got contradictory evidence from the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and the Department of Finance. Another example that the Committee encountered related to the subject of the observance of Australia Day. This involved evidence from the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and the Australian Broadcasting Commission under the appropriation for the Department of Communications. It was fortuitous that Estimates Committee B dealt with the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and the Department of Communications. If it had not happened that we subsequently had Australian Broadcasting Commission witnesses before us, we would have been in great difficulty following up in any meaningful way the evidence given to us by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. We were told by that Department that $36,000 was requested as part of the cost of staging an Australia Day concert. The Department's explanatory notes, that is, the printed notes that are supplied to the Committee to explain Budget Estimates and Supplementary Estimates, stated:
. . . initial advice from the ABC was that the Committee-That is, the Australia Day Committee-

would not be required to contribute to the cost of the concert and accordingly no provision was made in the 1980-81 estimate. However, following a close examination of the concert's costs the Committee was informed that some contribution would be required for the concert to proceed.

As noted in the report of the Estimates Committee, the Committee members were confused by the evidence presented on this matter. Witnesses from the Department of Home Affairs and Environment endorsed the statement that the ABC would not require funds to support the concert. When we questioned them they were uncertain, however, why this situation had changed and, further, were unable to say how the money was spent. The money appears in the estimates, but witnesses were unable to tell us how the money was spent.

The purpose of Estimates committees is to find out details on this sort of expenditure. As I have indicated we raised the matter again during the consideration, of the Additional Estimates for the ABC under the estimates for the Department of Communications. Witnesses from the ABC contradicted the explanations given by witnesses from the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. The Home Affairs evidence appears on pages 109 and 110 of the Senate Estimate Committee Hansard for Monday, 27 April 1981, and the ABC evidence appears on page 128. In particular, the Committee was told that the ABC had never undertaken to meet the costs of the concert. The ABC's evidence was subsequently supported in further information received by the Committee, after it had finished its hearings, from the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and the ABC.

I am saying as simply as I can in a big hurry that we were given in written form in the explanatory notes an explanation for an item but the explanation was just not true. When details of the item were sought at the Committee hearing witnesses were unable to tell us what the details of the item were. When further information was sought from another department the original evidence was flatly contradicted.

I raise the question of where this leaves an Estimates Committee which is acting on behalf of the Senate. If Committee members cannot take at face value the words written in the explanatory notes, if they cannot believe what they are told by witnesses, they really do wonder what is the attitude of the departments, the witnesses or whoever to Estimates committees. I suspect what happens on occasions is that witnesses do not know the answer. They might know part of the answer but instead of saying 'I do not know, I will find out' they make up an answer around what little they may or may not know. It has certainly been my observation in the chair and just as a member of Estimates committees. All of us are aware of the different quality of evidence that we receive from different departments. When I was on the committee which dealt with the estimates for the Department of Foreign Affairs it was a pleasure to go through the estimates because invariably whatever questions were asked there was an expert present who could give a prompt answer. If anyone wanted to follow up the information given in the answer then and there he could. If there was not someone present who could give the information-and this was fairly rare in the whole range of the evidence that that Department covered-the witnesses would say: 'We do not know. We will find out'. They did not mess around with making up half an answer.

I would like to make a plea to witnesses who come before Estimates committees. We would rather them say 'I do not know' than pretend to know for a little while and waste the time of committees and make its members very short tempered indeed when they discover that they are not being given evidence of the quality that they should be given. Further, I suggest to Ministers that they look at the standard, the highly varying standard, of witnesses who come before Estimates committees. I have mentioned the Department of Foreign Affairs. It is interesting to look through the rankings of witnesses who appear from that Department. They are all fairly senior people who are in a position to know and who can give a precise answer. It rarely happens that committees talk to senior officers who do not know or who, if they do not know, will try to pretend that they do. I make a plea to Ministers, who have an undoubted influence, to determine just which of their officers will appear before Estimates committees and to ensure that the witnesses are high level officers for the sake of the operation of Estimates committees, not only for the quality of the evidence but also for the quality of temper of us all by the time we have finished.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to apply a litmus test to the remarks of Senator Martin about prompt responses to questions asked by Estimates committees. I direct my remarks to the Department of Communications. As the honourable senator will be aware, I was only a visiting senator to Estimates Committee B. I happen to be a member of Estimates Committee D. The information I am seeking relates to an area which may be straddling the functions of the Department of Communications and the Department of the Capital Territory. I refer to the Black Mountain tower. There is a prologue to my questions. Way back in 1972 I, and a Queensland colleague of mine, Senator Keeffe, foreshadowed the stupidity of foisting a glorified restaurant on to a project designed to improve communications. We said it would not work. The evidence I subsequently got in reply to questions upon notice revealed that there is a rather high-powered army of private security people guarding the tower. We favoured the improvement of communications for the people of the Australian Capital Territory but we did not feel that the Government should disturb the surrounding parkland with massive excavations to construct a restaurant that is a virtual white elephant.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a mystery to me why I have not been able to get figures about the tower. I do not know whether this comes within the responsibility of the Department of Communications, or the Department of the Capital Territory. In the spirit of what Senator Martin has said in respect of the seeking of information, I want a breakup of the rental per year for the Black Mountain restaurant. I want that balanced against the cost of the army of private security people who, because the public have access to the Black Mountain tower, have to protect the communications operations. I have never argued about the need for security, but I can see that the Government is in a bind.

Senator Keeffe and I brought down a minority report in 1972 which said that there was no need for the restaurant and it would not be a financial success. I am not one of those people who have an obsession with balancing the budget, as this Government has, but I have been unable to get information as to the rental that is received for the Black Mountain restaurant. I want that figure balanced against how much the Government pays the contractors whether it is the Metropolitan Security Services or other organisations which play at being toy policemen. I think it is a simple request. I repeat that the decision to have a restaurant was wrong. I am very curious to know how much we are subsidising this restaurant because of a wrong decision. I am getting well above party politics in this matter because the decision was made by the Public Works Committee, which is representative of all major parties. I repeat that Senator Keeffe and I have been proved completely right. I would like to get a complete breakup on how long the restaurant has been going, what its actual takings have been and the rent it pays and balance that information against the cost for the MSS operatives that guard the tower. If the restaurant did not exist there would be no need for the massive number of MSS operatives that are being used.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response solely to the point made by Senator Mulvihill and perhaps in light of Senator Kathy Martin's comments a few minutes ago, I point out that the request for detailed information is something which I will have to take on notice. I will seek that information for the honourable senator and let him have it as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night Senator Walsh asked questions relating to the activities of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. He did so in the context that some unfortunate circumstances prevented him being present during the full committee deliberations. He therefore had some questions and I undertook to try to provide answers for him today when consideration of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) was resumed. He asked: Who authorises travel for the chairman, members and staff of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal? What is paid in respect of that travel? He also asked whether the Auditor-General is investigating any matters concerning travel and subsistence for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: The officers have gone to some lengths to try to provide some information. I am able to advise the honourable senator as follows: Travel within Australia for the chairman and members of the Tribunal is arranged by the secretary of the Tribunal as is necessary for the chairman and members to attend hearings or otherwise conduct official business. In these instances fares are paid by the Tribunal and the chairman and members receive a daily rate of travelling allowance to cover accommodation and subsistence. This is at a rate prescribed by the Remuneration Tribunal, and currently stands at $72 for the chairman and $61 for the members for each overnight stay. Travel within Australia by staff of the Tribunal is authorised by the chairman or the secretary to the Tribunal as appropriate. Fares are paid, together with a daily rate of allowance, to cover accommodation and subsistence in accordance with the rates--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that for outside Australia?

—Within Australia. The rates are prescribed from time to time by the Public Service Board and are applicable to staff employed under the Public Service Act. In respect of overseas travel proposals by the chairman or members of the Tribunal are subject to approval by the Prime Minister. Overseas travel by the secretary or staff of the Tribunal is subject to approval by the Overseas Visits Committee within the quota arrangements of that Committee. Fares and travelling allowances for overseas visits are paid in accordance with procedures established for all overseas visits by Commonwealth officers. The accounts of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal are subject to examination by the Auditor-General. I am informed that the Auditor-General has just completed an examination of the accounts of the Tribunal. The Tribunal has advised that it is not aware of any further investigations being sought by officers of the Auditor-General's office. Those are the answers which we promised to get for Senator Walsh.

SPEECH.PARA: I must now respond partly to some of the matters that Senator Martin has raised. For some period I was the Minister at the Committee hearing while some of the examination was going on. I suppose that someone must appear as a friend of the officers. They cannot come into the Senate and speak for themselves. In fact some pretty harsh things have been said about them in the last few minutes by the honourable senator in relation to some of the evidence given and some of the discrepancies which emerge between different answers. I should like to make quite clear and to put on the record that I hope that no one is suggesting that the officers who attended that Committee's hearings and those of other committees were not attempting to assist the Senate and the Parliament in every way possible to get information. I assert that as a fact. We had 28 senior officers from the Department of Home Affairs and Environment who were trying to do their best. I must say that appearing before a Senate Estimates committee is a strange experience, especially for the first couple of times. It is an environment with which honourable senators are familiar and with which officers generally are not. There is a genuine desire to assist, but the fact is that they are not senators; they are not subject to the hurly-burly of debate in this chamber. I sit on many Estimates committees. When there is a breakdown of communications such as occurred in this case it is not a bad idea to look at both sides of the communication process and not just at one. Honourable senators often can contribute to the way in which answers are given by the precision of the questions and also by a general attitude, whether it is an attitude of co-operation--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are reading us a lecture, are you, Senator?

—No. I am just responding on behalf of some officers who have been pretty roundly criticised. I will not suggest that there was no material requiring criticism, but some of the criticism was directed towards the officers themselves. If there is an aggressive line of questioning, sometimes it is not easy for them to cope with it. I am suggesting that if officers are attacked in a fairly aggressive way it often makes it more difficult for them to do their jobs properly. I reject any suggestion that there was any deliberate attempt to distort the evidence or to distort what the Committee received. I imagine that the honourable senator would agree with me. There was no such deliberate intention. We would like to get that on the record. Having said that, the honourable senator has raised a number of matters which require some answer because they are matters which quite properly have concerned her.
—And the Committee.

—They have concerned her and the Committee. I sat as Minister on several committees. Different committees operate in different ways. The first point which was raised by the honourable senator was the point relating to financial assistance towards the exhibition tour of the United States of America by the speedboat Spirit of Australia. The honourable senator had some concerns in relation to payments made to Mr Warby. The report of the Committee expresses concern that this financial assistance had not been properly accounted for in terms of the agreement with Mr Warby, and, in particular, that the final part payments were made without an evaluation of the original part payment of $100,000. I think that states the Committee's concern. The explanatory notes did not deal with this aspect.

SPEECH.PARA: At the Committee hearing the departmental witnesses indicated that all the funds had been provided in pursuance of a government decision. That is to say, if there was a reason it was done, it was not as a result of a decision of officers; it was a government decision. The Committee was told that it would be provided with the available details of expenditure. In written replies to questions the Department went on to indicate that the final payment of $43,000 was made to Mr Warby on 11 February on the instructions of the then Minister that steps should be taken to obtain the funds. The matter was dealt with urgently because Mr Warby was leaving for overseas. In its reply, the Department of Finance stated that it had approved this final payment in response to the approval given by the then Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, and the Department of Finance decided it was not required by the Audit Act or Finance Regulations or by the terms of the original agreement of the Minister for Finance to withhold part payment until evidence was available of proper expenditure of the earlier part payment.

I am saying to the honourable senator that there may well be matters requiring criticism, but the officers of the Department at all times acted under ministerial instructions. The Department of Finance acted within its regulations, and it may well be that what the honourable senator seeks is perhaps a variation on the procedures which apply. What was carried out was within the procedures. The Department of Home Affairs and Environment acted on ministerial instructions, and the Department of Finance processed those instructions in accordance with the relevant provisions. The Department, of course, will ask Mr Warby to account for the expenditure of the total amount. All action was taken by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment in response to a ministerial direction and with the agreement and the authority of the Department of Finance.

I think the honourable senator then referred to the Southern Cross Replica Museum Trust. She noted that of an advance of $50,000 which had been sought and obtained from the Advance to the Minister for Finance only $15,000 was required immediately. I think that states the honourable senator's concern. There may have been some misunderstanding. My understanding from the Department was that the total $50,000 was required before the Appropriation Bills could be passed. That is the understanding I had been given by the officers. The sum of $15,000 was required immediately and the whole $50,000 was required before the Appropriation Bills could be passed. In those circumstances the written reply given by the Department of Finance is consistent with this. The Department of Finance states that it was not told that only $15,000 of the grant was required immediately. I put it to the honourable senator that the problem facing the Department of Home Affairs and Environment was that it required the $50,000-to the best of its assessment, and I believe it turned out to be the fact-before the Appropriation Bills went through. On that basis it sought some money from the advance. It is quite clear that there was some misunderstanding on the part of the witness from the Department, and perhaps even on the part of some committee members, of the distinction between the money being required immediately and the money being required urgently. The Department considers that the money was required urgently in that it was required before the Appropriation Bills were passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sum of $15,000 was required urgently.

—The honourable senator is right; $15,000 was required urgently and immediately and the remaining $35,000 was required urgently but not immediately, but still before the Appropriation Bills were passed. I submit that it may well be a matter of misunderstanding. The fact is that there was need for the whole $50,000 in advance of the passage of the Appropriation Bills. I hope that that will be of some assistance to the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The next matter raised by Senator Martin to which some response should be made concerns item 14 of subdivision 3 of division 330, the observance of Australia Day. On page 14 of Committee B's report it is stated that the Committee was confused by the evidence presented on this matter; that the Department's evidence was contradicted by the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Senator Martin, in tabling the Committee's report said:
It appears that the Australian Broadcasting Commission officer was telling the truth.

The explanatory notes presented by the Department state on page 19 that the cost to the Australia Day Committee of staging the Australia Day live concert was $36,000 although initial advice from the ABC had been that no contribution would be required; that accordingly no provision was made in the original 1980-81 estimates. At the hearing the departmental witness stated that the Committee was not aware before December 1980 that the ABC would require any funds from it. In its written replies, the Department explained that the need for additional funds had arisen from a shortfall in sponsorship.

The apparent contradiction clearly arose because the departmental notes and witness were not sufficiently precise. Here I acknowledge the point made by the honourable senator. This was completely unintentional and I bring to the chamber on behalf of the Department apologies for that unintentional inadequacy in the notes. It was thought initially that the cost of the concert would be met through sponsorship which was to be organised by the Committee, and that no contribution from the Committee's appropriation would be required. This did not prove to be the case. Of course there was clearly a certain degree of verbal confusion but no intention to mislead. The officers of the Department had no intention other than to assist and help the Estimates Committee. I believe that those are the only matters that have been raised by the honourable senator--

TALK.START.PARA: —So far.
—Yes. If necessary, I may come back to other matters later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to return to the subject of the estimates of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. Committee members will recall that I engaged upon a fairly strong campaign for the provision of better field games facilities in Canberra, particularly in relation to the training facilities for our discus and shot put representatives, Gael Mulhall and Beverley Francis. In that regard I received finally an assurance from the Department of the Capital Territory that adequate facilities for field games exponents would be made available in Canberra. I am happy about that.

SPEECH.PARA: However, since the sittings of the Estimates committees we have heard further rumblings about the administration of the Australian Institute of Sport. On a number of occasions prominent athletes attending it have expressed dissatisfaction with it and have returned to their home States. I received a response to a question about the personnel of the management committee of the Institute. Perhaps I could now be given an indication as to whether there have been any worth while discussions between the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Ian Wilson, and Mr Don Talbot for the purpose of clarifying matters. Is the ship, so to speak, on a rather rough course and perhaps being steered towards a reef? Perhaps the Minister can indicate when the high-powered management committee of the Institute, which is studded with sporting luminaries, is to meet, particularly at this time of apparent crisis. In other words, I would like to know the state of play in regard to the administration of the Australian Institute of Sport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of comments on the remarks a few moments ago of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). When I spoke a short time ago I was referring to items encompassed by Appropriation Bill (No. 3), which I understand the Committee is now considering. The report of Estimates Committee B contains a recommendation relating to the items to which I was referring. I have not yet directed my comments to that recommendation because one other item in the report is also germaine to the quality of evidence and to that recommendation. I refer to item 15 of division 868-Other Services, which is dealt with in Appropriation Bill (No. 4). I seek leave to make comments on that line item because they would also be germaine to other items in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) referred to in the report of Estimates Committee B.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. First I would like to make one or two comments in relation to the Minister's statements on the quality of evidence and the mental disposition of witnesses when they come before Senate Estimates committees. I appreciate the Minister's soothing bedside manner and accept the purpose of his comments. I am sure, conversely, they were not aimed at any particular members of Estimates Committee B. We appreciate that witnesses do attempt to assist members of this chamber in every way possible. What I was trying to say was that they would assist us even more if they would not attempt to give answers when they do not really know the answers. It would be of greater assistance if more often they would simply say'; 'I do not know; I shall get that evidence for you'. Frequently failure to do that leads to the problem that I have mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that briefing sessions are held for witnesses who are to appear before Estimates committees. I do not know whether it would be applicable to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment, the Department of Communications or the Department of Education-I know that it applies to some other departments-but I suggest that the suggestion of our Committee might be included in those briefing sessions, which are directed to informing witnesses on how they should handle appearing before Estimates committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will be done.

—I thank the Minister. I understand that the briefing arrangements are informal in nature. I also ask the Minister to consider the possibility that one of the reasons senators become very aggressive, and indeed positively hostile, is that they become irritated about the quality of the evidence that sometimes is presented to them. A little better understanding of that point might make Estimates committees function more smoothly. I would not suggest for a moment that when a committee comes upon an item in respect of which it believes that something has not been conducted as it should be, it should take that out on a witness. Nevertheless, the committee will direct its questions to such witnesses.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not suggest, as the Minister conceded I did not, that there had been a deliberate attempt to distort. However, the final item that I wish to mention-that in Appropriation Bill (No. 4)-requires special attention. Although it was not perhaps the subject of a deliberate attempt to distort, we saw displayed a rather cavalier approach on the part of a witness to the giving of evidence before an Estimates committee. I would like briefly to point out to the Senate and to the Minister an aspect of the debate on the Southern Cross Replica Museum Trust in respect of which it was indicated that some confusion existed. The Minister said that the money was required urgently, that it was not unforeseen, rather that the fact that it was to be required urgently was unforeseen. That was accepted by the Committee. Nevertheless, I should like to refer to one or two matters that were raised in evidence. I refer to page 119 of the Hansard report of the proceedings of Estimates Committee B, at which this exchange is recorded:
Chairman:
So you knew in June last year that costs were going up. You knew that it was likely that it would be necessary to ask the Government for an additional grant?
Witness:
No, we were still very hopeful that we could raise the balance of that money from private enterprise.
Chairman:
When did you know you would not?
Witness:
Only about January or so of this year.
Chairman:
So in February you asked for $50,000?
Witness:
That is right.
Chairman:
Has the money been expended?
Witness:
Chairman:
Yes.
Witness:
Some of it, certainly.
Chairman:
How much?
Witness:
It would have to be a guess. I would think somewhere about $20,000.
As it transpired it was about $15,000. A little later, the following was said:
Chairman:
So in March you said that you would need $50,000. By what date?
Witness:
At that stage we were asking for money that was urgently needed for use within about a fortnight.

The $50,000 was needed, and it was needed over a period, but only $15,000 was needed urgently. I accept that perhaps the Department did not know that it would spend only $15,000 out of the $50,000 by the time the Appropriation Bills came forward. However, it should have been a little more definite, and the Department of Finance should have been a little clearer, that there was a case for $50,000 before the Appropriation Bills. Some written evidence on this issue from the Department of Finance states:

The former Minister for Home Affairs and Environment wrote to the Minister for Finance on 24 February 1981 seeking a further and final emergency grant of $50,000 to the project. The Minister's letter included an indication that half of the $100,000 total funds needed to complete the project was required immediately to permit construction to continue and to give the Trust time to raise the balance from other sources.
Further on it was stated:
Information was requested at officer level from the Department--
That is, the Department of Home Affairs and Environment-
inter alia on the urgency of payment and why it had not been foreseen earlier. The explanations of the Department were provided to the Minister for Finance.

There was need for the Government to indicate immediately that it would give the $50,000. There was not need for the Government to give the $50,000 immediately. That is the point being made. We would just like to see a little more care on that point. I accept that it was not known precisely how much would be needed before the Appropriation Bills, but I put it to honourable senators that the evidence suggests that it could not have been claimed that all the $50,000 was needed urgently.

I point out to honourable senators that Estimates Committee B has asked that the consideration of certain evidence be given to a committee. We considered this very carefully. There is no institutional way in which the Senate-except in debate, which is not very quickly-can come quickly to grips with the issue of the quality of evidence given to Estimates committees and how we might give some guidance to departments on what we expect in terms of quality of evidence. Accordingly, Estimates Committee B has recommended that a meeting of Estimates committee chairmen be convened to consider the apparently misleading and contradictory evidence presented to the Committee and that Estimates committee chairmen report to the Senate on their findings. The committee of Estimates committee chairmen would be an informal committee, but I think it important that a group of people who have a very clear and firm interest and motivation in that subject undertake to go into these matters in some further detail instead of our canvassing them for hours in this chamber.

There is a precedent for this. At one stage some years ago there was some concern about the Advance to the Minister for Finance. Estimates committee chairmen at the time met informally and agreed, not just as a committee but after consultation with other honourable senators who had an interest in the subject, on advice that might be given to departments, to Ministers and to the Department of Finance about information that could be given to us with the explanatory notes and in relation to the Advance to the Minister for Finance. That was the only way we as a committee could see how we could somehow move quickly to come to grips with this issue.

Nevertheless, I want to make a couple of points on this final item. The Minister made some comments about intent, good will and so on. The evidence we received on this final item does not help at all. It may be a once in a lifetime or once only occurrence, but I would not like to think this is in any way the standard we could apply to evidence or information given to us in explanatory notes. We were told in the explanatory notes that an amount of $1m was being requested for this item. The explanatory notes stated:
An amount of $1m will be required in 1980-81 for the following projects;
The notes went on to list five individual projects for which the money would be allocated. The following was revealed in evidence from a witness, as reported in the Estimates committee Hansard:
It may be that the $1m goes to two or three of those facilities in the first instance and not to all of them.
I will quote from the Hansard to show how this came up. The question was:
Does that mean that it is unlikely that those two facilities will incur the expenditure allotted?
The witness said:
No, it is more than likely that a priority may be rated as a higher priority by the State when more investigation is undertaken in that sense.
My question was:
For 30 June?
We were being asked to vote $1m to be spent before 30 June and at that stage it was still not clear what the expenditure program was. Of course, we were seeking details of that. The witness said:
Yes, but that $1m may not be spent on all of those projects, given that some of the projects are in a much more advanced state than others.
He gave some examples. He said:

It may be that the $1m goes to two or three of those facilities in the first instance and not to all of them. Given that the $1m is part of a total $25m appropriation, the position will level itself out.
Question:
So the statement that: 'An amount of $1m will be required in 1980-81 for the following projects;' is not correct?
Witness:
It says 'for the following projects'. It does not say for all of the following projects.
Question:
One would assume that that is what that statement meant. Is that true?
Witness:
Yes, that is true.

One would assume, when reading in notes the statement 'An amount of $1m will be required in 1980-81 for the following projects', with the projects then listed, that the money was going to be spent on those projects, not on some assortment of them. Do we have to examine all the prepositions that appear in explanatory notes to be sure that the information we are being given is accurate? I say that not in a nasty sense, but I think it should be noted-it was certainly discussed by the Committee-that that evidence was given without a blush, a wink or a hint of hesitation. If the witness was feeling some nervousness about appearing in front of aggressive senators, he certainly was not showing it. That sort of evidence certainly makes senators more aggressive. I hope that that was a once only occurrence. It would be very disturbing to think officers, in preparing explanatory notes, believe such a statement can go in when they must be fully aware of the potential of such a statement to mislead any one who was prepared to take those notes at face value and not to seek further details. That is the reason we suggest that this matter be looked at by an informal committee-I am not moving that a committee be set up-comprised of chairmen of Estimates committees. Such a committee could look at this detail, at the quality of the evidence we receive and at what Estimates committees can do when they receive contradictory evidence. I remind honourable senators that it was fortuitous, when our Committee got the contradictory evidence, that the other department involved was present. When the other department was not present, an officer from the Department of Finance was there and we could ask for an undertaking that information be given. That was fortuitous. I think it is something on which we need further information. I think there should be some report and recommendation to the Senate on the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -I wanted to speak before 6 o'clock because I have three or four questions following on from the questions I asked last night. I do not expect Senator Peter Baume to answer them off the top of his head, but he may be able to obtain an answer after dinner. He stated that the travelling and overnight allowances applicable to members of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, including the Chairman, when travelling within Australia are set out by the Remuneration Tribunal and that when they travel overseas Public Service conditions apply. Are the Public Service conditions in question published? If so, where?

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly-I think I referred to this last night-do employees of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, including the Chairman, use credit cards overseas? If so, what are the conditions authorising the use of such credit cards? If personal credit cards are used by the employees concerned, what are the conditions applying to reimbursement by the Tribunal for the original out-of-pocket expenditure by the employees? Senator Baume has stated that the Auditor-General was examining or investigating-I am not sure what term was used-some of the expenditures by the Tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I said that he had just completed the examination and that we were not aware of any special problems. I think that was the answer.

—I was not sure whether Senator Baume said that. I will still ask my question. Was expenditure incurred by the Chairman the subject of that examination and was the Auditor-General satisfied that no irregularities had occurred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will try to get the answers to Senator Walsh's questions. I think we could probably have them by 8 o'clock. I think it is proper to respond to the two matters raised by Senator Martin. The first relates to the international standard sports facilities. I can understand the difficulties everyone got into. The problem is that a three-year program was being got under way and the projects listed were part of that program. At page 131 and onward in the further explanatory notes given to Estimates CommitteeB, the status of each of those projects is set out in detail.
—That was subsequent information.

—That is correct. The information that emerges is that the exact moment at which funds can actually be put into one of the projects depends on a whole range of factors, including factors which are in the hands of the States.
—There is no quarrel about that.

—There is no quarrel about that. I was present when this discussion took place. The explanatory notes were deficient to the extent that they did not make clear what emerged in the evidence. That was a deficiency. It was unintentional. There was no attempt to mislead or otherwise misdirect the Committee. Really there could be no purpose in doing so. The projects are the same projects. It is a question of whether we are funding two, three, four or five of them.
—Naturally you would agree that it could have been more precise.

—Senator Martin says that it could have been more precise. Instead of referring to the program in general terms only the explanatory notes should have stated explicitly that the funds required in 1980-81 were part of a three-year program and that that three-year program involved those projects which were listed. I think that probably would have got over the difficulty.

SPEECH.PARA: I return for one moment to the $50,000 for the Southern Cross Replica Museum Trust. The Department of Finance advises me that of the amount of $50,000, $15,000 was required to meet that week's payroll and other necessary expenditure-literally that week. The Trust is not permitted by law to go into overdraft. It is not permitted by law to enter into commitments unless the funds are actually held by the Trust in a bank account. It could undertake no further activity unless it had money on hand. Guarantees that funds will be forthcoming are not acceptable.

The situation was that the balance of $35,000 was required to enable commitments to be entered into for major items such as engines and timber for the wings. Provision also had to be made to cover wages in advance because of the nature of retrenchment requirements. The total of $50,000 was required well in advance of the passing of Appropriation Bill (No. 3), which of course we are still working on now. It has all been used. I really think that again it is a matter that fits in with the general exchange that has taken place in the Senate in which a genuine attempt has been made and, I think, more information has emerged as we have investigated it.

Finally, I say to Senator Mulvihill that the Government is committed to the long term development of the Australian Institute of Sport and to the development of the capacities of our elite athletes. Funds have been provided in this financial year to permit the recruitment of world class coaches and to assist our athletes to continue their training and education in Canberra. It has always been intended that the Institute's development would be staged-not one-off, but staged. Funds will be provided next year to develop the facilities further and to permit a small increase in the number of young people who can attend the Institute. I am aware that there have been some problems with competing demands for the use of facilities, and the honourable senator and I have discussed them.

TALK.START.PARA: —A probable clash of personalities and things like that.

—I am sure that will happen in the development of the new Institute. I hope that we can all ask for good will in an attempt to try to see these things worked out. There is a genuine concern that the Institute should develop along the lines which I know the honourable senator would endorse as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to refer to the Department of Communications. I direct a question concerning the Australian Broadcasting Commission in Darwin. I drew attention recently to the fact that the Darwin ABC had been given State status. In other words, it had been given a certain amount of autonomy. I put a question forward in this place-it was not during the hearings of Estimates Committee B-concerning the funds available in two areas: Firstly, I referred to the establishment of the State status of the ABC and, secondly, to the ongoing funds needed to keep the ABC operating. As yet I have had no reply, so I raise the matter again. Without dwelling too much on this matter-I have already given this information to the Australian Broadcasting Commission Committee of Review, commonly known as the Dix Committee-I make the point that infrastructure is needed for small organisations in the same way as it is needed for large organisations. The cost per capita in a place like Darwin for the ABC, education and other services must be higher than in the States. I must say, of course, that there was general agreement when I put forward this thesis to the Dix Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The establishment of an organisation like the ABC in the Northern Territory obviously must be cheaper when some facilities already are available. The ABC was operating as a small part of the South Australian organisation. Some funds are still needed. Can the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) indicate approximately how much more money is needed to establish the ABC in the Northern Territory under its own system as distinct from being part of a State system? Where are these funds provided in the Additional Estimates? They must be contained in the Additional Estimates, of course, because the State status was given only about two weeks ago. I make the point also that ongoing costs must be high because once again the per capita cost must be higher in an organisation which has to provide a rural commentator, an outside broadcast unit, a sports commentator and so on. Can the Minister indicate what is the differential? I imagine that this amount also has been included in the Additional Estimates. Can the Minister direct me to where I will find that figure?

We are very conscious in the Northern Territory, of course, of the fact that we do not want simply a repeater station for southern programs. We want to see our own programs developed. I am rather mindful of the comments that my colleague Senator Townley made the other day in relation to Tasmania. His comments were reinforced by those of my colleague Senator Wheeldon who talked about the Western Australian situation. We want to see individual programs developed in the Northern Territory. I put these questions to the Minister: How much extra money will be needed? Where will it be found?

TALK.START.PARA: —The matters that Senator Robertson has raised can be responded to only by the Australian Broadcasting Commission directly. I do not have that advice at the moment. I will undertake to get it for the honourable senator as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the hearings of Estimates Committee B I directed a question to Australia Post about the Surface Air Lifted mail scheme. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) and the officers present will be aware that I questioned whether there was any discrimination against Yugoslavia compared with Greece, Spain and other countries which benefited under this system. I pay tribute to the officers. I received an in-depth reply about the method of consultation with various overseas postal services and I understand, the Yugoslav Government. In the meantime I publicised the response I received from the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) via the Committee largely through Novo Doba, the leading Yugoslav newspaper in Australia, a host of clubs and with my colleagues from Western Australia and Queensland and particularly the Atherton Tableland. There appeared to be a considerable amount of interest among people of Yugoslav origin as to when finality in this matter would be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the fact that the response indicated that consultation was taking place with the Yugoslav postal authorities and a broad overall assessment was being made, can the Minister tell me when the officers expect their survey to be completed? What would be the odds on people of Yugoslav origin benefitting under the Surface Air Lifted mail scheme?

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I think this question relates to an area of a specific statutory authority. I will need to obtain information for Senator Mulvihill.
— I put a few questions before the suspension of the sitting which have not yet been answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I overlooked the matter; I apologise to Senator Walsh. I believe the questions he asked related to the travelling allowance, official credit cards and other matters connected with the Chairman and members of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Is that correct?
—Yes.

—The following answer has been provided by the officers: The travelling allowances overseas are paid in accordance with the schedule determined by the Public Service Board for permanent heads. The Remuneration Tribunal has determined that holders of particular public offices will be entitled to the same rates and allowances as permanent heads. The Chairman of the ABT is entitled to the cost of accommodation plus an allowance as set out in the schedule-I will provide a copy of that schedule to Senator Walsh-to cover meals and incidentals.

SPEECH.PARA: The usual practice is for an advance to be paid before departure and the officer must fully acquit that advance by production of receipts on return. Official credit cards are not used. However, officers sometimes adopt the practice of using their own credit cards as a useful means of accounting for expenses to acquit their advance on return. The Chairman's expenditure is covered by the accounts of the Tribunal and is subject to the Auditor-General's investigation. As I indicated earlier, the Tribunal is not aware of any queries made by the Auditor-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to indulge in carping criticism. I think the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) will accept my comments in the spirit in which they are given. We have seen a repetition of the practice of a full backup staff being present when the Estimates committees are meeting but when the Committee of the Whole is meeting there is limited backup staff. That has occurred tonight. This situation amazes me. Perhaps the best way I can illustrate my point is to draw an analogy with rugby. I do not know whether we play seven, 13 or 15 a side at the committee stage. I paid tribute to the advice I received from officers of Australia Post after Estimates Committee B met. I take it that senior officers are present and that their wisdom is on tap. How is it decided who will be here and who will not be here?

SPEECH.PARA: Let me use a rugby terminology to illustrate my point. How does the Minister decide whether he will have six or seven forwards and no backs or all backs and no forwards. How did he arrive at a decision tonight concerning the departmental representatives. The Minister must have known that questions like mine would have been asked. With respect to Australia Post, has the Minister put in his first or second team? Who decided which officers' services would be dispensed with? Senator Martin and, in the past, the eloquent Senator Rae, have raised the question of what is the perfect system. If the Committee of the Whole is meeting and senior officers of departments are present, why is it that the full team is not here? One can compare this situation to a car's transmission: If one interferes with it the car will not go. It amazes me that we have this facade. It is a facade because we do not have the full team from the first to the thirteenth player or the first to the fifteenth player. I suppose that if it were a soccer team the Minister would not win if he took out his half back line. That is what happened with the Australian team. After having made those sporting analogies, I think it is time we took stock of ourselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Mulvihill will appreciate that the purpose of the Estimates committees is indeed to extract information of the kind that he seeks from officers of a certain level. However, as he will recognise, the Committee of the Whole is addressing itself to the Additional Estimates which contain no appropriations for Australia Post, Telecom, the Australian Broadcasting Commission and so on. His questions are more of a general nature. Accordingly, the Government has not made provision for all officers to be present whereas they were available at the hearings of the Estimates committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) that once we open up certain estimates for that department we open up the whole of the estimates for the department. If a department seeks further moneys it has to face up to queries across the whole of the spectrum. I do not think it is reasonable to criticise Senator Mulvihill for seeking information about other sections of a department which may not be seeking further funds. If departments or Ministers do not wish that to happen they should not seek any further appropriation but should wait until the main Budget is presented. I think it is a little unfair for Senator Messner to try to wipe us off. It is perhaps fortunate that I have no questions to ask about this group of estimates. I might be prepared to contribute to the next group. In all seriousness, once a department's estimates are opened again, senators have a right to ask questions about the estimates for the whole department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise some matters relating to group C. First of all, I wish to correct the content of a question that I put to the officers of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in an Estimates committee hearing. I said to Senator Guilfoyle, who was the Minister appearing before the Committee, that I had had a question on notice for quite some time for which I was awaiting an answer. That question asked whether the previous Governor-General had been provided with a free telephone service in the United Kingdom. I had that question on notice for quite some time-I think ever since he left this country and went to the United Kingdom-and I became very frustrated with the answers that I was getting. They were very negative. I was not told whether or not the previous Governor-General had a free telephone. The answer that I kept getting back from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) was that the information was not available-or, if it was available, he would not give it to me. All the Government needed to say was yes or no. So I must take it that in fact the Government does provide the previous Governor-General with a free telephone service in the United Kingdom. Otherwise, it would quickly deny the suggestion. But I cannot find out how much it costs the taxpayers of this country to service that free telephone.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said in the Senate on quite a few occasions, it is my opinion that the book that the previous Governor-General wrote was dictated over the telephone to the proof readers in Melbourne. It must have been done at an enormous cost to the Australian taxpayers. I will not pursue that matter any further because immediately the Labor Party becomes the Government, which will happen at the next Federal election, I will be able to get that information. Then I will reveal to the public the double standards of this Government and how it pays people for services rendered. The services rendered were those performed on 11 November 1975 when Gough Whitlam was unceremoniously sacked.

I wish to correct the misconception of my question to Senator Guilfoyle. I said that I had had the question on notice for quite some time and that I had not received an answer. As I have said, I became so frustrated with the negative answers I was getting that I gave notice of a motion to the effect that the Senate expresses its grave concern that Senator McLaren could not be provided with an answer in the interests of the taxpayers of this country as to how their hard won earnings were being expended by this present Government. As I have said, I will have to pursue that matter much further. The other question that I have asked consistently in the Senate ever since the change of government in 1975 concerns how much it costs to run Kirribilli House and the Lodge. I am always told--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about what it costs to keep Kerr in booze?

—Of course, that is another matter. Perhaps Senator Walsh would like to raise it. I have already raised the question of what it costs to supply him with a free telephone service, and how he was able to write a book over the telephone at enormous profit to himself. I am concerned about the double standards of the Prime Minister. I have asked in the Senate on many occasions what it costs to maintain Kirribilli House and the Lodge. Every time that question is asked in this place and in the other place we receive the stock answer from the Prime Minister. He quotes the previous Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, saying that the four official establishments, including the Lodge, Kirribilli House and two other establishments, cannot be separated. But, as I have said in this place on many occasions, the Prime Minister very conveniently had at his fingertips on 24 March 1976 some information relating to the running of the Lodge in respect of the last six months of Gough Whitlam's occupancy in answer to a Dorothy Dix question from the honourable member for Barker in South Australia, Mr Porter. Mr Porter asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Can he inform the House of the cost last year of running the Lodge and Kirribilli House?
Mr Fraser, in his answer, said:

I do not have the figures for the whole of last year but I have them for the last part of the year for both places. In the last six months of last year the Lodge cost the Australian taxpayer $64,941, running at an annual rate of $129,882. Kirribilli House, where perhaps the then incumbent spent a somewhat greater part of his time, cost $75,379 for that same six months, running at an annual rate of significantly over $150,000.

The Prime Minister, in an effort to embarrass the previous Prime Minister, quite conveniently had those figures at his fingertips. Every time I have asked what it has cost to run the Lodge and Kirribilli House since he has been the occupant, he has reverted to precedent, saying that those costs cannot be divulged. I asked this question again in the Estimates Committee hearing and I received no answer. The most pertinent part of his answer was the statement that for the same six months the cost of Kirribilli House was running at an annual rate of over $150,000 and that the then incumbent spent a somewhat greater part of his time at Kirribilli House.

Where does the present incumbent of the Prime Ministership spend the greater part of his time? He spends it at Nareen. What does it cost the Australian taxpayer to ferry the Prime Minister back to Nareen every weekend? What are the costs of the VIP aircraft and all the facilities that have been installed at Nareen? I shall ask further questions before we conclude consideration of the estimates for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I am not satisfied with some of the answers that have been supplied to questions asked in the Estimates Committee hearings. What does it cost the Australian taxpayer to keep the Prime Minister installed at Nareen? It would cost much more than it cost for Gough Whitlam to reside at Kirribilli House. The previous incumbent of the Prime Ministership, Gough Whitlam, did not have to have all the security facilities, including an airstrip and all the facsimile equipment, installed at Kirribilli House. It was all there.

The present Prime Minister, the head of this Government, puts the taxpayers of this country to enormous expense. Yet he had the hide in answer to a Dorothy Dix question, off the top of his head, to come up with what it cost to run Kirribilli House and the Lodge while Gough Whitlam was the occupant. There again is evidence of the double standards of the Prime Minister. I could use much stronger words. You could not stop me from using them, Mr Temporary Chairman, because, as I said in the Senate the other day, I have a whole sheaf of extracts from the Hansard record for the period of over three years in which the Labor Party was in government, showing what we were accused of. I am quite prepared to use them. As I said to Senator Chaney a couple of weeks ago, I will put them all together at the appropriate time and make a speech about them just to prove to the electors the type of government this country has at present and the double standards under which it operates.

Tonight I again ask the officers who are sitting behind Senator Messner for a breakdown of the costs of running the Lodge and Kirribilli House for the last 12 months. I wish to know also how long the present Prime Minister has occupied Kirribilli House in the last 12 months. He is on record as saying that he was not going to use Kirribilli House as a place of residence during his term of office, that it would be used and occupied only by very important persons visiting this country. He may not be in residence at Kirribilli House at any particular time, but surely we can be told what it costs to run the Lodge. I also ask-I am sure that I will not be told-what it costs the Australian taxpayers to have Mr Fraser flying backwards and forwards from Nareen. Only last week I saw an article in the Press which stated that Mr Fraser flew by VIP aircraft to a place in New South Wales to buy a bull. That was at taxpayer's expense.

I assure people who are listening to this broadcast tonight that at no time ever did Gough Whitlam use a VIP aircraft to fly anywhere in this country to buy a bull. Nor did he ever use a VIP aircraft to see a son working as a jackaroo on a cattle station. That is on the record. I expect that the VIP manifest will be tabled, if the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) runs true to form, before we get up. But it will only go back to 31 December last year so I will probably have to wait until the end of this year before I can debate the matter I mentioned. However, I will pursue the matter, as honourable senators know, with great vigour. I served as a senator in the three years of the Whitlam Government. Since the unceremonious dismissal of that Government by the previous Governor-General in 1975, I have had to sit on this side of the chamber and listen to the diatribes by honourable senators opposite about the honesty and open government that they engage in when, in fact, the reverse is the case. All of those things are on the record. No public money was misused by a Labor government. The money that we used was for the benefit of every Australian citizen, particularly those people in need. Yet day after day we find enormous amounts of money being expended by this Prime Minister to satisfy his luxurious needs, such as going to buy a bull.

I refer to another matter-I do not think it was mentioned in the Appropriation Bills or explanatory notes with which we are now dealing-which relates to people whom he is sending overseas as couriers with personal invitations to attend the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. I asked Senator Guilfoyle many questions as to the cost of the CHOGM conference. Part of the answer was that out of the expected expenditure of $12m, $6m would be expended on security measures in Victoria. The money would have to be paid to the Victoria Police. Expenditure of that kind was not undertaken by the Whitlam Government. We saw fit to expend the taxpayers' money in this country to look after people in need. This Government that we have now says: 'To hell with the people in need. We will feather the nests of our great financial friends'. We now see the chickens coming home to roost.

If honourable senators look at the front page of today's Australian they will see that every Liberal government in this country today is in disarray. In Western Australia a member of the State Parliament has resigned because the Liberal Premier forced a gerrymander. We see problems in Victoria where Mr Hamer is under attack by a Mr Smith, the previous Minister for Agriculture. In New South Wales we saw Mr Mason under threat of dismissal because of disunity in his party. We see the present Prime Minister under threat of dismissal. No Government senator attended the dining room until 1.50. The party meeting went on until 1.50. There were great ructions there. Not one of the rebels on the other side was in the Senate during Question Time. I could name all the honourable senators who were not here. There were many vacant seats. They had a swarm outside. The country is in disarray but at the same time we have a Prime Minister who could not care less about expenditure of taxpayers' money. These are the questions that have to be asked and answered.

Before I go any further I want to see whether the Minister can obtain from the officers who sit beside him the expenditure of taxpayers' money on running the Lodge for the last 12 months. I have asked that question for God knows how many years in this place-at least five. I also want to know: Does the Prime Minister occupy Kirribilli House? If so, what was the period of his occupancy in the last 12 months? I will leave it at that. My quarter of an hour is nearly up. Of course the night is long and I am prepared to stay here until breakfast time, until I get the answers. I have done this on previous occasions. I will not say any more until I find out whether I can get answers to the questions I raised, not only on the Estimates committees this year but also on Estimates committees of years gone by and in this chamber in the Committee of the Whole. At this stage I will cease speaking to see whether I can be provided with those answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLaren well knows that successive governments, including that of Mr Whitlam, followed the precedent that information concerning individual breakdowns of expenditure on the various official residences was not provided. Rather, the whole sum appropriated is given and consequently that is available for discussion. With regard to the point that Senator McLaren raised on the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting which is coming up in October, I have some information for him. Additional CHOGM expenditure requirements this financial year have been identified as planning for the meeting has progressed. Commonwealth heads of government meetings are held every two years. Since 1971 the venues for the meetings have been Singapore, Ottawa, Kingston, London and Lusaka. This year the meeting will be held in Australia. This will be the first full meeting to be held in the Pacific area. Up to 45 heads of government from Commonwealth countries, accompanied by Ministers and officials, are expected to attend. This will be the largest meeting of Commonwealth Heads of Government ever in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The current estimate for the total appropriations of CHOGM is $12m. Australia must be prepared to bear this cost when countries such as Jamaica and Zambia have been prepared to bear similar costs in the past. Of the estimated appropriations of $12m, $6m is related to security requirements. Senator McLaren acknowledged that. A substantial portion of this $6m will comprise the transfer of funds from the Commonwealth to the State of Victoria to offset increased operating costs of the Victorian police force for the provision of the required security. Also included in the $6m for security is expenditure on security communications equipment such as portable radio transceivers and television surveillance equipment. The majority of equipment will be available for Commonwealth use after the meeting. The other major items of expenditure cover residential accommodation, transport, fitting out of the meeting venue, furniture and operating costs of the task force which has been established to handle the arrangements for the meeting. Of course this is one of the great significant meetings of the world, having so many Commonwealth heads of government present in one place. In fact such a meeting has not occurred in this nation since Federation and indeed it represents a milestone in the development of the Australian Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ask a question to make sure that I heard correctly. Was the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) saying that his officers have advised him that the figures that Senator McLaren wanted, namely, the breakup of how much it costs to run the Lodge and Kirribilli House, are available and in the hands of his officers, but that it is a Government decision not to present them to Senator McLaren? Or is it that the officers cannot provide the breakdown or will not provide the breakdown? Will the Minister make clear whether it is a Government decision not to provide Senator McLaren and honourable senators with the breakdown or whether the figures are not available?
—In order to clarify the matter for Senator Chipp I will quote from an answer which Mr Whitlam gave on this matter which--

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I ask you to protect the rights of senators, which is your duty. I have just asked the Minister in charge of the House a question couched in extraordinarily simple English. I am not the faintest bit interested in what Mr Whitlam said or what Mr Whitlam intended; I simply want to know, are the figures about which Senator McLaren asked available? If so, will the Government provide them? If not, why not? That needs no reference to Mr Whitlam. I ask you, sir, to keep the Minister in order.
—The Minister will answer the question in his own way.
—Consistently governments have refused to give that information.
—Except for this Government, except for this Prime Minister. He set a precedent.
—That is not true, as you know, Senator Walsh. Other governments have refused to supply that information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pursue this matter because when the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) rose to answer my question his first words were that a precedent had been created that the figures were not divulged. I did not read all the answer given by Mr Fraser to Mr Porter, but I think for the record I have to do so, and that is going to be very embarrassing to Senator Messner, the Minister in charge of these estimates. It will also be very embarrassing when it is thrown back at the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I will give in full the answer which the Prime Minister gave to Mr Porter when he sought this information. I have cited some of the figures about the amount of money. Mr Fraser said:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that both residences were being paid for by the taxpayer for the benefit of one particular person--
There was then an interjection by Mr Innes who said:
Tell us about Manila. Tell us about Singapore.

We all know about that. That is not a point to be debated here tonight. Every member of this Parliament knows about the episode there and how a member of Foreign Affairs fell foul of the Prime Minister, but I am not going to indulge in that tonight. I want to read out the answer given by Mr Fraser. He said:

Honourable gentlemen opposite do not like the facts of life about their Leader. That is why they keep on trying to hide them. But I think that a few people have a right to know and a few people have a right to be able to understand. Both places were costing the Australian taxpayer ($280,000 and, since I thought that this was much too great a subvention by the Australian taxpayer to house the Prime Minister of this country, it is one of the significant reasons that Kirribilli was returned to its proper purpose as a residence which can be used by distinguished overseas guests . . .

Now, Mr Minister, you have it in black and white. I have been quoting from the House of Representatives Hansard of 24 March 1976. That is where the precedent was created by this Prime Minister and that is why I have repeatedly asked for the last five years for the costs of running Kirribilli House and the Lodge for Mr Fraser. What does it cost taxpayers? He is on record as saying it is a cost to the taxpayers. The taxpayers and the members of Parliament have a right to know. I am asking you again, Senator Messner. Apparently your officers know. Of course they are under some restriction because we know what happens to public servants if they do not bow to the wishes of this Prime Minister; their jobs are under threat. I ask you, Mr Minister, to accept the responsibility of telling this Parliament tonight what it is costing Australian taxpayers to house this Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, at the Lodge. I am not sure whether he has ever slept at Kirribilli House. I have asked you that question. You did not answer it in your reply. I am waiting for that reply. Your officers must know. They are here as the representatives of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. They must know, otherwise what is the use of having appropriations put before this Parliament and the explanatory notes being made available if Ministers are going to come in here and hide the facts from the taxpayers, which Mr Fraser said you have no right to do? I have read out his words. You have no right to do it.
