I again say, if you are not prepared to answer it, this country is now being run by a Prime Minister, who has very expensive and luxurious tastes and who is afraid to divulge to the Australian taxpayers what it costs them to keep him in luxury not only at the Lodge but also to fly him to and fro by VIP whether it be to Hamilton then to Mount Gambier, then by commuter aircraft or by Commonwealth car from there to his residence at Nareen and what it costs to fly him at taxpayers' expense to outlandish cattle stations to purchase a bull. We want to know and that is the whole purpose of putting appropriations before the Parliament. I say to you, Mr Minister, again that we are entitled to an answer and I want it.

TALK.START.PARA: — Just in case the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) decides not to speak, which would bring the matter to an end, I will speak. He is learning fast. The simple question I want to ask him is this: Is the information available? Senator Chipp asked it in equally simple language, but the Minister just passed over the question. Is the information available, and is he holding back that information? The Minister is nodding his head. I take it he is not prepared to answer.
—The Minister will answer when he gets the call.
—You have no guarantee of that.
—You have not got the call. Senator Georges has the call.

—I have some other questions to ask on these estimates, but in order that we get this matter cleared up now I would suggest that the Minister should answer whether he has the information. If he has not got the information then of course he should seek it. If he has it and he is refusing to divulge that information to the Committee then it is a very serious matter indeed.

—It is quite obvious that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) is not going to give us the information so I can only take it from the Minister's silence that he is either afraid of the reaction that he will get from his leader if he divulges the information or else he is under threat from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) not to divulge the cost. I think it puts at very grave risk the whole government when a Minister is prepared to protect his leader in respect of the squandering of taxpayers' money and not to divulge the costs. If he had nothing to be afraid of, nothing to hide, he would be quite prepared to divulge the information to the Parliament. We have not got the numbers in this place. We may have the numbers in this place when we are considering the Budget Estimates later this year. It might be a different story then. We might get back to what it was like in 1975. This Government might find the Budget held up until such time as it is prepared to give representatives of the taxpayers of this country their rights. This Government should not forget that every member of this place has a responsibility to the taxpayers of Australia. We are their servants. We are elected by them and we should endeavour to act in their best interests. I have had many requests from taxpayers in the State in which I live, in view of the answer Mr Fraser gave to Mr Porter, who also is a South Australian representative, back in 1976. As I said, he was able to give an answer off the top of his head. Of course the question was a Dorothy Dixer. He had it all there. As I have said before on many occasions, the answer was purely an attempt to belittle the previous incumbent of the office. I could go on to quote many other things that were said, but I will not do so tonight. I will do so at the proper time when we may be able to force this Government to divulge to the community at large what it costs to house this Prime Minister, that is, if he is the Prime Minister of course when the Budget is debated in this chamber. There is some doubt about that. All my queries might be chopped off.
—It could be the member for Kooyong who has taken over.

—It is quite possible it could be the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). I do not think the honourable member for Kooyong, if he becomes Prime Minister of this country, would hide behind the statement that a precedent was laid down by Mr Whitlam when that precedent was broken by Mr Fraser. It is the last precedent, in my view, that is the precedent one always has to take cognisance of in this Parliament; not the early ones but the last decision that was given, and that precedent was broken by Mr Fraser. It is of no use my pursuing the matter as I have done before in this place hour after hour. I say to Senator Messner that you have done the community and the State of South Australia which you represent a great disservice by refusing to say tonight to the Committee that you are under instruction not to divulge information or that it is not available. If we knew it was not available then we have other avenues to pursue it. We can only get the answer that it is not available or you refuse to reveal it. However, we on this side have long memories and I am particularly one who has a very long memory. I know of the suffering I have gone through in the last five years. I know of the suffering that we went through when we were in government and the then Opposition members, who now sit opposite, were refusing to allow the will of the people to apply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter concerning the conduct of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner). I have been a member of parliament for 21 years. Without overdramatising the situation, I say that tonight the Minister has treated me and the Parliament with a contempt, the like of which I have not seen in 21 years. I will give the Minister one more chance to be civil and to answer the question that Senator Georges and I asked; otherwise I will move that we report progress, and we will divide on it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not terribly interested in the answer to Senator McLaren's question. I do not think that it is the most important question that I want answers to, but that is not the point. The point is that he is a senator elected by the people and has asked for a breakdown of the figures for what it costs to keep the Lodge and Kirribilli House. I asked: Is that information available? Do the officers have it? If the officers have it I want the Minister to say that the officers have it but that for policy reasons the Government will not disclose it. I would not like that answer because it goes against the spirit of freedom of information, but at least it would be an answer. At least the Minister would not be treating the Committee with contempt. Senator McLaren has asked for information. He has not been given an answer. I have asked the same question, and so has Senator Georges. The Government might wonder why senators on this side of the chamber, and indeed on the other side of the chamber, are pressing for a proper Freedom of Information Bill. If we continue to have a Minister such as Senator Messner treating this place with such utter contempt as he has tonight, either wilfully or unconsciously, this will increase the demands for a Freedom of Information Bill.

I will move that we report progress unless the Minister indicates he will answer the question. The whole procedure is a farce. For the benefit of those people who are listening to this broadcast, I point out that there are 25 to 30 highly paid-although underpaid, no doubt-civil servants present in the gallery who will be here all night. God knows how many others are waiting out in the corridor to come into the gallery once consideration of this group of estimates has been concluded. The civil servants are present to advise the Minister on matters which senators such as Senator McLaren are raising from time to time. Judging by the progress we are making we will be here until 11 o'clock tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Later.
—Midnight?
—Later.

—I thank the Deputy Government Whip. We will be here until one o'clock tomorrow morning on these estimates and going through this farce. I am sure that will gladden the hearts of the members of the civil service who are present. We will go through this exercise until one o'clock in the morning. Senators are asking for information and receiving contemptuous answers from the Minister. I think it is a farce. It is one of the great jokes of all time. Talk about costs! The costs of this exercise would be almost immeasurable. But the important thing is what it is doing to the institution of parliament. It is making it look farcical.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the Minister and, with your indulgence, Mr Temporary Chairman, I ask him to give me an indication as to whether he will answer the question. He has a quizzical look on his face, which indicates that he does not understand what the question is. Let me repeat it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't understand the answer.
—There has been no answer.
—Suppose you sit down and we can get on with it.

—Senator Walters will get on with it, all right. She will get on with it by voting on a motion that we report progress. The smugness of that smile on her face will no longer be there after 30 June. We can give her a guarantee on that. At that time she will not be able to gag senators and treat this place with contempt as is happening tonight. Is the Minister prepared to answer two simple questions? Are the figures that Senator McLaren asked for available? Namely, is there a breakdown of the cost of running Kirribilli House and the Lodge? If they are available, will he present them to the Committee tonight? If not, why not?

—Firstly, I deal with Senator Chipp's remarks in connection with Senator McLaren seeking information on the Lodge and Kirribilli House. He would know from his short period in this place that these are questions which have consistently been asked and which have consistently been replied to in the form in which I replied to Senator McLaren's questions and his own on an earlier occasion. Consequently, I have no more to say on the matter except to acknowledge that it is a matter of the Government's policy in this area and-
—What is?
—As to the provision of information about individual residences.
—Why?
—That is the consistent answer which, of course, has been traditionally acknowledged. Consequently, I suggest that we ought to get on with the business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: -The information we seek is merely the cost of running the Lodge and Kirribilli House.
—No, whether the information is available. That is the first question. Is it available?

—The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) has indicated that the information is available and refuses to give it. That is what I infer from his remarks. He has the information but is refusing to reveal it. He would not want to be before the Joint Committee of Public Accounts because it would take a very serious view of his attitude to withholding information. It does not concern security in any way. It is not a matter of the security of the nation. The policy of governments has been not to answer questions about the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation or other security agencies. We have argued about that, but we generally accept that it has some validity. But there should be no hesitation to give the costs of running Kirribilli House and the Lodge. They are residences which are supported by the taxpayer. There is no personal involvement by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) or anyone else. It is the taxpayers' money. I think the Minister admitted that. It seems to me to be quite extraordinary that the figures should be withheld unless the costs which have been incurred are such as to invite a considerable reaction from the community.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer to the other matters within this group of estimates but I will not until the Minister gives a far better answer than that which he has given. I think that what Senator Chipp has indicated-that we should move to report progress-is the sensible course in the circumstances. I think the Committee will have to thrash this matter out. A Minister is refusing to give information concerning public expenditure. It is as neat as that. He is refusing to give the figures for the running of Kirribilli House and the Lodge. The Minister may argue that he does not want to give a breakdown, but at least he can give us the total cost of running those two places. Is he not prepared to do that?

TALK.START.PARA: —We have got the total.

—I am told that we have the total, but the senators behind me have sought a breakdown. My argument is still valid. The breakdown should be available. I consider that reporting progress is a serious matter. It is even more serious in that this is possibly the second or third time that we have reported progress against the same Minister. Honourable senators may recall that on previous occasions he has not been able to give us the information that we required. I ask the Minister to reconsider and give the information that we seek. Surely there is nothing to hide-or is there? Is the Minister saying that there is something to hide? Is he afraid to give the figures? If he is not afraid to give the figures, the answer is simple. His advisers have the figures. Give them to the Senate.

—Two questions arise. The first is: Is the information on the cost of maintaining official establishments available? The second is: What are those costs? I leave aside for the moment the second question and note that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) has refused, albeit passively, to answer the first question about whether the information is available. Given that fact, if Senator Chipp cares to move that progress be reported until such time as at least the first question has been answered the Opposition will support his motion.
—I have no information on the matter.
—Could I ask whether the Minister is saying that neither he nor the officers present have information available on the cost of maintaining official establishments?
—If Senator Walsh is referring to the total amount, as he knows, that is available.
—I am referring to an individual breakdown of precisely the kind that the Prime Minister himself gave in 1976, and asking whether that information is available.
—No.

—I refer to item 03 of subdivision 2 of division 505 relating to telephone services. Senator McLaren asked what type of equipment had been installed for the sum of $35,000 referred to in the Estimates. The reply given was that it was primarily for rental charges for existing telephones at the four official establishments. It has been reported recently in the Press that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is building a holiday home in Peterborough, Victoria. Can the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) indicate whether any of that sum which has been set aside has been used to provide equipment in that area?
—I am advised that there has been no expenditure of that kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In common with Senator Walsh, I regard this as involving an important matter of principle. I repeat that the Australian Democrats-I am sure that Senator McLaren would agree-do not regard the breakdown of expenditure between Kirribilli House and the Lodge as the most important question before the Senate; rather we are looking at the principle that we are here tonight examining government expenditure. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) has stated-I believe that I now understand him correctly for the first time-that he has been informed by the civil servant who is sitting next to him that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet does not have in its possession a breakdown between the expenditure on Kirribilli House and that on the Lodge. With your indulgence, Mr Temporary Chairman, I pause for an interjection from any of my colleague Senators if that is not what every Senator understands.
—That is so.
—I thank my colleagues. An extraordinarily serious breach of principle has occurred by the Minister's treatment of the Senate during the consideration of an Appropriation Bill. Therefore, I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Chairman report that the Committee has made progress and seeks leave to sit again.

I do so in order that the Minister may confer with the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) with a view to his instructing his Department to divulge those figures to the Minister, or to the Minister who may happen to be at the table, so that the chamber may be informed of the breakdown.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator McLaren

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have reached in this place the ridiculous situation of honourable senators on this side seeking information similar to that which was made available in 1976 by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in answer to a question from Mr Porter in another place. The Prime Minister, in making that information available, gave details of the running costs of Kirribilli House and the Lodge and said that he was doing that because the public should know. He accused the Opposition at that time-it was the Government just prior to that time-of trying to hide the facts from the people. The simple fact is that this is public expenditure; it is expenditure by the second citizen of this country-if we consider the Governor-General to be the first citizen-of taxpayers' money. It is information which has previously been made available by the Prime Minister of the moment. It is information which he made available because he felt the public should know. Yet we now have the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) claiming in this place that the public and, in particular, the Senate have no right to know.

SPEECH.PARA: I am amazed that those opposite, who frequently proclaim in this place-they did so particularly between 1972 and 1975-about the public's right to know, now blindly sit here and say that we have no right to know what the Prime Minister is doing with the taxpayers' money in this country. One must then ask: What has the Prime Minister, through his junior Minister in this place, got to hide? We have a right to know just what is going on and we have a right to the information. At least we should get an explanation as to why the Minister at the table cannot tell us what is going on and why he has been instructed not to tell us what is going on. He may stonewall all he likes on this problem. He can refuse us reasons and information and we will persist in asking for that information. We have not only not been given the information; we have also not been given one reason why that information should not be made available. When we were in similar situations on other occasions in this place we heard long and agonising speeches from those of the then Opposition about the right to know. We demand the right to know and we persist in seeking this information.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the appropriations of 1974?

—As Senator McAuliffe said, the debate on the appropriations in 1974 and 1975 went on and on with the seeking of all sorts of extraneous information and with vexatious questions. They went on night after night and day after day. Yet Senator Messner, in his new and illustrious position as a Minister, merely sits there and stonewalls and says: 'You should not know'. That is completely opposed to the democratic principles that everyone in this place has previously espoused. I urge the Minister to reconsider his situation. I urge him not just to take blindly the advice of the gentlemen sitting on his left but to give us the information we seek.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) going to maintain his silence? Is it going to be necessary for us to wait until the Estimates come before the Estimates committees again so that we can ask the members of the Public Service directly how they feel about having information available which they are not prepared to give to the Parliament? Surely the Minister is going to act a little more favourably than he has. We will be accused later of holding up the proceedings of the Senate, but surely that criticism must fall very much on the Minister's shoulders. After all, when we started to debate the Estimates this evening we made considerable progress. It was only when the Minister now before us took his place and refused so arrogantly to give information that progress slowed down.

SPEECH.PARA: I merely now wish to ask another question. I just wonder whether I am going to get the information. There is a certain increase in expenditure-some information has been given about it-for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, supposedly to be held in Melbourne. It is extraordinary. I am directing a request to the Minister and the Minister is engaged in conversation with the Government Whip. I take it that the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting will still be held in Melbourne. Is it intended to shift that meeting from Melbourne to Canberra? If it is to be moved from Melbourne to Canberra, what will be the cost of that exercise and how can it be justified?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) is turning this place into a bigger farce than he normally makes it. Questions have been asked about matters of public expenditure which are the concern of everyone in this place and everyone outside this place. Questions have been asked about the costs of running the prime ministerial establishments and questions now have been asked about the costs of running the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, yet the Minister sits there mute and not only will not answer questions but also will not give reasons for not answering questions. The few honourable senators who sit behind him-the four of them-with the exception of Senator Walters, who gives inane interjections and makes no contribution to this debate, are spending their time answering their correspondence.

SPEECH.PARA: Why, Mr Chairman, can we not get answers to these questions-questions which were so important to members of the then Opposition when we were in government and questions which, in 1976 were considered sufficiently important to be answered by the Prime Minister in reply to a Dorothy Dix question in another place? Why should honourable senators in this place and the taxpayers of this country not know what is going on? What has the Government to hide? What has the money been spent on that the Minister will not tell honourable senators about in this place? By how much has the expenditure increased that the Government will not tell honourable senators in this place? What has been going on at Kirribilli House and the Lodge? We ask first of all for answers and, secondly, for reasons for non-answers.

The public servants who sit beside the Minister remain mute and the Minister, in his junior position in this place, is unable to answer and remains mute. He is a disgrace to the Ministry. I implore him to consider this chamber and to consider the processes of democracy in this place and to answer. If the Minister will not answer, I believe that there are sufficient honourable senators in this chamber to persist in asking the questions until the Minister either has to answer or has to shut down this place. If he does that, he is a disgrace to the Government he represents.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really think that this farce has gone on long enough. I did expect, when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Senator Grimes, rose to his feet to speak, that there would be some attempt to bring some decorum into this place. The people listening to this debate on the radio tonight must think that the way in which the Opposition is carrying on is absolutely absurd. We all know what is going on here and what the Opposition is attempting to do. But it is not going to succeed. The fact is that the Opposition has had answers to the questions which have been put by Senator McLaren and, in particular, by Senator Chipp. The questions put by Senator Georges were of the most inane kind and were not worthy of any kind of answer. In that regard, I did not expect that that kind of comment would come from a person of such quality as Senator Grimes.
—You are losing your cool.

—I have not lost my cool; not at all. We will deal with the Opposition. The point that needs to be acknowledged here is that the matters which have been raised tonight by Senator McLaren have been raised consistently by him over the years inside and outside Estimates committees on various occasions. Apparently Senator Chipp does not have the experience to understand that. These matters have been consistently answered by Ministers--
—I have been here for only 25 years.

—With respect, not in this place. The situation now is, of course, that tonight Senator McLaren has asked a number of questions which he has asked over a long period. He is seeking answers to those questions and he knows that he will not get specific answers to them. I will answer one point which Senator Chipp raised and which I regard as important. He did not give me the opportunity to answer before he moved that progress be reported. He misrepresented me by saying that I said that individual figures were not available from the Government. He should know that that is not what I meant. I said that I did not have that information available.
—Why?

—Apparently Senator Chipp will not accept this either. I am sorry that I am unable to satisfy him. I now undertake to repeat the answer to Senator McLaren's earlier questions. He knows full well what the answer is. It is that the information regarding the individual residences which are owned by the Government and used as official residences is not available.
—It is.

—It is not available in my hands and I am unable to give the honourable senator any information. The second point referred to by Senator Chipp was whether such information involved a question of Government policy and to that question, the answer is yes. That has been clearly said by me since this farce started. It is honourable senators on the opposite side of the chamber who are creating the farce that the people of Australia are forced to listen to tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have been maligned by the good Minister, perhaps I can explain to the people to whom the Minister was calling in such longing tones that the situation is that in 1976 the Prime Minister of this country, Mr Malcolm Fraser, was perfectly willing to give to the House of Representatives the information which we are now seeking. He gave that information in response to a question-allegedly without notice-from one of his own back benchers. We are now told by the Minister that the Senate, in 1981, cannot have that information because it is Government policy not to give that information. Why is it that in 1981 the situation is that the Government has decided that it is policy not to give that information when in 1976 it was perfectly willing to give that information for its own political purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: We wish to know what has happened to the taxpayers' money in this area. It is a simple question. In the Budget context, I believe it is not a lot of money. It ill becomes the Minister, who has not been a member of this place for as long as he seems to think he has been, to suggest that in asking what has happened to the taxpayers' money we are holding up the Committee and that we are asking vexatious questions. We are asking questions which can be answered simply. If they cannot be answered simply there is no one keeping accounts in the residences we are talking about. If that information was available in 1976-without notice-in the House of Representatives, it should be available in debate on the Appropriation Bills in this chamber in 1981, with plenty of notice.

Why should we not ask for it and why should the Minister, with all his seniority and all his experience in this place, cast aspersions on people in this place who seek that information? Why should his colleague, who is sitting behind him, sit and sneer when she so often cries for information in this place? Why should we not have the information? Not only are we not given the information, but the only reason we are given for not getting it is that it is Government policy not to give such information. Why is it Government policy? Why is the Government, which claims that it is open to the people, which claimed it was going to open up politics in this country, not willing to give this simple information? We ask that question. We have repeatedly asked it. The Minister has either not replied or has stonewalled and cast aspersions on people on this side of the chamber. It is not satisfactory and, as I said before, it ill becomes a Minister of the Government to behave in such a way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a very sad night for the chamber when a Minister obviously has information and is withholding it from this Parliament. I can recall the days before the establishment of Estimates committees when we met as a Committee of the Whole. I can recall one evening in this chamber when I asked the responsible Minister a question. He was a responsible Minister-not irresponsible like the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner). A sum of $10 had been spent. The Minister agreed-and the amount was in the Department of Air estimates-that it was a question he could not answer. He deferred consideration of that section of the Estimates until the information had been obtained. The sum involved was $10. Afterwards it was found that this sum had been spent near a Royal Australian Air Force depot in the Middle East to buy a push-bike for a local civilian. It was a legitimate expense. He was an honest Minister who decided that he would hold up consideration of the Estimates rather than be in a situation in which he would refuse to answer a question.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight the odour is brushing off on the Ministers' advisers. The Minister is sitting there like a dummy letting them cop the consequences. They are the people who should be able to advise him at this point in the debate. We saw Senator Kilgariff run out and bring in another junior Minister, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume, to sit beside and advise the Minister, who cannot cope with this question. Then, of course, the Government brought in the Deputy Whip. The rest of that side of the chamber, except for Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen, is absolutely empty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not quite.

—I am sorry, I have an apology to make. I apologise to Senator Gordon Davidson who, in fact, should be the Minister sitting where this imitation of a Minister is sitting. One of two senior people from South Australia-Senator Jessop and Senator Davidson-should have been appointed to this position instead of this Minister, who cannot cope with even a simple Estimates committee question. I will tell honourable senators why this Minister got the job. He is a yes man, a bootlicker and a Fraser supporter. That is why he got the job. In other words, one of the other senior South Australian senators should have got the job.

SPEECH.PARA: I will ask the Minister another question. Why did the Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, at very great expense to the taxpayers of this country, take out the beds in his VIP plane and put in more comfortable beds? He is the man who is preaching to this nation that we ought to be saving money. He is the man who is taking away the rights of pensioners to have at least a decent living, the man who is creating unemployment and the man who set up the razor gang. Yet he is the man who, when he travels on his great overseas trips, takes out less comfortable beds so that he may sleep in comfort while he flies the Pacific Ocean.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just longer beds.

—I did not mention Senator Walters as a possible Minister because I think she has a 20-year apprenticeship to serve. If she wants to interject she may do so, but I ask her to make intelligent interjections. I withdraw nothing that I have said about the Minister. He has had to handle the portfolio of veterans' affairs. I know he was in the Boer War, World War I, World War II, the Korean War and the Vietnam War, but he has served his Department with inexperience and inability to be able to cope even with that job. Why he was allowed to be the Minister in charge of the appropriations tonight is beyond my comprehension and beyond the comprehension of every taxpayer in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Expenses are mounting. The Prime Minister is the leader, closely followed by people such as the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch, in spending the taxpayers' money while the public of this country suffer. Our kids cannot get jobs. We are now taking away their education. When the report of the razor gang is discussed in this chamber there will be some horrible tales to tell. Nobody on this side will be frightened to tell those stories. Yet this Minister is now speechless, sitting there like a mummy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is because you are speaking.
—I do not think Senator Kilgariff is in a situation in which he can interject because he is the person who went to get Senator Baume because the Minister was in trouble.
—The duty Minister.

—Oh, come on Senator Kilgariff. Senator Kilgariff, as Government Whip, ought to have gone and got one of the senior Ministers who at least might have been able to tell untruths better than the junior Minister can tell them. I respectfully suggest that progress be reported and that we go on to the next item in the appropriations. I do so on behalf of the taxpayers of this country. Here is a man who cannot tell us where tens of thousands of dollars have gone. Mr Fraser is the biggest spender in this Parliament. The Minister cannot tell us where Mr Fraser has spent the money because he is covering up. He is fulfilling the same role as a man with a balaclava who robs a branch of the Commonwealth Bank, because he will not tell us where the money has gone. I respectfully suggest that progress be reported and we go on to the next item in the Estimates. I suggest that the Minister be charged with the responsibility of bringing back that information tomorrow before we go on with this debate. He could not answer a former member of his own party, Senator Chipp. The Minister tried to denigrate Senator Chipp as part of the overall plan, knowing that at midnight on 30 June he will become a nonentity in this chamber because he will no longer have the numbers. I suggest that that course be taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Western Australia) (9.26)-For the benefit of those radio listeners who may have just tuned in and for the benefit of those Government members whose concentration spans are very limited, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) has been asked the cost of maintaining the four official establishments on an individual basis. After a great deal of prevarication he said that he did not have that information on hand. He added that even if he did have the information on hand, he would not disclose it. That answer has come from the representative of a Prime Minister who, in 1976, not only provided that information but also was able to provide it ostensibly in reply to a question without notice.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me back to the question I asked before the division. If that information is not available, why is it not available? The inescapable conclusion is that it is not available because either the Minister does not want to get it or the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has told him that he is not allowed to get it. The Prime Minister was able to supply this information, ostensibly in response to a question without notice, in 1976 but refuses to supply the same information in 1981. That is the sort of background which, I suppose, one would expect from a Prime Minister who, three weeks after the recommendations of the razor gang were brought down, three weeks after an allegedly ruthless exercise in cutting superfluous government expenditure, took a VIP trip to Armidale-a VIP trip being a prime ministerial journey in a special Royal Australian Air Force aircraft-to buy a bull.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure of that?

—I am absolutely certain of that. It has been reported in the Northern Daily Leader and by the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Within three weeks after this phoney exercise in trimming superfluous government expenditure this self-indulgent Prime Minister took a trip to Armidale in a special VIP RAAF aircraft to buy a bull for his farm at Nareen. We will be asking later what the cost of that exercise in self-indulgence and double standards was. We might also ask whether the RAAF aircraft will have to be refitted to take the bull to Nareen.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government temporarily has the numbers in this place to push these Appropriation Bills through. I have no doubt it will use its numbers to do just that. I serve warning on this Government-I assume that the Australian Democrats will take the same view in September or October as they have taken tonight-that this question will arise again when this chamber is considering the appropriations pertaining to the 1981 Budget. On that occasion the Government will not have the numbers to pass the Appropriation Bills. Unless this information is supplied then, the Budget will be deferred. Senator Walters can be very smug tonight but she will not be so smug in September or October when the Budget appropriations are being considered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only just come into the chamber so I cannot be accused of conniving to get publicity or conniving for any other reason to embarrass a Minister. This should not be an emotional debate. I do not think there is any special desire to embarrass the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner). The important point is that we have responsibilities as elected politicians under the Westminster system. The Government alone is not responsible for expenditure. All parliamentarians are responsible for every cent of taxpayers' money spent. It is a responsibility that we have to honour and that we have to carry out. An appropriation may come before us which may or may not be justified.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case we are asked to allocate an extra $27,000 for official establishments. We find that nearly $1m was allocated for official establishments in the 1980-81 Budget as against a far lesser amount in the 1978-79 Budget. In the last Budget the expenditure for official establishments was increased tremendously. That may or may not have been justified. Obviously not enough money was appropriated. Another $27,000 is required. It may be justified. But whether we belong to the Australian Labor Party or the Liberal Party, surely we should not be prepared to spend taxpayers' money-we have a solemn obligation to protect taxpayers' money and to see that it is spent wisely-unless we know where the expenditure is going and for what reason it is being made. That is what honourable senators on this side of the chamber want to know. That is what all the questions have been about.

It is not good enough for a Minister to say that he does not know where money is going or that he will try to find out the necessary information. Honourable senators should know all this information before we vote to spend one penny. That is the whole question. If we do not do that we are dishonouring the oath of office that we took and we are dishonouring our obligations to the electors. If we approve an appropriation and do not know the reason for it then we will reach a stage when we will do away with democracy and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) will spend money where he wants to.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would suit him fine too.
—He cannot very well do it because the Constitution makes provision.
—But he has broken the Constitution every time he has looked at it.

—I have made an appeal to the Committee not to get too emotional about this matter. I do not think that what the honourable senator says is quite correct. The Constitution makes provision that all monies spent must be approved by Parliament. That throws the responsibility on every member of parliament to see that the taxpayers' money is spent wisely. That is provided for in the Constitution. The Prime Minister wants the Committee to approve an appropriation of $27,000 for official establishments.
—An extra $27,000.

—An extra $27,000. The Prime Minister does not want to ask how it will be spent. The Prime Minister could take that approach to the appropriations for the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Department of Social Security, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and so on. He could say that we should vote so much for a certain purpose. Are we carrying out our responsibilities if we vote for such an appropriation without knowing whether it is a justifiable expenditure?

SPEECH.PARA: When I first came into this Parliament in 1963 we had a big debate when only one appropriation Bill was presented to the Parliament. It included capital expenditure and expenditure for the ordinary annual services of the Government. A protest was made in this Parliament and a vote was taken on the question. It was found that the Parliament considered that it was not a proper presentation of official accounts because the Senate is limited in its inability to amend money Bills only if they are for the ordinary annual expenditure of the Commonwealth and not if the Commonwealth wants to make an expenditure for any other purpose. The then Treasurer, Mr Holt, gave an undertaking that in future two appropriation Bills would be introduced, one containing the ordinary annual expenditure and the other containing other expenditure.

I now question the extra expenditure sought for official establishments. If it is sought to cover an increase in the wages of employees at the official establishments it would be covered by ordinary annual expenditure. If it is sought to cover some alterations or enlargement of the establishments it should not be included in Appropriation Bill (No. 3). On one occasion an appropriation was sought to put in a new window at the Governor-General's house. We had no say in whether it was justified. I think the then Governor-General condemned the window because every time he looked out it he saw the tower on Black Mountain, which he could not stand.

We must not forget our responsibilities. This matter goes across party lines. Honourable senators opposite cannot tell me that members of the Liberal Party are immune from their responsibilities to their electors. They know they are not. I would like one honourable senator opposite to justify spending taxpayers' moneys for, which they are custodians, when they are not aware of what that money is to be expended on. That is the whole issue. I think the Minister is in an extremely difficult situation. I think he should report to his superiors. According to our oath of office it is essential that we insist this information be supplied. If the Minister is not permitted to supply it I think another Minister who will supply the information should be appointed to attend to these particular appropriations. The Minister says: 'I do not have the answer to the question but I will get it.' That is all right so long as we get the answer before we vote on the appropriation. We should not vote to appropriate money for any department on a Minister's assurance that he will supply certain information after we have voted on the appropriation.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) called me 'inane', to which I take strong objection. If the word 'inane' is to be used it should be directed at the Minister for his behaviour tonight. If he has any doubt about the meaning of the word he should look up a dictionary. Even the smallest dictionary would suitably describe his behaviour tonight under the heading 'inane'. I should like to refer again to the question that I asked. Since we have ceased to be inane and have become much more particular I want to refer the Committee to page 20 of a document entitled 'Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, Explanation of the Estimates 1980-81'. An appropriation is sought for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. The second last paragraph states-
—Did you say page 20?
—Yes, page 20.
—He has a voice. He breathes.
—Yes, he has a voice when he wants to. On that page it stated that the meeting will be held in Melbourne. I now ask: Is it the Government's intention--
—Where is it?
—Come now, it is not so difficult to find. I am referring to the explanatory notes of the estimates for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet for 1980-81.
—What is the page number?
—It is page 20. The proposed expenditure for that item is $385,000.
—It is all right. Apparently there are two different documents.
—Are there? Is the Minister trying to tell me that there are several documents?
—No, you have a separate page; that is all.
—Does the Minister know to which item I am referring?
—Yes.

—The estimated expenditure is $385,000. I ask: Is it the Government's intention to change the venue of that meeting from Melbourne to Canberra? Is it a fact that the Government has booked the Lakeside Hotel in anticipation of that event? Can the Minister tell me the estimated increase in expenditure under this item that will be needed to meet that change?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) is obviously not going to answer even Senator George's question. To follow up the earlier remarks of Senator Cavanagh, myself and others I make a plea to the Minister to reconsider his earlier answer in which he said that he would not give the Senate the reason for the increase in the costs of maintaining the government establishments of Kirribilli House, the Lodge, et cetera because it was not Government policy so to do. As Senator Cavanagh has pointed out, we are bound by our membership of this chamber and of this Parliament to ask for an accounting of all public expenditure.
—Every cent.

—Every single cent. In 1976 the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), who uses these establishments, was willing, in answer to a question, allegedly without notice, to give information about the running of those establishments to the House of Representatives. The information was freely available in 1976 and, in the words of the Prime Minister at that time, it was available because the public had a right to know. The members of the Committee are now asking for a breakdown of that expenditure. The only answer we can get from the Minister is that he will not give it to us because it is not Government policy to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: That answer should not be satisfactory to any senator on either side of this chamber, particularly in view of the fact that the Prime Minister, a few short years ago, was willing to give that information not only to this chamber but also to the other chamber and to the people of this country. Even though an amount of only $27,000 is sought, we should not be willing to pass this appropriation in the light of the Minister's answer. I am aware that the Minister is not answering on his own behalf. I am aware that he is being instructed by the Prime Minister, through the gentlemen who are advising him in this chamber tonight. But that is no excuse. We have asked the questions. Every member of the community can find out what every member of this chamber earns. The community knows what our salaries and allowances are. That information is publicised freely through the documents of this Parliament and the Press. There is no reason why every member of the community and every member of this Parliament should not know what it costs to run the Government establishments. To be told that the only reason we cannot know is that it is not Government policy to let us know is the absolute opposite of democracy. It is the absolute opposite of what this chamber and this Parliament are all about.

I join Senator Cavanagh, Senator Chipp, Senator Walsh and others who have spoken tonight in asking for simple answers to simple questions about amounts of money which are absolutely insignificant in the total context of the Budget of the Commonwealth of Australia but which, despite their minuteness, are absolutely essential in maintaining democracy and public accountability in this country and the rights of this Parliament and, through this Parliament, the rights of the taxpayers of this country, to know what is done with the taxpayers' money. I just ask the Minister and his ministerial colleague to think really about the answer that has been given. If we allow this sort of answer to go through, as Senator Cavanagh has said, we could get the same answer to questions in relation to all sorts of other appropriations. We could get the same answer in relation to the Department of Social Security, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Department of Primary Industry and all the other departments. The relevant Minister could say: 'It is not Government policy that you should know'.

It is not only the Opposition but also the Government that does not know these facts. I must point out that the only people on the Government side of this chamber at the moment are the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Government Whip. The rest of the Government senators will not sit there and put up with the embarrassment of what is happening in this chamber tonight. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs may be happy enough with this situation in which he finds himself. I certainly would not be, and I do not believe that anyone else in his situation should be happy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, according to the Minister's roster system, I was due to--
—Mr Chairman--

—I have the call. I have had to listen to Senator Keeffe. I was rostered on duty at 9 p.m. I have been enjoying the debate. At this stage I should like to answer a couple of questions that have been asked during my rostered time. There was a question about the 707 aircraft. I am not certain which honourable senator asked it; it might have been Senator Walsh. I was asked: Were certain changes made to the aircraft? I am advised that changes were made to make the beds collapsable and that this was done to provide more working space and not to improve or alter the accommodation facilities. I have been listening to the debate about the apportionment of costs for the official residences. It seems to me that certain facts are available. An enormous amount of information has been provided about the aggregate costs of the official residences. I do not think that anyone is in any way questioning the fact that the aggregate costs for the official residence are shown function by function. They are shown between pages 14 and 18 of the explanatory notes. More details are given in Appropriation Bill (No. 1), which shows the costs of all the different functions of the official residences. There has been no attempt not to reveal this information, and neither should there be.
—Come on. He told us he did not know.
—The Committee is in charge of its own affairs. I am just trying to put a point of view. We are following what I would call the Whitlam declaration on this matter. I will read it.
—No, you are not.
—You are following the Fraser double standards. That is what you are doing.

—Mr Chairman, it is interesting that honourable senators do not seem to want me to read the declaration. It states the position of governments for at least the last 20 years. Senator Don Chipp was a member of a government which followed the same practice. The Whitlam Government followed the same practice. The practice which we are following on this matter and which has been set out to the Senate is the practice which has been followed by numerous governments for a long time. I will read Mr Whitlam's statement on this matter. I will quote from page 2776 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 4 November 1975.
—That is not relevant.
—The honourable senator may say that it is not relevant but I am stating the reasoning which Mr Whitlam put forward, which is the reasoning that we are putting forward today unchanged. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: For many years, successive Governments have followed the principle that costs of the four official establishments-Government House, Admiralty House, Kirribillie House and the Prime Minister's Lodge-should be regarded as a total charge against the annual Budget appropriation. Each year the Budget papers show the total commitment for maintaining all four residences. Both estimated costs for the ensuing year and actual costs for the preceeding 12 months are given.

That is the principle which has been followed over many, many years by governments of which Senator Chipp was a member and of which honourable senators opposite were members. It was enunciated very clearly by Mr Whitlam and it is the practice which we are following tonight. I believe the people who have to live in these official residences-I am thinking particularly of the Governor-General and the residences he occupies-do not have an easy life; they do not have much privacy. I think there are good grounds for each of the governments which have taken this view doing so. Over a number of years governments of all political persuasions have taken this view. If there are particular expenditures about which senators want to know, if they put their questions to us-I cannot answer their questions at the present time and I am not even sure whether we can get the answers-we could see what information could be provided. But the practice which has been followed for many years by governments of all persuasions, by people from all the parties in the Parliament, seems to us to be an appropriate practice to continue to follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —If that had been said two hours ago we would have made progress. Thank you for that.

—I am trying to state calmly what the situation has been because I think it is an issue which the Senate has been over many times. As honourable senators say, the Senate is master of its own business. At the moment I am putting to it what I think is a reasonable view.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite amazed at Senator Baume's explanation, although it takes us at least part of the way along the road to what we are trying to find out. He must know that his Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) repudiated that agreement in 1976 when he decided to expose everything in an effort to denigrate the former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam. A few moments ago we had a visit from Senator Carrick, the senior minister in this chamber. He came into the chamber with a very disgusted look on his face because of the way in which his two junior Ministers are handling the business of this chamber, and he walked out again. Quite obviously he does not want anything to do with their embarrassment tonight in this chamber. It is beyond comprehension that, except for one backbencher, the Government benches are deserted. The Government Whip and two very junior Ministers are trying to hide the dishonest things that this Government is doing. The Government is dishonest.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister, whose estimates we are trying to debate, gave approval for two senior backbenchers, Mr Jull and Senator Collard, to accept private money to visit America in order to compile enough information to give a certain private consortium the benefit of their experience and knowledge that they gain. Undoubtedly, they would have persuaded the Government to make sure that that consortium was given certain commercial options to exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order.
—I ask Senator Baume not to get up and cry because if he is going to cry he can cry after the House rises tonight.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I am not trying to be disputatious but I think Senator Keeffe went a bit far in suggesting that if two members of the Parliament went away on a trip that was publicised this week, they would come back and try to use their information to ensure that certain people got certain contracts. I think that is making an imputation against members, and that is not proper.
—I did not interpret it that way, Senator. I call Senator Keeffe.

—I am prepared to withdraw that imputation but I will not withdraw the fact that this Government is corrupt. I have said that in this chamber before. It is a totally corrupt government and it is led by a Prime Minister who has either been led by the nose or is himself corrupt. Yet we have in the chamber junior Ministers who are hiding what is going on in the Department of the Prime Minister and the Cabinet. This involves taxpayers' money. The Government is not prepared to allow this matter to be exposed, because somewhere dishonesty is going on. The taxpayers of this country are facing another big problem, and that is the sending of six backbenchers and six Ministers, carrying little gold embossed invitations, to attend a conference to be held later this year at Captains Flat or Bungendore or somewhere else. As my colleague Senator Georges said, arrangements are being made so that the conference will not be held in Melbourne. The Minister who gave approval for the episode that I mentioned a while ago is getting out of this Parliament. Why is he getting out? Is it because there are so many things that have been lined up to compensate him for the loss of his funeral parlours? What of the consent that has been given to this illegal visit by two backbenchers who at least had the grace to withdraw from the trip to America?

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is so corrupt that it ought to resign. The Minister who has copped all the flak tonight has now gone away with his tail between his legs to hide and report. He ought to be dismissed from the Ministry. The Government sent in a second junior Minister who is almost as incapable. Look what he has done to Aboriginal affairs! He has sold out Aboriginals to the States. He knows that the only people who will suffer as a result of that action are the blacks of this country. He is a man who, at one time in his career in this Parliament, had very high ideals. Now he backs up a corrupt Prime Minister, a corrupt Government and he has sold out--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, if he stands up he will cry again. Let him stand up and cry.
—I raise a point of order. Senator Keeffe referred to a corrupt Prime Minister. I am sure that is not in accordance with Standing Orders.

—I wish to speak to the same point of order. In speaking to this point of order, I refer again to the many times that Government senators, when in Opposition, called the Whitlam Government corrupt. The honourable senator talks about a precedent being created tonight. It was Government senators when in opposition-I do not mean the honourable senator personally but his shadow Ministers-who set the stage for people to be called corrupt. The honourable senator has no right to object to any honourable senator on this side of the chamber calling his Prime Minister corrupt. I can quote page after page of Hansard which reveals that Senator Carrick, the present Leader of the Government, former Senator Webster, former Senator Greenwood, Senator Withers who is still a member of this chamber and Senator Cotton who now has a Government appointment in America put down substantive motions accusing the Whitlam Government of being corrupt and dishonest. It ill becomes the honourable senator to stand in this place tonight and object to honourable senators on this side of the House firing at him the words which he used continuously for three years but which he knew were not true; he could not prove they were true. Tonight we are proving it. The honourable senator should not stand in this place and drag a red herring across the trail.

—I wish to speak to the point of order. It is a point but I do not think what the Liberals did at the time of the Labor Government is justification for breaching the Standing Orders on this occasion. Mr Temporary Chairman, with all respect I ask you to consider very seriously whether there is a breach of Standing Orders and whether anything was said against the Prime Minister or anyone else which could be taken as being disrespectful. There comes a stage in the activities of an individual when he is not treated with kid gloves or presented with bouquets, when sometimes there is justification for saying things that would not normally be said. Senator Keeffe, I think, led with a series of illustrations, all pointing to the fact that there was corruption and he assessed that the leader of this corruption was the Prime Minister. He then expressed the statement 'led by your corrupt Prime Minister' but he had established the foundation leading up to that statement. Surely if one gets that far one must come to the conclusion that there is a corrupt Prime Minister. That is the only thing that--

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I take another point of order. Senator Cavanagh, in speaking to the point of order, is compounding and repeating the same breach of the Standing Orders. I ask you to uphold the Standing Orders.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Kilgariff

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I draw your attention to Standing Order 418 relating to offensive words used against either House or any member thereof. The Standing Order reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Senator shall use offensive words against either House of Parliament or any Member of such House, or of any House of a State Parliament--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am well aware of the Standing Orders. I ask Senator Keeffe to withdraw what was a direct accusation against a member of another House. 'A corrupt Prime Minister' were the words used. Senator Keeffe, I ask you to withdraw.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I am glad that I have not offended against the Parliament but I think I have made the point. We have had two junior Ministers--
—Senator Keeffe, I have asked you to withdraw your accusation against a member of another House. 'A corrupt Prime Minister' were the words you used.

—I said it in a collective sense. After all, he is the leader of this country or at least we expect him to be a leader of the country in his role as the Prime Minister. I do not want to be offensive about it at all. One can make accusations against a government being corrupt. If that part is offensive I will withdraw it insofar as it refers to a particular person. But if he is the leader of an organisation that is corrupt--
—That is what I am asking you to do, Senator Keeffe, to withdraw.
—I did.
—You have withdrawn?
—Yes. May I continue?
—You may continue your remarks but not in the same vein. I remind the Committee that we are discussing the votes under group C.

—I am ashamed of the behaviour of the Government in a consideration of this nature where we are examining the expenditure of millions of dollars. We have had in this chamber tonight two Ministers. One has gone away to lick his wounds and the other in the last 20 minutes has proved himself incapable of carrying on with the debate.
—Charade.

—Perhaps 'charade' is a better word. I think if one is handling the taxpayers' money one ought to be at least honest enough to say, if one does not know the answer: 'I will bring it in tomorrow'. If a Minister cannot cope with a particular section of the Estimates then for heaven's sake let us not consider that part; let us go on to the next section of the Estimates. There is nothing wrong with that. In the days of reasonably honest government it was done in this chamber, and I have seen it done in this chamber. When explanations could not be given, consideration of that section of the Estimates was postponed and when the information was obtained it was brought back into the chamber for consideration. That is at least an attempt at honesty. Why cannot it be done tonight? Why is this big cover-up going on? I appreciate what Senator Baume did when he read out the so-called Whitlam gospel. But the succeeding Prime Minister decided that that was no longer the gospel. In other words, he changed the church. That was several years ago. He has been the Prime Minister ever since and he and his Government are now covering up that information. Why?
—I raise a point of order. My understanding, Mr Temporary Chairman, is that you have asked the honourable senator to withdraw certain words.
—He did withdraw those words.
—I did not hear him say that. In fact, he appeared to be debating some other matter.
—I am sorry, Senator Kilgariff. There is no point of order. Senator Keeffe did withdraw the words.

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I suggest that Senator Kilgariff go to see the people who look after hearing aids as soon as possible. I made my attitude to this quite clear. One cannot get down on one's hand and knees and crawl across to Senator Kilgariff's benches and say 'Sorry, Bernie'. It is just not on. His action is a diversion to try to hold up our consideration of the Estimates. If the Minister in charge of the chamber at the moment were prepared to be an honest Government Minister, upstanding with some ideals left-he has lost a lot since he became a Minister-he would say: 'Fair enough, let us have another look at this; let us come back with the answers tomorrow'. The people on this side of the chamber are going to be accused of holding up the consideration. I again say that the Labor Party senators have not held up the consideration in this chamber at all. We came here for two weeks in February but the Government had no business for us to deal with. The Prime Minister was not prepared to allow his senators to go home. He was not prepared to allow people like Senator Withers to go out to organise themselves against him. So he kept them all here where he could keep an eye on them. In fact, for about only half of this session this chamber has done a worthwhile job. The other half of the time we have been held here could have been used in doing more profitable work for the people in our own areas for which we are responsible political representatives. Now we come to the crunch-the end of the session. I forecast that Prime Minister Fraser will keep us here till midnight on 30 June 1981 because he lives in fear of the Chippocrats. He lives in fear--
—Australian Democrats.

—I am sorry. It is a popular word and it is well known. He lives in fear of people such as Senator Withers. He is starting to live in fear of people such as Mr Sinclair. He definitely lives in fear of people such as Andrew Peacock. This sort of business, which should have been dealt with at least a week ago, is still being dealt with now and probably will still have to be dealt with next week because two incapable junior Ministers have been given a job with which they cannot cope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to get to the point of this matter. I wish to ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), who is the second Minister who has dealt with this subject tonight, just what is the answer that is being given to the Opposition. We have asked for the detailed breakdown of the costs of running these Prime Ministerial establishments. We were told by Senator Messner, the Minister who preceded this Minister, on roster I understand, that we could not have this information because it was not Government policy to give this information. We have been told, I believe, by the Minister in charge of the chamber at the moment, that we are not to be given this information because Mr Whitlam did not give this information in 1974. I make the point that Mr Fraser was perfectly happy to give this information in another House in 1976. If the Government persists in not giving us the information, will the Minister please tell us why? Is it because it is Government policy? In that case, it is completely unsatisfactory, I believe, to this chamber. Is it because the Government has now suddenly taken up the attitude that Mr Whitlam had, and with which we may not agree, in 1974? If that is so, why is the Government turning its back on the attitude of its own Prime Minister, whose establishments these are, in giving this information in 1976?

SPEECH.PARA: We have been given the run around here tonight. I believe it is a simple principle that this House deserves to be told what is happening with public money. It is not a very large amount of public money. I believe if we are not to be told-whether we accept that is up to this chamber, I believe-at least we ought to be given consistent reasons why we should not be told in this place. We certainly have not been given them tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe I owe Senator Georges an answer to a question. It has been difficult to get it to him. Senator Georges asked whether some part of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting would be held in Canberra. My advice is that the main conference will be held in Melbourne but that the retreat, the informal weekend on which Commonwealth leaders talk informally, will be held in Canberra. I think that is the answer to the honourable senator's question.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to Senator Grimes, I simply make the point that the Whitlam guideline which I read out in answer to that question put down on 4 November 1975 really stated the position which has been followed by successive governments for many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not by your Government.
—It has been followed by our Government.
—It has not.

—If the honourable senator would let me finish, there was an exceptional circumstance in 1976 when some information was made available. The fact is that, apart from that, the consistent pattern of response by this Government, by the Whitlam Government and by governments before that has been to follow the course of action set out in Mr Whitlam's parliamentary answer. It is that answer by Mr Whitlam which provides the model we are following in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put this matter into some order. I do not see the Whitlam guidelines as setting out a prohibition on the provision of information. I thought we could agree with the Whitlam guidelines as read out. As I understood the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) when he read them out, information will be supplied on the individual costs of the four establishments. That is what we are asking now. The response of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) was hopeless and he arrogantly told us that it was not government policy to give any answer. Therefore, I raise the question. We have a responsibility. We must have the answers before we can vote taxpayers' money. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, on taking over responsibility in the chamber, somewhat repudiated the remarks of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. He knew the weaknesses of the Minister and cleared the matter up as best he could. He gave an answer which I thought, to an extent, was satisfactory. He said that the expenditure on the four establishments is provided. He said that the answer to the questions is not yet known but that he would obtain the information and provide it to us. This is a complete repudiation of the statement that the information is available. It is not known at present. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs does not have it.

SPEECH.PARA: That answer is satisfactory except for the fact that surely as I expressed before, knowing our responsibility and our right as custodians of taxpayers' money, before we vote $27,000 we should have the answers which the Minister said he will get. It is a question of adjourning this appropriation until after consideration of some other appropriations so that we do not delay the proceedings. Then he can supply that information. This permits us to carry out our responsibility. It gives the Government a clean sheet to say: 'We made everything available to you, now vote it or reject it'. I think, bearing in mind the fairness of the Minister, he could say that he could do his best and give the information to us before the appropriations are completed, and we could proceed. That would end the argument. It would delay this appropriation until the other appropriations were dealt with. I do not think it is a question of reporting progress, it is a question of adjourning this appropriation until the consideration of other appropriations is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, thank you for the call at last. As I was the senator who raised this matter earlier tonight, I found it very difficult to answer some of the assertions made previously by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) and now by Senator Peter Baume, who apparently did not hear my remarks earlier. If he had he would not have come into the chamber and quoted from what he termed the Whitlam bible as to the setting down of guidelines for expenditure on the four government establishments. We know that the expenditures on Kirribilli House, the Lodge, Admiralty House and Government House are all lumped together. At no time have I or any other senator on this side asked for the breakdown of the expenditure on Government House or Admiralty House. I think those are the four establishments in question. We have asked persistently-I have done so since 1976-about this matter. Doing a quick mental calculation tonight, I note that this is the ninth time that I have sought this information in the Committee of the Whole, quite apart from seeking it at Estimates committee hearings, over the years. It is no good the Minister saying in here tonight that the information is not available and that he might get it for us and provide it to us later. Of course, once the vote is passed that is it. We are being fobbed off when it is not available. We will raise the matter again.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am upset about is that Senator Baume quoted the guidelines of Mr Whitlam. After quoting them to everyone who was listening to the Parliament tonight he said that his Government has religiously followed those guidelines except on one extreme occasion. What was that extreme occasion? Senator Baume knows. It has been said over and over in this chamber. It is on the record, it is in the Hansard, it is everywhere. I will state again, in order to put people's minds at rest and to give the contrary point of view to what was put tonight, the remarks of Mr Fraser in the House of Representatives on 24 March 1976.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who asked the question then, Senator?
—Mr Porter, the Liberal member for Barker in South Australia. It was a very short question; it took up only three lines in the Hansard. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can he inform the House of the cost last year of running the Lodge and Kirribilli House?

Right off the top of his head Mr Fraser was able to tell the House of Representatives what it cost. Yet these questions have been posed to Ministers one after the other in this place for the last five years, and they cannot tell us. They had warning about it. They are warned every year that it will come up. They know it will come up. Senator Messner even said tonight that I should know that I will not get an answer, but I will persist until I get it. Senator Baume can rest assured of that. That is why the taxpayers pay me, to ferret out where their money has been wasted by a very extravagant Prime Minister. It is quite all right for Mr Fraser to say Mr Whitlam was extravagant. He said:
Honourable gentlemen opposite do not like the facts of life about their leader.
How appropriate those words are to be thrown back to the people who sit opposite us tonight. Mr Fraser went on:
That is why they keep on trying to hide them.
That applies again to honourable senators opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?
—Mr Fraser said this. He went on:

SPEECH.PARA: But I think that a few people have a right to know and a few people have a right to be able to understand.
Again I agree with Mr Fraser's words. That is what I have been trying to do for the last six years. Mr Fraser went on:

Both places were costing the Australian taxpayer $280,000 and, since I thought that this was much too great a subvention by the Australian taxpayer to house the Prime Minister of this country, it is one of the significant reasons that Kirribilli was returned to its proper purpose as a residence which can be used by distinguished overseas guests who come to this country and not as a second house provided by the taxpayer for the Prime Minister.

I put two questions earlier tonight. I wanted to know the period of occupancy by this Prime Minister of Kirribilli House. The other one is the persistent question: What is it costing the taxpayer to maintain the Lodge? We cannot get the answer. It was quite convenient for Mr Fraser to castigate Mr Whitlam for what it was costing the taxpayer when he was the occupant. Of course, it is not convenient now to reveal to the public at large what it is costing the taxpayer to keep Mr Fraser over there. If it is good enough for Mr Fraser to use the words which I have just cited-I have hurled them back at the people who sit opposite-it is good enough for people on this side of the chamber to want to know what it is now costing while he occupies it. That is a simple question. Surely the accounting of the Government must be in a terrible shambles if the officers who are here tonight from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet cannot tell us what it is costing.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's reprehensible.

—Of course it is reprehensible. That is a word which became very popular when those who now sit opposite were sitting on this side. It was used every day in the Parliament. I am very disturbed when I look around-I have said this before in the Parliament-and at a quick count I see that 25 of the top Commonwealth public servants have been sitting in this chamber since 8 o'clock. It is now 20 past 10. They have had to sit here while we tried to get two simple answers. How often does the Prime Minister use Kirribilli House? He is on record as saying it would never be used by the Prime Minister; he was changing the whole concept of it; it was only for overseas visitors. The Minister could quite easily have told the chamber tonight that the Prime Minister has not used it at all, or if he has used it for a week, a fortnight or three weeks, he could have told us. We would have been satisfied tonight, for the purpose of examining these appropriations, if the Government had told us how much it cost to keep the Prime Minister installed at the Lodge. Of course, we know that it has cost an enormous amount because so many kitchen cabinet meetings have been held there, in the last six months especially.
—But life was not meant to be easy.

—Life was not meant to be easy. That is what the Prime Minister said.
