It is certainly not meant to be easy for the taxpayers of this country, particularly those on the lower incomes, but obviously it is meant to be very easy for the Prime Minister because he will not divulge to the taxpayers how much they have to fork out of their pockets to keep him at the Lodge in luxury. It may well be that if the Prime Minister were prepared to tell the Parliament what it was costing we would not have an argument about it. I put a similar question earlier. Did the Government provide the immediately previous Governor-General with a free telephone service from London to Australia? Of course, the Government will not tell us. We know that he has it or the Government would say: 'No, he hasn't one.' We do not know what it costs the taxpayers because the Government will not tell us. Nor do we know what it is costing to have Mr Fraser installed at the Lodge, again because the Government will not tell us. He was quite prepared, in an effort to embarrass Mr Whitlam, to tell the public at large what it cost to keep Mr Whitlam there during the last six months for which he was Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: What do Government senators think we are on this side of the House? We have been here for two hours and 10 minutes-we dealt quickly with the appropriations brought on before the dinner adjournment-in an endeavour to extract from the Government two simple answers. It is quite obvious to the people at large that when Senator Peter Baume came into the chamber and quoted the guidelines laid down by Mr Whitlam he was trying to draw a red herring across the trail. I did not think that he would endeavour to do that. Had he been listening to the earlier stages of this debate he would not have done so because he would have known that his contention has been refuted. No matter what he says, or how often he quotes those guidelines, he cannot alter the fact that the Prime Minister, his own leader, broke the guidelines and set a precedent so that we, in turn, want to know what it was costing him to occupy the Lodge. We will continue to seek that information.

As I said tonight, at about a quarter past eight, if we do not get those answers before the next election we will certainly get them after it. We will not need to present a Dorothy Dix question to our new Prime Minister. He will make to the Parliament a statement as to what it cost the taxpayers of this country to keep Mr Fraser installed at the Lodge during his five and a half, six or seven years of occupancy. Those figures will be revealed and they will not be very nice either, because the Government has tried to cover them up for such a long period. Such action represents complete dishonesty. Labor was accused of being dishonest in government but its accusers were unable to prove their statements. However, the present Government, by its attitude toward this question alone tonight and since it assumed office, leaves us with no alternative to accusing it of being dishonest. I repeat, it was quite prepared to reveal the cost of the last six months of occupancy of the Lodge by Mr Whitlam but ever since it has tried to cover up the situation and has backed its stand by quoting the guidelines set down by Mr Whitlam.

The Committee ought to adopt Senator Cavanagh's suggestion and pass over this item in the appropriations for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It should proceed to a consideration of the other groups that we must deal with tonight. It should not take a vote on the matter now before us. Let us do that tomorrow after Ministers have consulted the Prime Minister and have read in the Press the reaction of the people of this country to this big cover-up.

I repeat, honourable senators have only to look at today's copy of the Australian to see what a shambles the Liberal Party is in in this country, especially in Western Australia, Victoria and New South Wales. One has only to see the way in which my own State of South Australia is rapidly going bankrupt under a Liberal Government. When the people read tomorrow of the way in which the number two man in this country-as Senator Grimes said tonight, the number one man is the Governor-General and the number two man is the Prime Minister-is trying to cover the expenditure of taxpayers' money they will see it as nothing short of a scandal and a gross piece of dishonesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to discuss an item that relates to the expenditure by the Department of Finance. I have raised the matter several times in the last two and a half years and it is one that the Government has said it has considered. At times Ministers have even commended it mildly, but the years have passed and nothing has happened. I wonder whether we could be given a progress report concerning it. I refer to some means of redesigning or changing our bank notes so that various denominations may be identified by touch. This is a matter which affects tens of thousands of disabled Australians. I refer to those who are so unfortunate as to be blind. This is a year, I thought, in which we were supposed to be doing special things for, and making special concessions to, disabled people. I had hoped that as the year wore on the Government might give some consideration to this important matter or some indication that it would have regard for the special position of these people.

SPEECH.PARA: One point that has been made in this year of the disadvantaged is that it is absolutely essential that disabled persons be able to control as much as possible the environment in which they live; that it is vital to their dignity, comfort and general joy of living that these things should be made possible. I have been in touch with many blind people, and virtually every organisation for the blind in Australia on this matter. They all support it and point out that our present bank notes are quite difficult to identify by touch because the difference in size between them is not sufficient. They say that blind people throughout Australia are placed in a totally demeaning situation in which they are forced to trust people with whom they transact business as to whether they are given the correct change. It is quite reasonable to expect that from time to time they do not receive it. A number of other countries, such as Holland and Switzerland, have long enjoyed this civilised facility. I should like to know why the Government looks at an idea like this, says that it is a good one several times over nearly three years, yet continues to do absolutely nothing about it. I hope that the Minister who is in charge of the Committee, Senator Chaney, will not tell me again that this is something that is fine, that the Government is thinking about it and give me no better account of it than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot do very much better than Senator Mason predicted, but I can point out that recently the Treasurer (Mr Howard) announced that the proposal that a new denomination of coins be issued has been specifically referred to organisations for the blind, so that in pre-planning the problem that the honourable senator has raised will be taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that, as the Minister in charge of co-ordinating activities for the International Year of Disabled Persons, the matter has not previously been raised with me in the context in which it was raised tonight. Now I have heard the honourable senator's remarks and his reference to previous comments in this chamber, I will examine the matter and see what can be done to meet the need that has been raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer briefly to one matter that has been alluded to tonight. I was surprised at how long it took the Minister in charge of the Committee, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), to answer questions from Senator Georges and Senator McLaren concerning the cost of the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. The fact is, as Senator Peter Baume had to tell us later, that CHOGM will be held in Melbourne, not in Canberra, because this city does not have the proper facilities.
—I said that the retreat would be held in Canberra.

—I understand that the retreat will be held in Canberra at the Lakeside Hotel. Of course Canberra does not have an adequate convention centre, and as the result of the razor gang's decisions of the last few weeks it does not look as if there will be a proper convention centre in the national capital in the near future to hold such meetings.
—Or accommodation. Where would you accommodate all these people?

—Senator Lewis is one of those people who talk all the time about small government. He would not want Canberra to accommodate them or to be a proper national capital, with an adequate convention centre and accommodation for such a conference. If the retreat is to be held at the Lakeside Hotel, does it mean that the hotel will be fully booked out for the period of the retreat? If so, what will be the full compensation to the people who run that facility? I would be surprised if the hotel were open to members of the public while the retreat was being held there.

SPEECH.PARA: I have asked a question about compensation because I want to refer to one of the most scandalous episodes that has ever taken place in the history of this country. I refer to what happened with regard to compensation for the people who were bombed at the Hilton Hotel in Sydney last time a similar meeting was held. The shopkeepers in the Hilton Hotel were compensated very quickly for the loss of their takings as a result of that bombing. But what happened about compensation for the dependants of the members of the Municipal and Shire Council Employees Union who were killed in that bombing? As a result of pressure from this side of the chamber and from such people as the Honourable Peter McMahon, M.L.C., who was general secretary of the union in New South Wales, the families and dependants of the people killed were helped by collections taken up by the union throughout New South Wales. I must say that finally the Federal Government adequately compensated those families, but it took years and a lot of pressure from this side of the chamber. The shopkeepers in the Hilton Hotel were compensated very early on. I would like to know whether the proprietors of the Lakeside Hotel are to be compensated if the whole of the hotel is to be closed. We would like to know whether that is a fact and how much it will cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister for Aboriginal Affairs) (10.30)-I understand the question that Senator Sibraa has asked and I think we can get some answers for him. We do not have the answers now because we do not have anyone here who can give the answers. I can undertake to get that information to the honourable senator, if that will meet his needs. It is information we have time to get, as the conference is some time off.

—Having heard that exchange, I wonder whether the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) will now get an apology from Senator Messner who, when I asked a similar question, said that I was being inane.
—Very hurtful.

—I was hurt. An answer was available, but he dismissed me, pushed me to one side, and said that I was inane. Honourable senators opposite seem to think that I am hardened to those sorts of insults. I am not. I am sensitive and I was hurt.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Lewis ought not to laugh. That is a fact. It seems to me that there was some substance to my question. There was information available. An exchange between Senator Sibraa and the Minister seemed to indicate that the question was important. However, I still ask: Is there a possibility that the conference will be transferred? In spite of the fact that Senator Lewis said that there is no accommodation, plenty of accommodation and plenty of chambers are available. If necessary, the conference can be held in this place and in the place across the road. There is no reason why that could not be done. Is there a possibility that the conference will be transferred from Melbourne to here? What cost is likely to be involved? I know that the Minister cannot give me that answer with regard to cost straightaway, but there must be some calculations to indicate whether the amount of money requested in these Estimates may not be sufficient. If it is not sufficient, to what extent does the Minister believe it will be extended?

—I understand that Senator Messner has already made available to the Committee a statement relating to the cost of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, so I do not have to give it again. I have no reason at all to believe that the main CHOGM conference will not be held in Melbourne. I really cannot promise the honourable senator that that is so, but I can say to him that the Government's intention is that it will be held in Melbourne. That is really all I can say in answer to his question. He was not in the chamber a few moments ago when I was able to give another answer concerning the retreat to be held in Canberra, to which Senator Sibraa referred. If there is any more information, I will make it available to him.

—I understood the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) to say in a previous answer about the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting that the Lakeside Hotel had been booked for a weekend retreat. When he gets the information for us could he tell us the length of that retreat, because my understanding is that the hotel has been booked for at least a week? Senator Sibraa wants to know the total cost and what compensation would be paid. While I am on my feet I want to ask the Minister whether we can pass the votes for Treasury, Finance and Administrative Services in Group C and delay the vote for the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet until tomorrow when he can come back with the answers, if they are available, to Senator Sibraa's question and to the questions that I have been asking all night. We on this side would be most happy if the procedure I have suggested were adopted.

—I want to ask a number of questions arising from division 140.1.01 of the Department of Administrative Services which can be found on pages 105 and 106 of the explanatory notes. If it is convenient, I will ask them in segments of three or four. I refer to the reference on page 106 of the explanatory notes to the staff of senators not affiliated with a major political party. Could I have a definition of a major political party in that context?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will try to get some information for Senator Walsh. While we are doing that I can answer Senator McLaren's first question by saying that he may well be right. I will get more information. When I said 'weekend', I was working from an assumption on my part. I do not know which days of the week the retreat will be on, but we will undertake to get that information and to make it available to the honourable senator. He also asked whether the Lakeside Hotel had been booked for a week. I will undertake to get that information in some detail, if I can, and make it available to the honourable senator.

SPEECH.PARA: What I had actually suggested to honourable senators with regard to breaking down the aggregated costs of the official establishments into the cost of particular establishments was that the Government would be following the formula laid down and stated publicly in the answer given in 1975 to which I referred, but that if there were particular questions regarding particular items of expenditure separate from that consideration I would see whether I could pursue them. I really think I can undertake to do that. I understand what honourable senators have said; that governments really are the servants of the Parliament. But at the moment those are the guidelines we are following. I suggest that we pass these Estimates. I will undertake to obtain particular answers to particular questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following that offer, would the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) take into account that the itemisation we are seeking is the itemisation given by Mr Fraser in answer to a question asked by Mr Falconer? Could he give us a breakdown similar to that which Mr Fraser gave to Mr Falconer?
—I am not certain that that is the kind of specific information I will be able to get. I will undertake to find out. That is all I can do.

—In view of the fact that the sittings of the Senate are drawing to a close for the winter recess, I will not itemise any articles as I did at one time when I wanted to know how much was paid for a dinner set and I was told that it cost $6,000 or $7,000. All I am after is the total cost in the terms that Mr Fraser was able to give it to Mr Porter. It would serve my purpose if I could get the cost of running the Lodge under the same terms. Those are the ones we are referring to, not Mr Whitlam's terms which no longer prevail in this Parliament as Mr Fraser has set new guidelines. They are the ones we are asking questions about, not Mr Whitlam's, because it is a new ball game altogether now.

—I do not wish to be tiresome or to go over ground again, but I do not think that is possible. The guidelines I have enunciated are the guidelines which the Government is following at present. Those guidelines are being examined all the time, but to the extent that the questions that honourable senators are asking are simply not consistent with those guidelines, I doubt that I will be able to get the information they want. I was referring to particular questions about particular items. I could at least try to find out the answers. I understand what the honourable senator wants. During the debate honourable senators have made quite clear what they require. I am saying that at present we are following the 1975 guidelines. Therefore, I do not think I can obtain the answers which Senator McLaren sought just now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

The air strike was still on; it was not settled until, I think, about the next Thursday. But because I had been inaccurately informed by the Government, through the Opposition Whip, I neither came to Canberra for the Monday hearing of the Estimates Committee, nor did I hand on the questions to anybody else who was at the hearing. SPEECH.PARA: Having made that explanation, I will proceed with the questions. I now turn to division 140.2.01, Travelling and Subsistence-Within Australia, which can be found on page 111 of the explanatory notes. Again, these questions are relevant to the Government Information Unit and are really an extension of a question I asked earlier; that is, who authorises travelling allowance for the three officers-Messrs Matthews, Verbickis, and Power-and for any other officers to whom it may be applicable? Likewise, when cars are hired by those three gentlemen or by any other officers to whom the question is applicable, what hirer code is used? Does the Government Information Unit have its own separate code or is the code of a Minister used? What are the car hire entitlements of employees of the Government Information Unit? I mentioned before, and I do so again in case it was not so regarded by the Department, that for the purposes of those questions I include as members of the Government Information Unit the Federal information directors.

Those are all the questions I have, Mr Temporary Chairman. I realise that it could take some time to obtain answers to those questions. I am not sure how long the Senate will sit tonight. From earlier information, I gather that it is likely to sit until 12 o'clock. I hope that answers can be provided before the Senate rises tonight, but if not--

TALK.START.PARA: —No chance.
—Well, can I have an undertaking from the Minister that answers to the questions asked will be provided some time tomorrow?

—I am reluctant to give any absolute undertaking because I am not aware of what physical or other practical difficulties there might be in the way of getting all the detail that has been requested by the honourable senator. I simply say to him that I will get it as soon as I can. I have consulted the officers who are attending the Committee this evening. They obviously do not have that sort of information with them. The honourable senator has explained why those questions were not asked at Estimates Committee C. Of course, had they been, it would have resulted in the information being available by now. I simply undertake to do the best possible to meet that request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the Department of Administrative Services estimates, division 130.5.02-Contract cleaning. There has been an increase of 6.6 per cent in costs, and the explanation given is that the increase is needed because of an increase of the labour content of some contracts. Since the estimates were dealt with, I have learnt that all watchmen cleaners in the Customs House in Melbourne and in the Treasury Place offices in Melbourne have been or are about to be sacked. They are being sacked so that Wormald Security can take over the watchman duties. Perhaps the same firm will take over the cleaning services. I want to know whether these increases in cost have anything to do with the fact that contracts have now been let to those firms to do the work for which these men and women were once employed. I would like to know what the difference in cost is now that contracts have been let to those firms as against the cost of the watchmen cleaners and cleaners who were employed in those areas.

SPEECH.PARA: When we talk about the difference in cost, can we include in that the cost of the unemployment benefit that will have to be paid to the people who have been sacked? Some of the people who told me they have been sacked or are about to be sacked include a man of 55 who will be eligible for a Service pension when he is 60 and who has no way of earning his living for the five years in between and a man of 57 who will get no pension until he turns 65 and can see no way of earning a living in the eight years in between. I suggest that the amount of unemployment benefit that will have to be paid to those people should be taken as a cost in these cleaning and security arrangements. In the course of being provided with the information about the difference in costs and what is to happen to these people, I also would like to be informed of what arrangements is it suggested will be made by the Department of Administrative Services to administer Customs House in Melbourne.

It is an area where Federal members have their offices and Federal members who do not have their offices there, as well as those who do, use the area to interview people and to hold conferences with people. These members are in the habit of using this area after ordinary office hours when, presumably, the building will now be closed. Up to this point there has always been a watchman to let one in and out. I would also like to know where else these private security firms are to be used. Up till now we have had Commonwealth policemen guarding, for instance, the home of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) at Nareen. Are the private security services to be used in that area? Is the cost of that security included in the estimates of the Department of Administrative Services?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the sort of detailed question which one might be able to answer at an Estimates committee when a substantial number of officers who are concerned with detailed matters are present. The officers who are here are actually waiting for the consideration of estimates of other departments. A number of officers from the Department of Administrative Services are present but they are not conversant with the matters the honourable senator has raised. Again I will simply have to indicate that I will seek that information for the honourable senator as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: I will pick up one point in what the honourable senator said. If there has been a change from employees to contract cleaning I think one can assume that the contract cleaners will also be employing men or women in that task so that, in fact, human beings will be employed in that work. In terms of any estimate of what additional costs might be incurred by the Commonwealth with respect to people who cease to be employed and go on to unemployment benefit, that cost could be only guessed because the decision of whether any benefits are payable is contingent upon the subsequent work history of those people-whether they obtain similar or other employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

Before I go on to ask one or two other questions, perhaps we can be provided with the answers to those questions I have already raised tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any response to make. I think I would rather hear what contributions are to be made rather than reply after each speaker.

—I have another request. I asked for a breakdown for each of the capital cities as to the number by which the Commonwealth car fleet and the number of drivers has been depleted over the last five years. If so, what is the number of new cars that are now standing in the garage or at grass which will be used at times when the big cars are not available or not needed?

—I have no further information on the matters which have been raised by the honourable senator. The last question is a new matter which he has raised and a further point of detail on information he has already received. I again observe that that is the sort of information which may be readily available at an Estimates committee. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a further question dealing with the same matter. It relates to a question I placed on the Notice Paper on 3 March. I am more than somewhat surprised that at this time, with the Parliament drawing to a close, I have not yet received an answer. It is Question No. 394 in which I sought information about the proportion of hire cars and the amount paid for hire cars. A whole list of detailed questions are asked. My question arose mainly from an answer given to Mr Morris to Question No. 310. That answer, which was given to Mr Morris on 25 February, caused me some concern. That was the reason I placed my question on the Notice Paper. Some time has lapsed-April and May-and it is very nearly three months since I placed that question on the Notice Paper. As yet I have not received an answer. I hoped that I would have received it before we considered the Department of Administrative Services in the Committee of the Whole so that I could pursue the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: There was one pertinent question I wanted to ask which the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) might be able to answer tonight even if he does not have the full details. It arises out of part of the answer given to Mr Morris. The answer referred to the cost of Government cars at the ordinary rate of $15.60 an hour and a special rate which applies when a Commonwealth car is specially requested. I want to know which members of parliament and public servants have the right to request a Commonwealth car as against a taxi or a hire car. The Minister would be aware that on many occasions in this Parliament I have objected to the use of taxis and hire cars while Commonwealth drivers, whom we look upon as being very reliable and trustworthy, are sitting at home. The staff is being allowed to run down through natural depletion such as retirement, death and one thing and another. These drivers are not being replaced.

I have expressed concern in this chamber for quite a period that we might come to the stage where the whole of the transport section, not only in Canberra but also in other areas, will be taken over by private enterprise-by taxis and by hire cars. I think I have expressed my concern about this matter in view of the fact that many public servants are moonlighting on taxis. These people are already on the Government payroll. When I go to get into my car at night to go home I find when I ask a question of some of these people, that they are already on the Government payroll. I asked a young chap whether he drove taxis full time. He said: 'No, I work for Senator Carrick'. At the time Senator Carrick was the Minister for Education. One of his staff was moonlighting on a taxi. Our Commonwealth drivers are very reliable and courteous to us. They know our needs and they know where we reside. Those chaps are not allowed to avail themselves of overtime and they are not being replaced. This is of great concern to me. That is why I put that question on notice. I want to know in particular who has the right to specify that he wants a Commonwealth car. If we, as senators, have that right I am sure that all honourable senators would prefer to be transported by a Commonwealth car rather than by a taxi. In Canberra taxis are licensed to carry the ordinary citizens. When I first raised this matter I had people contact me who said: 'I am very pleased you raised this matter because when we come out of the pictures or a play at night in Canberra we have to stand in the cold, on many occasions when Parliament is sitting, to wait for a taxi to take us home'. Honourable senators will be aware that under the pine trees opposite Parliament House there is a great line of taxis waiting for a government job. Their job is to serve the residents of Canberra. They are supposed to provide a service. That is what they are licensed for.
Consideration interrupted--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 11 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the division I had nearly finished my remarks. I was expressing my concern about the rundown of Commonwealth drivers and the replacement of them with taxi drivers. I have nothing against taxi drivers, but I object to the fact that people who are already in receipt of a very good income as members of the Public Service are moonlighting by driving taxis at night when Commonwealth drivers are being deprived of that work. We ought to be recruiting more drivers. This would alleviate some of the high unemployment. I reiterate that all honourable senators-this applies to honourable senators on the other side of the chamber-have complained when they have left late at night and have to wait for a car because one is not available.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I have no objection to taxis as such. They are here for a purpose. The reason that they are licensed in the Australian Capital Territory is to serve the needs of the citizens not members of Parliament. Whilst taxi drivers are at the rank waiting to carry members of Parliament and staff home at night they are not available to ordinary citizens who may want to make use of them. That is why I express concern. I hope that eventually some notice will be taken of the plea that I have made here over the years. No taxi or hire car manned by a public servant who is moonlighting should be given work by the Government. In view of the very high rate of unemployment I think it is most necessary that the Government and the Department of Administrative Services, before engaging cars, should ascertain whether taxi proprietors and hire care proprietors are employing public servants to drive their cars.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of who is entitled specially to request a Commonwealth car. Of the last three cars I have had from the car pool, one was a hire car, one was a taxi and one was a Commonwealth car. I found that they all got me to my destination with equal facility. The honourable senator made a series of suggestions for the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) with respect to the administration of the car pool. I will refer those suggestions to the Minister for his attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) back to the answer he gave me about the watchmen-cleaners. I understand that he may not have the staff available to give some fine detail but I cannot believe that with the advisers he must have available from the Department of Administrative Services he cannot tell me whether the watchmen-cleaners in Victoria have been sacked. I cannot believe that it would take a great deal of time and trouble to get an answer to that question. I do not believe that the Minister cannot tell me whether contracts have been let to do the work that those people used to do in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think it is very smart for the Minister to say that we cannot take into account the unemployment benefit that may have to be paid to these people, because people will be used by the cleaning firms. TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Melzer is at liberty to press me for an answer but I cannot do any more than give her the best information that is available to me. The best information that is available to me is that the officers present are not aware of any dismissals of cleaning staff by the Department of Administrative Services in Victoria. That is the best information I have at the moment. I am sorry that I cannot provide further information this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier tonight I requested that the estimates for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet be left over but in view of the fact that we are awaiting the answers to many questions in relation to the Department of Administrative Services asked by Senator Melzer, Senator Walsh and me, I suggest that the vote on the estimates for group C be held over until tomorrow and that we pass on to another group tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been drawn to my attention that a precedent was set some years ago in relation to the information we have been seeking tonight, particularly in relation to the cost of the various government establishments. The now Mr Justice Murphy was then a member of the Senate. I was not here then. I dare say that had I been here I would have taken part in the debate. Information was sought about the use of VIP aircraft. That created quite a furore. I think Mr Howson, the then Minister for Air, was the responsible Minister. The Parliament was told repeatedly that the information sought was not available. Because of the persistence of members of the Opposition and in particular Senator Murphy, as he was then, Mr Gorton, who was then a senator and who went on to become the Prime Minister, finally relented and tabled the required documents. There has been no problem ever since. Twice a year the manifests for VIP flights are tabled in this Parliament. We have the opportunity to question the use of VIP aircraft, as I sometimes do. That precedent has been set. I think we are fast reaching a similar situation now in relation to the cost of running the Prime Minister's Lodge and Kirribilli House. We might well see a repeat of what happened during Mr Gorton's days in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Fred Chaney produces the information, he might become Prime Minister, like Mr Gorton.

—That is right. Mr Gorton went on to become Prime Minister. Unfortunately, I do not think Senator Chaney would like to follow in his footsteps. Mr Gorton was apparently too small a liberal for the Liberal Party. He was a man of the people. Of course, the Government to which Senator Chaney belongs is a long way from being a government of the people. Certainly, under Mr Fraser it is not a government of the people. I will not use the time of the Committee tonight to expand on that matter. I suggest to Senator Chaney that we postpone the vote on the estimates in group C until tomorrow, when we might be provided with the answers we are seeking, and pass on to group D, which comprises the estimates of the Department of Defence, the Department of Foreign Affairs, and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Otherwise we might find ourselves bogged down until a very late hour tonight, getting nowhere with group C. I make that suggestion to the Minister in all good faith.

—I was thinking about Senator McLaren's request to postpone consideration of group C Estimates as the honourable senator spoke. Any inclination I had to go along with it disappeared with the interjection by Senator Chipp. Now that I have been in government for a while, the last thing that I would want to contemplate is the fate that he suggested. The fact is that the bulk of the questions which have been asked and for which answers are not available tonight are of such a nature that they should have been asked before the appropriations were dealt with in this chamber. In my view they should have been asked in the Estimates Committee hearings. With respect to the detailed list of questions submitted by Senator Walsh, I accept that for reasons beyond Senator Walsh's control he was not able to put those questions in the Estimates Committee hearings. I do not think that was the Government's fault.
—It was so. I was misinformed. It was the fault of the Government.

—Senator Walsh's intelligence information cannot be very good. I regret any reason for his being unable to attend. In any event, I do not believe that the nature of any of the questions that remain unanswered is such that the matters should be held over. I think we should proceed to put the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney has opened up Pandora's box by saying that the questions that have been asked tonight in the Committee of the Whole should have been asked in the Estimates Committee hearings. Senator Chaney should know full well that when the Estimates Committees were first set up-he was not here and neither was I, but I have read Hansard and I have read Odgers' Australian Senate Practice-that there was an understanding in the Senate that no senator would be deprived of exploring any matter that he wished in the Committee of the Whole. SPEECH.PARA: My request tonight was a very simple one. The Minister does not have to have all the officers present tomorrow. I do not think that we will explore the matter any further than we have. If the Minister says tomorrow that we are not going to get the answers, as Senator Messner has said, we cannot go any further than that. We do not want to be bogged down. In view of the fact that we are seeking answers and, as my colleague Senator Cavanagh said tonight, that we are to be asked tonight to pass into law an expenditure of taxpayers' money without knowing where it is to be expended, we are asking that the vote on the estimates in group C be postponed until tomorrow or Friday or whenever we can deal with them. Let us get on with the other groups. I think I have put forward a very sensible proposal. If the Minister cannot agree to it, I for one will not be very co-operative in relation to the estimates for the other departments. I could be very awkward. I am not making a threat; I am just asking the Minister once again to acquiesce with this side of the Committee and assist the good working of this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a question about the Public Service Board. It has been drawn to my attention lately, that the Government, as this is the International Year of Disabled Persons, has a policy of encouraging people to employ disabled persons. Presumably the Commonwealth Public Service Board has been part of any such plan. How far has the Public Service Board got in its campaign to employ disabled people? How many disabled people have been taken into the Commonwealth Public Service in view of the staff ceilings and cutbacks that have been imposed by the Government in recent days? I would also like to know whether the Commonwealth Public Service is liaising with State public service boards in an effort to employ disabled people especially in view of the fact that it is using the Loan Council to impose staff ceilings on State public services.

—The officers do not have the figures requested by the honourable senator. I advise the Committee that as part of the Government's efforts in the International Year of Disabled Persons the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs has been promoting a campaign specifically for the employment of disabled people in the private sector. I think that campaign started at the beginning of April and is proceeding with some success. I have not had my attention drawn to any specific figures within the public services, either Commonwealth or State. I think the matter which has been raised by the honourable senator is an important one. Like the other matter which was raised with respect to the currency, it is one which I am very glad to have drawn to my attention as Minister responsible for co-ordination. I will undertake to get the facts from the Public Service Board. I will go beyond that and ensure that the matter is listed for discussion at the next Ministers meeting so that the broader question raised by the honourable senator can also be discussed. If one draws a parallel between the special efforts which have been made with respect to the employment of Aboriginal people as against the special effort which is being promoted this year for the employment of disabled people one sees that there is a very clear parallel with the encouragement of employment in the public sector and in the private sector. Indeed employment in the public sector preceded the campaign conducted by the private sector. I am afraid I am not as well informed with respect to the particular point which has been raised, but I will get an answer and see that the matter is further pursued.
—The question is that the votes in Group C be passed without requests.

—Before the matter is put to a vote I want it recorded that I had a request. Whilst the question will be carried without request I want it recorded that I had a request. I wanted to be provided with the details of the cost of running the Lodge. I want it recorded that I will not vote for Group C. I must accept the will of the Committee but I point out that my request has not been adhered to and I record my vote against passing this line of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not respond to the honourable senator last time because the debate can be prolonged if one repeats oneself. The various requests have been taken on board. I will ensure that answers are pursued and obtained as soon as possible to the various matters which have been raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the officers are entering, I wish to correct a matter regarding advice given to us of Estimates committees sitting on the Monday. Let me fill in the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) on this matter. On Friday we did not know that the Estimates committees would sit on the Monday. The information given to us was that if the air strike continued no meetings would be held on the Monday. This information was still the same on Saturday. The Government Whip and I were travelling to Canberra on the Sunday and we heard that night that the committees would sit on Monday. I point out that Senator Walsh is correct in what he said and the Minister was incorrectly informed.
—I regret any lack of information I had on that point. I thank the Opposition Whip for that explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose to speak at this time of the night is like coming on as a late second half replacement. I wish to deal with two matters which relate to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. They also concern strictures similar to those applied earlier to Senate McLaren. I am seeking information that flows from answers that I received on Estimates Committee D hearings. I have not had an earlier opportunity to do so. The first matter relates to an answer to Question on Notice No. 623. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has a copy in his hand. It dealt with the checkered career of a former Royal Candian Mounted Policeman Mr Stawiarski who was also suspected of having KGB links. Some weeks ago, when startling revelations were made in Britian about security breaches, I said to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack)-I was referring to a gentleman named Bennett who was a permanent resident in Perth and who never sought Australian citizenship; if he did he may not have got it-that we were becoming a latter day Botany Bay for peculiar people who may be spies who came in out of the cold or, in the case that I have mentioned, a spy who came out of the cold and went into it again. In the question to which I have referred I wanted to know how this gentleman got here as he had a dubious background.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister looks at the copy of the answer that he has he will see that this gentleman, who was a Canadian national, arrived in Australia in 1976 with his family. In 1978 he returned to Canada and in November 1980 he was issued with security authority to re-enter Australia. Part 2 of the answer says that on 2 April 1981 he was convicted for what is called a breach of trust. From that wording I assume that it includes people like Sir Anthony Blunt and people of the establishment who have been proved to have been involved in espionage for foreign powers. I am not overdoing the James Bond approach, but I want to know why the Department of Immigration representative who interviewed this man in Ottawa made this mistake which sometimes happens with people who are supposed to come from impeccable backgrounds.

The Committee knows that I raised a question regarding the former American legal mouthpiece for the mob in California named Wainwright. I think we had given Mr Wainwright approval to come here and that a Los Angeles court had indicted him. I think, the American terminology of a grand jury was mentioned. We have all heard of similar cases. I have a case of a person who wanted to get his father to come here from a European nation. Apparently the father had a weakness for souveniring car radios. He did not come here. A number of offences were involved. If we can detect a minor felony, how is it in this world of espionage that we get the dregs of ex-security people who have divided loyalties?

I would like the answer relating to this gentleman to be fleshed out. Did we make a false evaluation of him? I repeat that there seems to be a class assessment. The fellow in Europe happened to be a motor mechanic. I am not defending his standing habits. If a member of the legal fraternity a Canadian immigration officer, a Canadian mounted policeman or someone who apparently had some links with British security went bad, how are we conned into accepting such people when they get here? I am not satisfied with the situation regarding Mr Bennett who is also here from Canada. I would like more detailed information in relation to Question on Notice No. 623. Did we fail in our original assessment of this man? It is easy to get someone from Europe or South America if it is believed that he had a militant trade union background. But if a person comes from a top public schoolboy background in Britain or its equivalent in Canada we give him the benefit of the doubt. I might say that I speak with quite a bit of feeling on this subject because I, Senator Wheeldon and one or two other people who are no longer with us were members of the Townley Committee that did interview members of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. I will not go into the position in detail as it existed in those days but I do say that some of the material that I got was handed over to Justice Hope for use in his inquiry. I am confident that some of those double standards which applied in those days are no longer in existence.

But I do say, presuming we had ASIO operatives overseas-and we do have them-whoever we had in Canada was a misjudgment. Anybody who has read of some of the happenings that have occurred in Britain in respect of intelligence agents will know that it is not a question of loyalty; they are in it for what they can get. I suggest that we should not place any reliance on some of the defectors who come across to our side. They use the political system for their own advancement. When it gets sick of them and we make a better offer they want to be involved. I know that the responsible Minister on this particular subject has had the answer placed in Hansard. However, so that the readers of Hansard will know the full ramifications of what I am saying, I ask that it be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
Senator Durack-The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) Mr Daniel Stawiarski (Starwairski) migrated to Australia in 1976 and left with his family in 1978 for Canada. In November 1980 he was issued with authority to re-enter Australia which has been cancelled.

(2) Mr Stawairski was convicted under the Criminal Code of the Province of British Columbia, Canada for a ''Breach of Trust'' in connection with the duties of his office. He commenced serving a six months prison sentence on 2 April 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to one other matter about which I think the Minister may be aware. After the hearings of Estimates Committee D I received a schedule which set out the backlog of people who were using either the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the Federal Court of Australia for lodging appeals as a means of circumventing a decision by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that they should leave Australia. I think the position is epitomised by the case of a New Zealand national, Mr Brett Collins. I think he is well known. He is well known in Sydney. I think his main claim to fame is as a succesful or unsuccessful bank robber. We all know that plenty of Australians are asked to leave countries because they have committed criminal offences. I do not think we ask any special favours for them. The schedule that I received from the Minister sets out a mass of people who are quite obviously here in breach of our immigration regulations. I suspect some of them came across the Tasman. The Minister would know that the Opposition has agreed with the Government's proposal to impose tighter controls on people coming across the Tasman. In the case of Brett Collins I notice the concluding paragraph on page 2 of the letter I received from the Minister on 12 February states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Administrative Appeals Tribunal has affirmed the Minister's decision that Mr Collins be deported. However, Mr Collins is to appeal to the Federal Court of Australia on questions of law arising from the Tribunal decision.

Far be it for me to try to usurp the authority of the judge, but I have heard senior Immigration officers voice their opinions before various committees. When I succeeded Senator Davidson as the Chairman of the Immigration Advisory Council we used to get a little holier than thou and say: 'Look at how the Canadians got themselves into a jam'. They virtually had an appeals system whereby any tourist who went to Canada could claim on some legal pretense that he or she should be allowed to stay in Canada. The Canadians were inundated with appeals. Surely we should have learned from that experience. The thing that mystifies me is how we have cluttered up the system. Like other honourable senators I have always been one of those who have fought for justice to see that somebody who has come to Australia and wanted to stay here permanently and apply for citizenship, but where there has been some misunderstanding about his past, was exonerated. Conversely, when people have been knocking on the door to enter Australia, particularly people from countries embroiled in turbulence, I have always tried to see that humanity was extended to them.

But that is completely different from the position of those people who are hypocritical, cheats or sneaks. If they have come here on a tourist visa they well know the conditions of the visa. I say this with more force now than I would have a couple of years ago. I think we all know of friends who have travelled overseas and got into difficult situations. I venture to include the British Home Office in this remark because only yesterday I asked a question in relation to its attitude. All countries are adopting a tough attitude on people coming into and going out of them. I have a request to make of the Minister. It is a two-pronged follow-up to the question on the schedule that I have. The Minister has given me a list of the people who are exercising their rights of appeal before the Ombudsman, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Australian Federal Court. I would like the nationalities to be shown in brackets beside the names of those people so that I can dissect the information and find out how many people have prostituted the reasonably flexible travel arrangements across the Tasman. I think it is very important to get that information. Perhaps I could also get an updated briefing as to what is happening in the case of Mr Brett Collins. Has the Federal Court fixed a date for his hearing? If so, what was the outcome?
(Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mulvihill has raised a series of questions. He referred to an answer to Senate Question No. 623 concerning Mr Stawiarski. I have a little bit of further advice on that matter from the departmental officers. Senator Mulvihill asked me to flesh out the answer which had been given. I am advised that, in fact, Mr Stawiarski had no convictions when he came to Australia. He was admitted to the country as the spouse of an Australian resident. We are making inquiries about the matters on which he has now been convicted. We are awaiting a transcript of the court evidence in Canada. The further information which the honourable senator has sought is, we hope, on the way but we may not be able to provide that further information in the short term.

SPEECH.PARA: Concerning Mr Bennett who was referred to on page 293 of the Senate Estimates Committee D Hansard when Senator Mulvihill was asking questions, I have no further information at this stage. I will see whether the Minister can provide further information for the honourable senator. In a sense the inquiry which was then raised about the position of Brett Collins and the rights and wrongs of appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are answered by Senator Mulvihill's own comments about the errors which can occur in the immigration area. Whilst it is, I think, fair enough to say that we would want to see humanity-all honourable senators are aware of the frequent attempts of Senator Mulvihill to make sure that humanity is exercised in this field or a sense of humanity is brought to bear-the distinction between the people who deserve humane treatment and those who are hypocrites and sneaks, as the honourable senator referred to them, is one which will lead to problems at times.

The point I am trying to make, and I am trying to make it shortly, is that making judgments of this sort can lead to errors. The Government has seen fit to give people in this situation more rights than they had previously to appeal to bodies which are independent of the Government and of the bureaucracy. I take on board the caution which has been uttered by the honourable senator in his contribution to the Committee debate. I will refer those points to the Minister. The honourable senator referred us to the real difficulties which have occurred in other countries with the clogging up of appeals systems and the tightening of eligibility conditions. My advice is that in fact 30 outstanding cases are before the AAT or the Federal Court of Australia at the moment, which does not sound too frightening a total. But I will undertake to provide the information which the honourable senator has requested, namely, an indication of the nationalities of the persons on the list which has already been provided to him who are taking advantage of appeals to the Ombudsman, the AAT or the Federal Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a number of minor issues which caused me some concern in Senate Estimates Committee D. The first matter I wish to refer to is the additional sum of $65,000 which was required for travel associated with the Boeing 707 simulator continuation training. I think I should refresh the minds of honourable senators that what happens is that special training is given to the crew of VIP aircraft. Every year they are sent to the Cathay Pacific Airways simulator in Hong Kong. Each crew, after its initial training, needs to return to Hong Kong three times a year for refresher training. That refresher training takes a grand total of 12 hours at a time. The reason the crew has to undergo this training is that there is no 707 simulator in Australia at the moment. Qantas Airways Ltd does not fly any 707s. In fact I do not think any airlines at the moment are flying out of Australia using 707 aircraft. There might be some flying in, but that does not alleviate the problem that there is no simulator in Australia for crews to train on. The additional $65,000 was spent because a whole crew left the Royal Australian Air Force last year, and subsequently a new crew had to be trained.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, it appears that no sooner do we train an RAAF crew-we give them intensive training to fly these 707s-then they are offered better paid jobs flying these planes with private airlines overseas. Of course, a number of private companies are still operating 707s in Africa, the United States, Europe and South America. I suggest to the Government, especially in light of the razor gang's suggestions which have come up recently, that it ought to look seriously at selling these aircraft if it wants to save some money. That sale would make a large profit. It would be possible to modify the BAC111s that we have at the moment. I am not arguing that we do not need a VIP fleet. In fact I say we do. But the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, has flown in a BAC 111 from Australia to the Middle East. I believe that these aircraft can be modified for overseas travel.

Of course, the catch-22 situation in which we find ourselves at the moment is that because we continue to have these expensive 707 aircraft we have to train crews to fly them. As soon as we train a crew to fly them they are open to suggestions that they should fly for private companies overseas. I see no way in which the Government can stop this drain of air crews that will occur. We will find time and again in the Estimates these additional costs for the training of the crews. I suggest that if we did not have these planes and if the Government modified the BAC 111s the same situation would not occur. The offers would not be made to the crews and therefore we could save not only the cost of the 707s but also the cost of training the crews to fly them.

Another item of great expense which the Committee found was the cost associated with picking the tactical fighter aircraft. The Government now is looking at only two options, the F16 and the F18. Because of the Government's failure to decide on one of these two aircraft last December we found additional expenditure of $245,000 in the Estimates that had been spent just on additional overseas travel. I made further inquiries during Estimates committee hearings and I was informed that from 1978 until June this year $510,483 had been spent on determining which aircraft to buy. I was able to find out also that there had been 41 military overseas visits and 27 civilian overseas visits in connection with this project. That is a total of 68 overseas visits and we still have not determined which aircraft we will purchase. I hope that it is the Government's intention to decide by October this year which aircraft it will buy. If it does not, it seems from these estimates, that we will spend another quarter of a million dollars early in the new year.

Another item that concerned me was an item of $20,000 in the Department of Defence estimates which was listed to pay outstanding Telecom Australia accounts dating back to 1977 for installations at engineering development establishments but which were only presented for payment in 1980-81. I suggest that any four-year delay in presenting a telephone account from Telecom has something to say about its administrative ability and its inefficiency. I could understand a minor account being misplaced, but I do not understand an account for $20,000 being misplaced. Another item in relation to the Department of Foreign Affairs which has been raised by me and by Senator Robertson in the Senate many times is that relating to the establishment of a consulate in Bali. We have finally been informed by officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs that that consulate will be opened. No date for the opening has been given. We were told that the delay in opening the consulate was apparently due to staff ceilings. I believe that a serious fault exists in the system when staff ceilings stop the opening of any of our embassies or consulates abroad and especially one that would fill such a great need as a consulate in Bali. I believe that if Australian representation is necessary at a place like Bali then it should be put into effect immediately. Of course, we should not leave it to organisations like Qantas Airways Ltd. I believe that the Qantas office in Bali is doing a tremendous amount of work, every week, every month, right throughout the year which should be done by consulate officials.

Another matter that concerned me was one that I put to officials. I asked whether the Department had any way of monitoring the Indonesian Red Cross's use of Australian donations towards East Timor relief. After the meeting-not during the Estimates Committee meeting-I received an answer to this question. I am sure a number of honourable senators will be interested in the reply. The reply was that the relief operations in East Timor were under the joint control of the Indonesian Red Cross and the International Committee of the Red Cross until its conclusion on 15 April 1981. Australian contributions were paid to the ICRC. We have no way of monitoring the specific uses of these funds. The reply stated further that the ICRC had issued situation reports at approximately six-monthly intervals and that the Government had been satisfied with the distribution of donations. We should ask the question: What will be the situation in the future? Will the Indonesian Red Cross take it upon itself to issue situation reports? One thing that is clear is that there is a great doubt about our ability to monitor any Australian contributions to East Timor relief in the future. I think that the situation has been taken completely out of Australia's hands. That is the situation that causes me a great deal of concern. (Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have certain questions to ask in relation to the Department of Defence, under group D. They follow questions which I asked in the Estimates committee hearings and are to be found at pages 269 and 270 of the Estimates Committee Hansard of 30 April. I asked whether Brigadier McMillan was involved in drawing up the specifications for the Defence Integrated Secure Communication Network, or DISCON, and the specifications for tenders and whether he is now employed by a firm which tendered for the contract. The comments made in reply to those questions mentioned that a similar question, No. 641, was on notice and that a reply to it was being prepared for consideration by the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the answer to that question is yes, that Brigadier McMillan was involved in drawing up the specifications for that contract and that he is now employed by a firm which tendered for that contract. If that is so, and I believe I am reliably informed that it is, I ask whether Brigadier McMillan obtained permission from the responsible officer-I believe the permanent head of the department-as he is required to do by Public Service guidelines prior to taking up that employment. If he did not seek and obtain that permission, is he in breach of those guidelines which I believe require a two-year time lag after leaving an area of the Department with which he has had some association before he takes up employment with a firm which had business dealings in that area of activity?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of matters have been raised concerning these estimates. With respect to simulation training, which was raised by Senator Sibraa, it is cheaper to undertake such training than it is to use aircraft for training, so that in itself involves an economy. The honourable senator may have exaggerated somewhat the problems that we face in retaining crew. I am advised that we have lost only one crew of two pilots for the Boeings since 1979. I would merely acknowledge the point made by the honourable senator and move on.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the cost of taking up a new tactical fighter, I understand that the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) has given an undertaking that a decision will be made by October. There was some fear that the decision would be made too soon and for the wrong reasons. Honourable senators will understand that their purchase is a significant and a substantial one and Australia needs to be sure that it is getting the right fighter.

The matter of the telephone account to which Senator Sibraa referred is really one which suggests some inefficiency on the part of Telecom Australia and perhaps should be drawn to the attention of the responsible Minister so that he can pass it on.

TALK.START.PARA: —It did come up under this section.
—Yes. It implies no criticism of the Defence Department although it is the agency involved. (Quorum formed).

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry that honourable senators might be feeling a little petulant. I was about to suggest that, since I hope to have replies to the other questions by tomorrow and I will see what I can do about replying tomorrow to the matter raised by Senator Walsh and also the question on the Red Cross raised by Senator Sibraa, this might be a convenient time to report progress. I thought for a moment I might be petulant and remain sitting for a while but that seems an unworthy way to behave.
Progress reported.
Senate adjourned at 11.57 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many invalid pension claims were received in each State in each month of 1980.
(2) How many of those claims were granted following the initial Commonwealth Medical Officer (CMO) examination in each State in each month of 1980.

(3) In how many cases where pensions were recommended by CMOs were those recommendations then rejected by senior medical officers of the Department of Health (a) without interview; and (b) after interviewing and/or examining the claimant in each State in each month of 1980.
(4) How many cases were referred to the Director-General of Social Security in each State in each month of 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

ANSWER.PARA: As explained in my answer to Question No. 90, asked by the honourable senator, statistics on invalid pensions have only been maintained by my Department since 1 September 1980. It should be noted that these statistics-

Subject to these qualifications the answers to each part of the question are are as follows:
NSW Vic. Qld* SA WA Tas. NT ACT
NSW Vic. Qld* SA WA Tas. NT ACT
NSW Vic. Qld* SA* WA Tas. NT ACT*
(b) No interviews or re-examination of applicants are carried out by SMOs.
NSW Vic. Qld* SA WA Tas. NT ACT

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which of the following documents, which were included in 'An Inside Dopester's Index of One Hundred Examples of Secrecy', an appendix to the book Secrecy: Political Censorship in Australia by Jim Spigelman (Angus and Robertson, Sydney, 1972), have now been published: (a) No. 19-Commonwealth Solicitor-General's report on Aboriginal land rights; (b) No. 20-Office of Aboriginal Affairs proposals on Aboriginal land rights; (c) No. 21-'Report on a Reconnaissance of Means for Aboriginal Advancement on the South Coast of New South Wales'-June 1969; (d) No. 22-'Assessment of the Needs and Opportunities for the Aborigines of the Kimberleys'-October 1971; (e) No. 23-W. D. Scott and Co. report on 'Social Indicators and Social Accounts'; (f) No. 24-Systematic survey of Aboriginal health in the Northern Territory; (g) No. 25-Report of the 1969 Workshop on Health and Nutrition of Aborigines; and (h) No. 26-Office of Aboriginal Affairs report on discriminatory legislation.
(2) Which of the above-mentioned documents have now otherwise been made available.
(3) Which of the documents so far not made available would the Government now be prepared to make available either unconditionally or on any, and if so what, conditions.
(4) Which of the documents does the Government continue to refuse to make available, and why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Devonport Child Care and Community Centre

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister received any representations concerning the financial plight of the East Devonport Child Care and Community Centre in the State of Tasmania; if so, what have been the representations and what action has been taken in respect of these representations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I have received a number of representations supporting two applications by the Devonport Council for financial assistance for the East Devonport Child Care and Community Centre.

I have carefully considered the current submission for funding the East Devonport Child Care and Community Centre but as child care funds have been fully committed in 1980-81, I have no prospect of providing a grant this financial year. However I understand that the Tasmanian Department of Social Welfare has provided $3,018 to enable the centre to continue operations until June 1981.

There are two other child care centres and a family day care scheme in Devonport. Advice from Tasmania indicates that these services are currently operating at less than full capacity. For these reasons, the East Devonport Centre was accorded a low priority when its first application was rejected in February 1980. The situation has remained unchanged.
The question of Commonwealth funding for the East Devonport Child Care Centre will be considered in 1981-82 having regard to the priority for funding that can be accorded the application.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action, if any, has been taken on the National Women's Advisory Council recommendations, set out on page 28 of the report 'My Child Was Born Disabled', Australian Government Publishing Service, 1980, for legislative action to aid the handicapped.
(2) What other action, if any, has been taken in the International Year of Disabled Persons regarding rights for the disabled in Government legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question are as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 5 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the proposed Australian domestic satellite be used to provide a telephone service to remote areas of Australia presently without such a service; if so, how many connections will be made through the satellite and what will be the total cost of providing this service.
(2) What will be the installation charge made to each subscriber for this service.

(3) If some or all of the above information is not presently available: (a) when will the information be available in respect of each question; and (b) in the absence of information, what is the best available estimate.
(4) In the Request for Tender documents put out for the satellite system, what telephone service were tenderers requested to provide for.

(5) What technical alternatives exist for supplying a telephone service in remote areas and what is the total estimated cost of these for the same service as may be proposed under the satellite system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As part of the request for tender for the Australian national communications satellite system, tenders have been invited for the supply of single telephone circuits by satellite for subscribers in remote areas. Surveys by Telecom are currently being finalised to determine the number and actual location of potential customers who may require a telephone service in remote areas.

The extent to which the satellite system will be applied for the provision of these services and their associated costs can only be determined in the light of cost and technical information that will become progressively available as tenders are evaluated.
(2) A decision on installation charges cannot be taken until more information on costs and number of subscribers is available from the evaluation of tenders and the field surveys referred to above.
(3) See (1) and (2) above. Tenders for the satellite system closed on 4 May 1981 and evaluation is likely to continue until December 1981.
(4) The request for tender invited tenderers to provide for the following satellite telephone services:-
a standard telephone service for those regions beyond the economic reach of terrestrial telecommunications technology, providing one circuit only through a small earth station;
a remote telephone satellite service for small communities, or homesteads which require more than one telephone circuit or more extensive telecommunications facilities;
a transportable version of the multi-circuit remote service which could be brought into service at short notice in an emergency situation;

portable earth stations and interfacing equipment of relatively large capacity which could be used for the provision of 'thick route' telecommunication services on an itinerant basis, e.g. to cover unexpected delays in the provision of terrestrial broadband facilities.

(5) Telecom recently called tenders for a terrestrial digital radio concentrator system (DRCS), to provide terrestrial telephone network facilities in low-density rural areas. Tenders for this system are now being evaluated.

The extent of the usage of the DRCS and the satellite system for providing telephone services in remote areas of Australia will be considered as soon as reliable orders of costs for both systems are available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the total value of parliamentary retirement benefits payable to former senator, Dr Glenister Sheil.
(2) What would the total have been if Senator Sheil had remained in the Senate until 30 June 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In accordance with the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948 a former member of the Parliament is entitled to a parliamentary retiring allowance if he has a minimum of 12 years service, or has ceased to be a member on at least four occasions, or, if retirement is involuntary, he has served for a minimum of eight years, or has ceased to be a member on at least three occasions. Where a former member is not entitled to a retiring allowance, he receives a refund of his contributions supplemented by an additional amount, according to whether his retirement is voluntary or involuntary.

The amount of the benefit payable under the Act in individual cases depends, in part, on decisions of a personal and private nature made by the former member and therefore the practice is not to make such information public because to do so would involve the unreasonable disclosure of information relating to the personal affairs of the former member concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

Where a former member is not entitled to retiring allowance, he receives a refund of his contributions supplemented by an additional amount, according to whether his retirement is voluntary or involuntary.

The amount of the benefit payable under the Act in individual cases depends, in part, on decisions of a personal and private nature made by the former member and therefore the practice is not to make such information public because to do so would involve the unreasonable disclosure of information relating to the personal affairs of the former member concerned.
