ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations Law of the Sea Conference

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the precise nature of the United States Government's shift in policy towards the United Nations Law of the Sea Conference.
(2) Was the Australian Government in agreement with the previous policy of the United States.
(3) What is the Australian Government's attitude to the new position of the United States.
(4) Has the Government communicated with the United States Government concerning the recent shift in policy; if so, what are the details.

(5) Does Australia have a continuing commitment to the proposition, expressed in a number of United Nations resolutions, that the seabed, the ocean floor and its subsoil beyond the limits of national jurisdiction are 'the common heritage of mankind'.

(6) Will the Australian Government do everything in its power to ensure that the resources of the international seabed will not be exploited so as to benefit any nation or nations disproportionately in a way which would be inconsistent with the United Nations resolutions embodying the abovementioned principle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Third United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea unanimously agreed at its Resumed Ninth Session (August/September 1980) on a program of work which required that negotiations be concluded at the Tenth Session (March/April 1981). However, prior to the commencement on 9 March of the Tenth Session, the State Department issued an announcement on United States policy, the full text of which follows:

'After consultations with the other interested departments and agencies of the United States Government, the Secretary of State has instructed our Representative at the UN Law of the Sea Conference to seek to ensure that the negotiations do not end at the present session of the Conference pending a policy review by the United States Government. The interested departments and agencies have begun studies of the serious problems raised by the Draft Convention, and these will be the subject of a thorough review which will determine our position towards the negotiations.'

It will be clear in these circumstances that it is not possible to predict what shift in the United States policy (if any) will come out of the review. The Australian Government understands that the review will not be completed until after the next Session of the Law of the Sea Conference, which commences in August 1981.

(2) The previous United States Administration had supported the conclusion of negotiations on the Draft Convention on the Law of the Sea at the Tenth Session, and the Australian Government was in agreement with that aim. However, the wish of the new United States Administration to review its policies means that the timetable for the conclusion of any agreement will be extended.

(3) The Australian Government understands the need of the new United States Administration for more time to consider its position on issues of such importance and complexity. The Australian Government hopes, however, that the policy review being conducted by the United States will be completed quickly so that a comprehensive and widely-accepted Convention on the Law of the Sea, in which Australia has substantial interests, can be concluded without delay.

(4) Yes, on several occasions. During my discussions with Secretary of State Haig in Washington in early March, I restated the position of successive Australian Governments, that Australian interests in the Law of the Sea would best be protected by the early adoption of a comprehensive and widely-supported Convention. The same position was expressed by, among others, His Excellency Mr K. G. Brennan, the Leader of the Australian Delegation to the Law of the Sea Conference, to the Leader of the United States Delegation, Mr James Malone, during the course of the Tenth Session, and by Sir Nicholas Parkinson, the Australian Ambassador to the United States, to the Deputy Secretary of State, Mr William Clark, in April.
(5) Yes.

(6) The Australian delegation to the Law of the Sea Conference will continue to participate in the discussions on the issue of seabed mining beyond the limits of national jurisdiction on the basis that such activities are to be carried out for the benefit of mankind as a whole.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Royal Agricultural Society of New South Wales pay damages of $1.2m to the Soviet Chamber of Commerce for the cancellation of a Soviet exhibition at the 1980 Royal Easter Show, and did the Commonwealth Government agree to indemnify the Soviets in full against this Soviet claim.

(2) Does the Minister not agree that the Soviet Union would be more impressed by Australian opposition to their occupation of Afghanistan if we ceased to foster our trade relationship with them in so servile a fashion, to the extent that the Australian taxpayer is now expected to pay out $1.2m to the Soviets in order to placate them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(2) The cancellation of the proposed Soviet exhibition should be seen in the context of the range of actions which the Government took against the USSR following the Soviet invasion and occupation of Afghanistan. These actions demonstrated that the Government was prepared where necessary to pay a price to give expression to its strong abhorrence of this Soviet aggression.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are underwriting activities by the Insurance Council of Australia subject to the provisions of the Insurance Act 1973.
(2) What are the details of the Insurance Council's arrangements with the Master Builders Housing Fund Ltd, pursuant to the Victorian House Builders Liability Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the Insurance Council of Australia Ltd is not authorised under the Insurance Act 1973 and does not engage in underwriting activities.
(2) I am also advised that:

(a) the Insurance Council of Australia administered the Master Builders' Housing Fund Ltd Insurance Scheme on behalf of Master Builders' Housing Fund Ltd which is the guarantor under the Victorian House Builders Liability Act;
(b) the Council ceased to be involved in this activity in November 1980 when the administration of the scheme was finally transferred to another company;

(c) the scheme was purely an insurance pooling arrangement. Participating insurers-authorised under the Insurance Act 1973-accepted premiums on an agreed share basis and undertook to pay claims on an agreed share basis in accordance with the policy; and

(d) the Council merely administered the receipt of premiums from the Master Builders' Housing Fund Ltd and subsequent distribution to participating insurers on the agreed share basis. It also administered the collection of funds from participating insurers to reimburse Master Builders' Housing Fund Ltd for claims it had settled in terms of the scheme. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What measures have been or will be taken to ensure that if a system of block health service funding to the States is introduced, the States will be obliged to maintain funding of community health program projects at existing levels and to maintain the funding at equivalent levels in real terms.

(2) Can the Minister for Health give an assurance that bulk billing for medical services will be retained for socially disadvantaged people, by including not only pensioners and benefit recipients but also the many low income families for whom private health insurance would be an intolerable financial burden.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As I announced on 29 April 1981, the Government has decided that the funds it provides for public hospitals, the general community health program and the school dental scheme are to be included in general revenue grants. This will afford the States the greatest possible freedom as to how the moneys to be allocated are spent. There will be no requirements laid down as to the services to which they should be allocated. However, the Government has decided that, at least for the initial period of the new arrangements, the amount to be included in the general tax sharing arrangement should be indentifiable as representing the Commonwealth's contribution to the cost of the health services provided by the States.

(2) Yes. When the revised health insurance arrangements come into operation on 1 September 1981, bulk billing for medical services will be retained for eligible pensioner health benefit pensioners and for disadvantaged persons, including unemployment and special beneficiaries. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the cost in the year 1980-81 of abolishing the means test for persons aged (a) 69 years; (b) 68 years; (c) 67 years; (d) 66 years; and (e) 65 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The estimated cost in 1980-81 of abolishing the income test on age pensions is;
(a) $68m for persons aged 69 years
(b) $71m for persons aged 68 years
(c) $81m for persons aged 67 years
(d) $81m for persons aged 66 years
(e) $99m for persons aged 65 years.

These costs are based on the estimated average number of persons and pensioners for the year ending 30 June 1981 and include the additional cost of bringing existing part-rate pensioners to full rate. These estimates are gross costs in that they make no allowance for the revenue which would be gained from taxation of the payments concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, is the Technology Transfer Council Advisory Board to be abolished.
(2) What were the functions of that institution.
(3) Was it performing its functions inadequately in any way and, if so, in what way was it inadequate.
(4) What action is proposed to take over the functions originally performed by the Technology Transfer Council Advisory Board.
(5) As a result of the action, what Government services can be expected to be affected, and in what way will they be affected.

(6) As a result of the action will any information which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that information, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.

(7) As a result of the Review will any informed advice or co-ordinating capacity which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that informed advice or co-ordinating capacity, and what way has it proved useful when it was available.
(8) What is the estimated saving in abolishing the Technology Transfer Council Advisory Board.
(9) What is the estimated short and long term cost of not having the services of the Technology Transfer Council Advisory Board available to the Government and the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Technology Transfer Council Advisory Board was originally set up to provide the former Department of Productivity with advice and assistance on the establishment of a technical referral network for the metals manufacturing industry. That initial task was completed when a company, Technology Transfer Council, was created to operate the network. The function of the Advisory Board then changed to one of advising and guiding the directors of Technology Transfer Council and the Department of Science and Technology on the operation of the network.
(3) The performance of the Advisory Board has been entirely satisfactory. However, the Government felt that a formal organisation was no longer a necessary part of the process of obtaining advice.

(4) Technology Transfer Council and the Department of Science and Technology will seek advice on the operation of the technical referral network from a wide range of individuals and organisations in industry, government and the tertiary education sector.
(5) No Government services will be affected.
(6) All the information which was available in the past will still be available.

(7) Advice on the operation of the technical referral network will no longer be available as a consensus of opinion of a group of expert individuals and organisations. Rather, a range of different views will be available, which Technology Transfer Council and the Department of Science and Technology will have to assess and evaluate.

(8) There will be a saving in departmental expenses of approximately $1,000 a year. It should be noted that the members of the Advisory Board did not receive sitting fees, travelling expenses or other reimbursement.
(9) There is no identifiable cost, either to the Government or to the community, arising from the abolition of the Advisory Board.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 February 1981 (Hansard, page 147) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question without notice concerning the Holcroft inquiry.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Following the tabling of the Holcroft inquiry's report in the House of 25 February 1981, the substance of this report, its recommendations and the general conduct of the inquiry have been the subject of considerable debate.

On 1 April 1981, the Government's initial decisions concerning the Holcroft inquiry recommendations were announced. The Government acknowledges that the inquiry's report contributes a great deal of valuable work towards expanding the knowledge of airline costs and revenues and has accepted the broad principles expressed in the report. Work is proceeding on the detailed review of the cost allocation methodology which is a necessary step that also involves the updating of costs to current levels.
The Government considers that by its acceptance of the broad principles contained in the Holcroft inquiry recommendations it has effectively countered comments brought against it on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 March 1981 (Hansard, page 323) Senator Lajovic asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question without notice concerning an item dealing with discrimination in education in a publication issued by the Commissioner for Community Relations.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations is currently undertaking a small scale study which will analyse the textbooks most commonly used in upper primary schools in regard to Australian Aborigines as well as people of Indo-Chinese, Turkish and Arabic backgrounds. Student teachers from sixteen teacher education institutions around Australia will participate in assessing the extent of discriminatory attitudes and ethnocentric biases existing in these commonly used materials. It is envisaged that an evaluative report will be produced.

The Curriculum Development Centre is aware of the dangers of bias which can occur in school materials and programs, and makes efforts through its own products, conferences, seminars, etcetera to counteract the biases, e.g. racism, sexism-found in existing materials. Through its Aboriginal and multicultural studies programs and materials, the Curriculum Development Centre specifically endeavours to develop positive attitudes to Aboriginal and ethnic groups.

The Schools Commission, because of its wide ranging interests in education for a multicultural society, will review the report of the Commissioner for Community Relations when it becomes available and take account of relevant issues raised.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Code of Conduct for Australian Companies in South Africa

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 March 1981 (Hansard, page 318) Senator Missen asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice concerning the possibility of Australia developing or adopting a code of conduct for Australian firms operating in South Africa.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Government believes that the apartheid policy of the South African Government is manifestly unjust, discriminating and exploitive. The Government has made its opposition to apartheid widely known in Australia and overseas. The Government hopes that Australian firms operating in South Africa will be guided by the Government's overall policy on apartheid.

The question of establishing a code of conduct for Australian firms operating in South Africa is being considered further. Officials are currently examining the practice of other countries with more extensive commercial involvement in South Africa.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 March 1981 (Hansard, page 417) Senator MacGibbon asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and relates to yesterday's announcement that the contract for the development of the Winchester South coal deposit in central Queensland has been awarded to a consortium comprising the multinational oil company British Petroleum and the Australian Thiess and Westfield Holdings companies. Is the Minister aware that tenders for development of this resource were received from some companies that are wholly Australian, companies which have the financial and technical resources successfully to develop the field? In view of the spirit behind the foreign investment provisions of existing Federal legislation, will the Government consider amending that legislation so that in future cases Australian companies with proven capacities have first refusal of similar resource development.
I undertook to refer the question to the Treasurer, who has provided the following answer:

The awarding of the Authority to Prospect over the Winchester South streaming coal deposit was a matter entirely within the responsibilities of the Queensland Government. The Foreign Investment Review Board, which advises the Commonwealth on foreign investment matters, was therefore not aware of all the tenders that were submitted for Winchester South. However, several parties did inform the Board on a confidential basis of their intentions to submit tenders.
Before development of the deposit takes place, the parties will need to obtain the approval of the Commonwealth Government under its foreign investment policy.

The general objective of the Government's policy on foreign investment in Australia's natural resources is to seek a minimum 50 per cent Australian equity together with at least 50 per cent of the voting strength on the board held by Australian interests. Proposals that are not contrary to the national interest but which do not meet the 50 per cent guideline may be allowed to proceed if the Government judges that the unavailability of sufficient Australian equity capital on reasonable terms and conditions would unduly delay development. In that event, however, the Government will, as appropriate, seek satisfactory arrangements for Australian equity to be increased to at least 50 per cent within an agreed period.

The Government has taken note of the honourable senator's suggestion but to implement it would appear to involve Commonwealth intrusion into the procedure for the granting of mineral titles by the State governments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1981 (Hansard, page 494) Senator Rae asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, questions without notice regarding the financial statements of Trans-Australia Airlines.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The decrease in annual profits was the result of a number of factors including the decision to write off losses on Swiss Franc borrowings. The Australian National Airlines Commission has exercised its commercial judgment in a manner acceptable to the Government. Trans-Australia Airlines is required to conform, when producing its financial statements, to accepted accounting standards applying to the business sector of the Australian economy. The Auditor-General is of the opinion that the financial statements are based on proper accounts and records and that the statements show fairly the financial operations for the year ended 30 June 1980 and the state of the affairs of the Commission as at that date. The Government is concerned about the unfunded superannuation liability and, as noted in the notes to the accounts, action has been undertaken to alleviate the problem. It should also be noted that the notes confirm that, despite the increased liability, the assets of the Commission's groundstaff superannuation fund are adequate, on the basis of an on-going superannuation scheme, to meet commitments falling due for some time into the future.
On 1 April 1981 it was announced that the Government had decided to restructure the Commission as a public company. The nature and structure of such a company are currently under consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1981 (Hansard, page 495) Senator Jessop asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, quesions without notice regarding the superannuation liability disclosed in the Trans-Australia Airlines annual report.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March 1980 (Hansard, page 656) Senator Evans asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a supplementary question to a question without notice, concerning Cabinet oversight of security organisations.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following information for answer to the honourable senator's question:

From time to time the structure and operation of Cabinet Committees is examined. When the last such examination was made in November 1980 it was decided that, having regard to the volume of business and the similarity in memberships of the Intelligence and Security Committee and the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee, one committee could effectively handle all the responsibilities of both.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 March 1981 (Hansard, page 884) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the establishment of a bureau to record the plans of foreign companies wishing to operate in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

In order to achieve the objectives the honourable senator has in mind companies would need to disclose details of their proposed investment. The question of maintaining a register of foreign investment proposals was raised by the honourable member for Griffith in a question upon notice on 3 December 1980. My response to the honourable member's question, based on advice received from the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB), is contained on pages 448 and 449 of Hansard of 4 March 1981. I indicated that procedures requiring the compulsory publication in a register of all foreign investment proposals would have a number of disadvantages whereas the principal benefits that might be expected to result from such a register are for all practical purposes being achieved by the present practices followed in respect of foreign investment proposals. A major disadvantage is the fact that many of the cases coming before the Government involve commercially sensitive proposals and the interests of the parties could be adversely affected if such commercial information were made public.

One of the major functions of the FIRB is to work towards a high level of Australian participation in new investment undertakings in accordance with the basic objective of the Government's foreign investment policy of providing opportunities for Australians to participate in foreign investment proposals to the extent appropriate in the particular circumstances, with specific guidelines being set down for Australian involvement in new natural resource projects.

There are a number of avenues by which the FIRB can, and does, assist foreign companies experiencing difficulties in acquiring suitable Australian equity participants. For example, the FIRB may suggest appropriate avenues for publicly announcing or otherwise advertising a proposal. Where this is not commercially realistic, the parties may be referred to possible Australian participants who have expressed an interest to the FIRB in new investment opportunities.

The present policy and practice provide substantial opportunities for Australian companies and institutions to participate with foreign investors in resource development and other investments in Australia. This gives opportunities for small investors to participate in projects of this kind through shares in the Australian companies involved or through investments in institutions, which are increasingly becoming more directly involved in the development of Australia's industries and natural resources. Small investors are also having increased opportunites to buy shares in partly foreign owned companies operating in Australia which are providing greater scope for Australian equity participation under the provisions for naturalisation or other aspects of the Government's foreign investment policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the adjournment debate on 9 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1369) Senator Colston asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, to raise with the Minister for Education a matter relating to the first term closing date in Queensland for receipt of applications under the secondary allowances scheme. Senator Colston referred to a recent press release put out by the Department of Education urging parents to apply before the closing date, which occurred about two weeks earlier this year-on 16 April-because of the State's new four-term system.

ANSWER.PARA: On the grounds that the new arrangement may have led to some confusion among applicants over closing dates, he asked that the matter be referred to the Minister for Education 'to see whether it is possible on this occasion to extend the period by which applications may be lodged because this is the first year in which this has arisen, even if it were only for another two weeks'.
The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The press release mentioned by Senator Colston was part of the normal 'last-minute reminder' publicity carried out each year by the Queensland office of my Department towards the end of the first term. This was a follow-up to the extensive nationwide publicity carried out late last year and early this year aimed at making potential applicants aware of the scheme.

As in previous years, the recent publicity appears to have been successful in reminding parents that they must apply by the end of first term in order to attract a full year's benefits. The application rate once again increased significantly in the final weeks and by the closing date was still well above that for previous years, as it had been throughout the term. Despite the earlier deadline, about 250 more applications were received than by the end of first term in 1980.

Senator Colston has referred to the possibility of confusion among applicants on the closing date issue, particularly in relation to the use of the word 'term'. My Department's understanding is that under the new arrangement the four segments into which the school year is now divided are still commonly known as 'terms'. For some years secondary students in Queensland have been accustomed to a division of the school year into two semester periods of assessment, even though there have been three terms for vacation purposes. The fact that the second mid-year vacation now coincides with the end of the first semester does not appear to have affected the continuing general use of the word 'term' to refer to the four administrative periods bounded by vacations. It seems unlikely that parents who had noted in the Department's publicity that they should apply before the end of the first term would genuinely have believed that they had until the end of the first semester, that is, 26 June, to do so. Certainly the figures I have given above suggest that, if there was any confusion on this issue, it had no indentifiable effect on applicant numbers.

In these circumstances a formal extension of the first term closing date by two weeks would not appear to be warranted. However, it has in fact been possible to accept as being on time for a full year's benefits all applications received in the Department's Queensland Office up to Friday 1 May, that is, two weeks after the official closing date. This is in accordance with normal concessional arrangements under which, for example, a parent who has learnt of the scheme just before the closing date is sent an application and then has up to two weeks in which to submit it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1386) Senator Lajovic asked me the following question without notice:

The following is in answer to the honourable senator's questions:

(i) Although no standard criteria were laid down, persons wishing to be considered for authorisation as civil marriage celebrants must demonstrate qualities of capability, responsibility and general personal suitability. They must be capable of understanding the provisions of the Marriage Act and of explaining these provisions to others. They must be able to attend to the documentation associated with marriage and its subsequent registration. TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1453) Senator Jessop asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and refer to the slaughter of Lebanese Christians by Syrian troops who, I understand, were initially stationed in Lebanon as a peacekeeping force. Is it a fact that, in addition to Syrian military action against Lebanese citizens, the Israelis are also engaged in attacks on the Syrians in that country, presenting an added threat to the lives of the Lebanese people? Can the Minister say whether this matter has been raised in the United Nations Security Council? If not, will the Minister ask his colleague in another place to list this as an urgent agenda item at the United Nations Security Council with the object of sending a United Nations peacekeeping force to Lebanon to restore peace and to prevent further bloodshed?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The situation of Lebanese civilians in Southern Lebanon, in Beirut and in Zahle has been of great concern to the Government since fighting broke out in Zahle on 1 April. The fighting, which has widened to include most of the opposing forces in Lebanon, as well as the largely Syrian-manned Arab Deterrent Force and Israeli forces, is a profound threat to hopes of a national reconciliation in Lebanon. Hundreds of Lebanese have been killed and wounded.

The shooting down by Israeli aircraft of two Syrian helicopters near Zahle on 28 April, and the subsequent introduction of ground-to-air missiles into the area by Syria, have led to an alarming increase in the risk to peace in the Middle East region as a whole. The Government is glad to note, however, that some progress towards a reduction in tension in Lebanon seems to have occurred following Syrian Foreign Minister Khaddam's visit to Beirut on 28 and 29 April, and that Israeli Prime Minister Begin has clearly stated that Israel wants a peaceful solution.

The situation in Lebanon has been the subject of consultations by members of the United Nations Security Council and Secretary-General Waldheim continues to confer with the parties to the conflict. There has, however, been no proposal that the Security Council take up the matter formally and no proposal that a United Nations peacekeeping force for the whole of Lebanon should be set up. The Lebanese Government has announced its opposition to the formation of such a force, and this circumstance makes it inappropriate to propose it at present.

The Government is nevertheless determined to work actively within the United Nations framework to support moves towards a political reconciliation in Lebanon. Accordingly, on 1 May, at the Minister's direction, the Australian Permanent Representative to the United Nations advised the President of the Security Council of Australia's support for a firm and unequivocal Security Council statement calling on all parties to work for a ceasefire, to behave with restraint, and to respect the authority of the legitimate government of Lebanon.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1545) Senator Hearn asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware that an aid known as Porta Printer II, designed to assist the deaf with communication, is available only at the cost of $800 a unit-$1,600 for two people to communicate-plus the cost of installation? As most deaf people cannot aspire to highly paid jobs because of their communication difficulty, they would be unable to afford to buy this unit. Could this equipment be provided at a reasonable rental for those in need of this facility?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Telecom Australia has advised me that the Porta Printer II telephone aid for the deaf is available to the public through a private company, Intercept Communications of Camberwell, Victoria. Owing to a recent upsurge of demand for the equipment in the United States of America, however, supplies of the units have been exhausted. Efforts are being made by the supplier to obtain other equipment but it is likely to be some time before any is available.

The device has obvious advantages for the profoundly deaf who have been unable to use the conventional telephone. Telecom has given a permit for its connection to the telephone network and, as part of its contribution to the 1981 International Year of Disabled Persons, is to act as distributing agent for the company. In acting as a distributor for the private company, Telecom will have the Porta Printer units available on a sale only basis. It is not known whether the private supplier intends making the units available on a lease basis. The sale price of the units will be in the order of $500-$1,000, however, it is understood that the supplier intends to offer a cheaper rate to disabled persons and organisations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for National Development and Energy say in the Senate on 12 March 1981 that 'studies have been made by the Treasury and the Government of the various resource-type taxes levied by other countries'; if so (a) what studies have been made; (b) what countries have been studied; and (c) what resource-type taxes were studied.
(2) What is the Government's reason in each case, for believing that such a tax would not be of benefit to Australia.
(3) Have all of those studies been tabled or made available to members of the Opposition; if not (a) which studies have not been made available; and (b) why not.
(4) Will those studies be made available in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. (a), (b) and (c). I am advised that the Treasury has gathered what information it could on various overseas resource taxes, principally in the U.K., Norway, Canada and Papua New Guinea, and from time to time has looked into the significance of certain features of the taxes.

In April 1980, my Department presented a paper to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources entitled 'Resource Related Revenue Measures: The Community's Return from the Exploitation of Non-Renewable Resources'. In an appendix to that paper the features of some overseas resource taxes were summarised and a table was presented comparing certain characteristics of those taxes.
(2) The Government has rejected this form of tax measure for the reasons outlined in the joint press release issued on this subject by the Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister of 2 July 1978.

(3) and (4) I am advised that the Treasury made some attempt to bring together all the information they had gathered on resource taxes and to indicate the significance of various features of existing taxes in papers prepared for the Government's consideration of the matter a few years ago. I am further advised, however, that there have been no other papers prepared by Treasury giving detailed analytical studies or assessments of any overseas countries' resource tax systems.
The paper on resources tax prepared by my Department for the Senate Standing Committee is readily available through the Parliamentary Library.

(3) Has part of this allocation been expended by the Northern Territory Government on building and upgrading airstrips to accommodate aircraft formerly operated by the now defunct Northern Airlines.
(4) What part of the budgetary allocations for the financial years 1978-79 to 1980-81 relates to items which have been carried over from past financial years.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1981 (Hansard, page 490) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy in his capacity as representing either the Prime Minister or the Minister for Trade and Resources. I preface my question by saying that I hope that the Minister has noted that the British Government has allowed Taiwan's first commercial bank to open a branch office in London and that an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review states that the United States is now moving closer to Taiwan. In view of the fact that total trade between Australia and Taiwan is now approaching $1,000m a year, what is Australia doing to promote closer diplomatic and commercial ties with Taiwan which were broken off during the time of the Whitlam Government.
The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The arrangements establishing diplomatic relations between Australia and China in December 1972 preclude any possibility of the Australian Government establishing a trade office or any official presence in the Province of Taiwan. We recognise the People's Republic of China as the sole legal Government of China, and acknowledge the position of the Chinese Government that Taiwan is a part of China.
However this does not preclude private organisations from doing business with the province of Taiwan or establishing offices to assist such activities.

In this regard the Australian Chamber of Commerce has been exploring the feasibility of establishing such a non-official trade support facility in Taipei. The type of commercial reporting that would be expected to be available from the Australian Chamber of Commerce's Office in Taipei would have direct relevance to the overall responsibilities of the Department of Trade and Resources in providing guidance and assistance to Australian companies involved, or interested, in exporting and generally in the promotion of Australia's trade.

On that basis, the Department would wish to subscribe to the services of the Chamber, provided through its office in Taipei, to obtain commercial information not presently available to it and, in general, not widely available to Australian commercial interests.

The nature and extent of the commercial information that might be obtained by the Department from the Chamber, and the charges that would thereby be incurred, have been under discussion between the Department and the Chamber.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 March 1981 (Hansard, page 566) Senator McLaren asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Government accede to the demand made by the member for Macarthur, Mr Baume, last Thursday, 5 March-it is recorded on page 499 of Hansard-and impose a levy on live sheep exports in order to encourage further processing in Australia which in turn will mean increased job opportunities for Australian workers?
The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

While the Government's policy is to encourage the further processing of Australia's raw materials for export, the Government also believes that this development must be consistent with sound commercial practice and in keeping with the realities of the market place.

The pattern of Australian meat and livestock exports to the Middle East has been determined by normal market forces. The dominance of live sheep in the trade results from the fact that consumers in the region have a strong traditional preference for fresh killed meat. If the Government interfered in the trade by hindering live sheep exports the most likely result would be that the Middle East would take a much smaller quantity of live sheep without increasing the volume of its meat imports.

Indeed, by establishing closer trading links with the region, the development of the live sheep trade has probably been a major factor in the expansion of our meat trade to the Middle East. In the decade to 30 June 1980, sheepmeat exports increased from 10,000 tonnes to 86,000 tonnes on a carcase weight basis. Beef exports to the area increased from 1,600 tonnes in 1970-71 to 51,700 tonnes carcase weight in 1979-80.
The Government therefore does not intend to impose a levy on live sheep exports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 March 1981 (Hansard, page 711) Senator Mulvihill asked me a question, without notice, concerning the health of Royal Australian Navy personnel who served in the vicinity of the Monte Bello atomic tests and ship movements during and after the tests.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to seek further details and now provide the following answer:

No information is available at present in relation to the patterns of health of personnel referred to. However, mortality and morbidity rates of naval personnel involved in the Monte Bello tests are being investigated as part of the Government's survey of all Australian personnel involved in the United Kingdom atomic tests in Australia. Results of this survey will be made public.
Atomic tests were carried out in the Monte Bello Islands on 3 October 1952, 16 May 1956 and 19 June 1956. Following the tests, radiation levels were monitored by four ships:
HMAS Hawkesbury: 8.10.52-26.11.52 (intermittently)
HMAS Fremantle: 8.9.57-9.9.57

Following the third test, some 30 tons of stores including generators were embarked from Hermite Island by HMAS Karangi for shipment to Fremantle, and subsequent transfer to Maralinga for use in the 1956 test series. Hermite Island was the operational base for the tests and was not a contaminated area. It is therefore unlikely that these stores would have been contaminated.

HMAS Karangi visited the Monte Bello area on 14 occasions following detonation of the first atomic weapon. These visits were in relation to radiation monitoring, laying of moorings and light beacons, and transport of stores and personnel. Dates of these visits are as follows; the ship was at Onslow when the third weapon was detonated:

There is no evidence of reluctance on the part of the Royal Australian Navy in supplying information. It should be borne in mind that records of events which occurred almost 30 years ago, if kept, may prove difficult to locate.

Information on the current radiological condition of the test sites is contained in a report by Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council tabled in Parliament on 13 November 1979. A major clean up was undertaken in May 1979 by a contingent of Australian Army engineers; this work was described in a report by my Department tabled on 2 December 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1204) Senator Sim asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister seen the latest survey of international trade prospects by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade which points out that a key factor in the present international malaise is the widely held belief in industrialised countries that the problems of adjustment in problem industries such as the textile industry should be left until their economies achieve a higher growth rate? The GATT report points out that because the future of these industries is inherently doubtful they cannot generate a decisive investment momentum, even behind increased protection, and that at the same time protection lowers the prospects of more promising national industries. The report goes on to comment that protection inhibits industrial investment opportunities in the less developed countries and their export potential. Does the Government accept the views of GATT? If so, why do we continue to afford high levels of protection for labour intensive industries accepted as being unsuitable for developed economies, thereby reducing the capacity of less developed countries to generate export income essential to meet the problem of high oil prices and to develop economies essential to a stable world economic situation?
The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am aware of the views of the GATT Secretariat on structural adjustment of industry and the effects of protection on trade, especially developing country exports, set out in the document referred to by the honourable senator. Distortions caused by barriers imposed against trade in order to protect industries which are uncompetitive by world standards reduce opportunities for trade, including Australian exports. It is a matter of record that Australia has been working through international bodies such as the GATT to improve multilateral trade flows.

The Government recognises that structural change-both nationally and internationally-is an essential part of the process of industrial development. In recent years structural change and policies to deal with it have been the subject of searching examinations in Australia (White Paper on Manufacturing-1977, Report of Study Group of Structural Adjustment-1979).

As a result of this process, the Government has reiterated its intention of encouraging the development of competitive manufacturing industries which are more export oriented, involve specialisation in particular skills and products, use advanced technology, draw on wider markets to take advantage of scale economies and rely less on government support. To this end the Government has made it clear that tariff reductions are an important factor in encouraging adjustment to a more efficient manufacturing industry in Australia.

Although change within industry is inevitable, careful attention must be given to the community's ability to absorb such change and to accommodate the economic and social consequences of change. The Government therefore follows a policy of gradualism-for instance with regard to reductions in tariffs against imported products.

Both the White Paper and the Study Group report have acknowledged that industry specific policies will be needed to meet the special problems of certain industry sectors. The approach adopted by the Government is, in general, one of providing support for a sector for a defined period during which real efforts should be made by the industry itself to improve its structure and efficiency, thereby helping it to acheive a better and more certain long term outlook.

In line with Government policy the average nominal rate of assistance to domestic manufacturers against imports has declined from 24 per cent in 1968-69 to about 15 per cent in 1978-79, a reduction of almost 40 per cent. Australia relies mainly on the tariff which is visible rather than non-tariff barriers used by some other countries.

Developing countries have been major beneficiaries of Australia's trade liberalisation. Imports of manufactured goods from Developing Countries increased more than sixfold between 1972-73 and 1979-80 (from $255m to $1,612m) and increased at a faster rate than imports of these products from all sources. Their share of imports of manufactured goods increased from 8 per cent to over 13 per cent in this period.

Being aware of the need for developing countries to participate to a greater degree in world trade the Government operates a developing country tariff preference scheme. This scheme covers a wide range of dutiable imports and was recently extended in a significant way to cover the textiles, clothing and footwear areas.

Clearly achievement of an increased growth rate provides better conditions for adjustment to take place. To this end the Government is trying to contain inflation because inflation must be restrained if the problem of increasing and excessive protectionism is to be overcome. Pressures caused by inflation reduce growth and increase unemployment resulting in a declining resistance to erect barriers to protect industries from outside competition.
If inflation is not controlled Australia will not attain adequate growth rates and will not achieve the conditions necessary for greater liberalisation of trade which will benefit all countries.
